reviewText: muy bien
Beautiful set of fret wires. Soft enough for easy filing adjustments.

I care about my pedal board--especially about minimizing noise in my signal chain. I tried George L's and Lava Cable Tightrope solder-free pedalboard wiring kits kits and found both disappointing. The assembly process was time-consuming and the failure rate was high. On the upside, being able to cut cables to exact lengths is nice (until you decide to rearrange your board), the thin cables look great and are very tidy--great for wiring lots of pedals in tight spaces--and the Lava Cable ends look really great.

But the solder-free approach turns something that should be easy into yet another project. I don't like tinkering with my signal chain; I like playing my guitars and basses. So I read a lot of reviews and took a chance on these Mogami cables. They're not very pretty. I don't much care for "pancake" heads. The wire is a little thicker than either of the other contenders, though still quite flexible. But, you know what? They're just as quiet as the higher-dollar options, I haven't had one fail, and they're much cheaper. I like them so much I'm ordering more so I can pull the remaining expensive, solder-free, doomed-to-fail cables from my rig.
summary: Reliable, quiet, and inexpensive: save time and money over solder-free pedalboard kits

reviewText:
I dig this little stand. I have a few issues with it, but overall it does what you need it to do. One problem is that if you're a Gibson player, your headstocks are going to touch. I can't place my SG and Les Paul on this without carefully negotiating the angle at which they're placed to keep them from touching. Also, the angle on the cradle at the bottom is a little weird. If you place the body of the guitar closest to the center pole, then it really feels like the guitar is going to topple forward. I just place them further up on the cradle so they lean at more of an angle. It does have the rubber tie that keeps the guitar from come out, but I don't really trust it that much.

I keep it in my recording room at home, and it does a nice job of holding my guitars. I'm happy with it so far.

Came in very sturdy packaging with all pieces accounted for. I have played it for about a month now without issues.

It should be noted that I immediately replaced the factory strings with D'Addario Medium gauge strings. I would suggest replacing the strings...factory strings tend to be poor quality.

For $100, can't be beaten.
summary: Just replace the strings and play!

reviewText:
I've been playing guitar for over twenty years now and I've tried just about every guitar string in existance and even these Elixir coated strings.  I've come to realise that the benefits for a slightly longer life barely makes sense given the much higher price you have to pay for it.  Eventually, all strings corrode and lose their lustre and if you are a professional playing gigs, you change your strings so often anyway that to pay much more for polycoating doesn't make any sense.  If you are the kind that occasionally takes out the axe then maybe this would make a difference but what I do is I get the least expensive ones and make sure I wipe down and clean them, even using products like string cleaners and Fast Fret to reduce finger squeak if necessary and my strings last for quite some time as well except at a much lower cost.

Few people know this but only a few guitar stringmakers exist in the U.S. and many of them that are retailed are actually the same strings with different brand names.  Granted Elixir probably isn't one of these as they try to make hay with the time they have left on their patent of this polycoating technology but my thing is why pay so much more for strings when the benefit you get is really not so substantial as to justify the price?  I myself use generic Kyser stings for my classical and acoustic guitars and Memphis Electrics for my electric just because they are the cheapest I could find on the web and my sound has not been detrimentally affected in any way.  In fact, you are much more likely to improve upon your sound by using better amps and guitar cables than you are with strings; at least most people would be able to hear the difference.  Don't get me wrong these Elixir strings are not bad but you are much more likely to get a better sound by improving your technique (practice), getting better cables, pickups, amps, guitars etc than from just using these strings.  For better string life, just wipe down and clean the strings before and after use.  This discipline once a habit is good enough.

Peace!
summary: Take Good Care of Your Strings and They Will Last Longer!

reviewText: Arrived on time and as described.

A bit disappointing with this foot pedal.  I was hoping for the price difference between the SP 32 and SP 33 that this might of been an upgraded design.  Apparently it's the same design.  Note: the model numbers are different because depending on which keyboard you have depends on which model will work.  The SP32 will NOT work with the PX-350.  You have to get the SP33.

This is a dark grey plastic bar which doesn't match the Black CS-67 stand. The pedals are small and does not fit flush with the floor which allows the chord to slide underneath without pinching. I would of preferred a channel on the side that the chord could of been slotted thru.

The left 2 pedals don't appear to be as responsive as the far right pedal.  If you want a 3 pedal solution, this appears to be the only option though.

On a side note, does anyone know of a 3 pedal design that would work with the PX-350M that doesn't have the cross bar for a more portable setup?

For pictures, it's the exact same as the SP32 which I had first ordered by mistake.
summary: Exactly the same as the SP32, not sure why the price difference.

I've had this microphone for a couple years, but couldn't believe that I didn't review it. Shame on me.

I've used a number of microphones. Sound recording and editing is a hobby of mine, and in particular I am drawn to condenser microphones. I also am a pastor who has set up our current sound system at church, and I was wanting a microphone that was low profile, but was sensitive for those who are harder of hearing.

At first I wanted to find a large condenser microphone designed for more vocal work than instrumental. But the pulpit doesn't have a lot of room and none of the large diaphragm condenser microphones I was finding were low profile enough. So I took a chance with this one, realizing that it's more designed for picking up acoustic instruments, but hoping it would be passable for voice.

Using the cardioid capsule, this is more than just passable for voice. It's fantastic. All of my expectations for this microphone were far exceeded, and the best part about it is it's at a price point that won't break the bank. It's lower profile helps it blend into the pulpit so that it's not a distraction.

This is just an all around good microphone. Yes, it's mostly for instruments, but don't overlook it if you're looking for a low profile vocal microphone. I should say I don't do any singing into this microphone, but rather just speaking.
summary: Very Good Microphone for Spoken Word

I have only been playing the harmonica for only a few years yet I love to try new harps. It just adds a little fun back into my practicing and playing. When I saw this harmonica being played on a YouTube video I thought, "Wow! I want that." It wasn't just the sound that lured me to buy it but also the unique look of this instrument. I was really surprised at how reasonable the price was for such a specialized product so I ordered it. When it arrived I was even more impressed with it in person. It has a VERY solid feel to it and even though it has a different shape than any other harmonica that I have ever held before it fit in my hands perfectly. In a matter of minutes I was able to produce that kind of 'wa-wa' tremolo effect that took me a long time to learn on my regular harp. The genius of this design is that the reed plates and the comb (the exact same ones used on their Promaster series) are enclosed by the cylindrical cover plate, forcing much of the sound through the ends, making it easy to cover and feather with your hands. This should be a great choice for the folk, country and gospel harp player. Since there are no screws on the exterior of the harmonica I have no idea how you would open it up to repair or replace the reed plates but since they sell them I am certain that it can be done. I have always stuck to Hohner harmonicas and I still like them a lot. However, I am so impressed with this product that I am going to add Suzuki harmonicas to my list of cool harps that I really want. I am sure that I will be buying more soon! Update: 6/17/12 I have been playing around with this harp and have found that if you cover one end and blow in the other it will play all of the notes--both on the draw and the blow--and if you cover the holes with your fingers it is kind of like a backwards flute. Just thought that I would add this.
summary: Not only beautiful sounding but beautiful looking as well

For under $200, I'm amazed at how nice this guitar is!  First, it was perfectly playable right out of the box - all I had to do was tune it.  And it stays in tune nicely too.

I did replace the strings shortly after getting it.  There was nothing wrong with the original strings - no rust and they sounded fine - I just wanted something softer so I put on Dedario Silk and Steel light strings, which are much easier on my fingers and have a nice mellow sound.  I am a novice transitioning from a nylon string guitar so I needed the most gentle strings I could get.  Now this guitar is a joy to play.  Problem is, I get nothing done because I can't put it down!!!

And the spruce top is pure eye candy as are the mahogany back and sides. And I like the mother of pearl Yahama inlay on the headstock. Very classy! The quality of build and finish on this instrument is top notch.  It just exudes quality and feels solid and balanced in your hands.

I've done a good bit of recording over the years. This microphone has very very low self noise, low distortion and a continuously adjustable variable pattern.

I've listened to and recorded with this mic and compared it to many other high priced options. This mic is outstanding, the sound of the mic simply disappears  . . . it records just about anything presented to it very naturally with great detail, but without hype or over brightness.

I applaud CAD for keeping the price low which provides a great mic for drum mixing which would not be possible at the price point of this  more expensive functional competition.

I bought this pedal for $13.92 on January 2011, and all of a sudden, it stopped working.

The reason is because the bottom is not one solid plate. Instead, there's a part that is screwed on and connected to the pedal.  So over time, the screws that hold the bottom part together breaks off, and pressing the pedal does nothing because it just moves the entire part up and down, not actually triggering the mechanism that causes the sustaining effect.  I have no way to fix this because the pieces holding the screw literally broke off the part that connects the pedal to the bottom.

Otherwise, the pedal is nice.  It feels good, and it doesn't move around too much.  But what good is it if it doesn't last?
summary: Became useless after about a year

reviewText:
I live in NYC and I own a 22 year old all solid wood Takamine dreadnaught which has aged really, really well and has been set up just how I like it (e.g., tall jumbo frets). I love playing it---it's a guitar, it's meant to be played and improves with play---but to say it would be hard to replace is an understatement. Thus it needs proper protection. Well I thought for the longest time that meant a standard hardshell case. However, I have a serious back injury from some years ago. While it's mostly healed up, it makes carrying heavy, unbalanced loads quite painful. The guitar itself weighs about 4 lbs, but with a hardshell case total load was topping 20 lbs. Thus playing guitar in NYC is not so fun. :( I looked into various options, and was considering the different hybrid case options. The MONO sold me with 6.5 lbs weight and built in backpack straps. It carries nicely, has some good extra pouches for a preamp, tuner, cables, etc. I highly recommend it. Unlike the cheaper gig bags, I don't feel like my baby is unprotected, either.

Update: Sometime after I bought this case, I dropped it and my acoustic down the flight of stairs into my apartment. It landed on the headstock! No damage at all. It also holds an thinline or relatively small archtop just fine, so if you're inclined to play arches, you are in luck. I put my Epiphone IBJL Casino and Ibanez archtop in it all the time.
This is what I expected.  It is a good value for the price.
summary: It is a good value for the price

reviewText:

Preface:  I should have gotten this free when I bought the EVH Striped Guitar.  For the price paid for the guitar, it should have come with a CASE!  But not even a gig bag?  C'mon EVH!  I held off buying this for a long time because of that feeling, plus they wanted $100 for a gig bag!  Crazy!  Well the price has dropped considerably, so I went for it.  But, rather than rate the stars on that aspect, I'm rating based on the quality of the actual product.

It's a well constructed gig bag.  It's got padding, a side pocket and good zipper. It's a little overpriced, but it does have a couple things about it that stand-out.

The first is the plush interior fabric.  I have no worries putting an expensive guitar in there.  Most gig bags have nylon inside, which is ok, but I wouldn't want to put any nice guitars in them.  It also has a plush fabric flap that rests between the back-end of the guitar and the zipper, so there are no worries standing the bag on end.  Nice!

Like others, this also has shoulder-straps so you can wear it like a back-pack.  Something I never do.  But this bag keeps them hidden so they don't flop about, and in the process, adds a little more padding.

If you need a nice gig bag, give it a look.
summary: It's a Gig Bag, it's Good. It should have been included with the guitar.

reviewText: Excellent fit.  Works great.  Well made.  Follow the size chart.

I carry 3 to 5 thin zildjian custom A's (not too heavy as far as cymbals go), along with 6 pairs of jazz 7A sticks (also not too heavy) to practice and local gigs 3 to 4 days a week. I don't treat the bag roughly, as my cymbals are greatly cherished. But in under a year of purchase, one shoulder strap has already ripped off at the connecting seam at the bottom and the other strap is about to tear. I had to re-tie and McGyver the straps to hold up to even normal to medium wear. I'm very disappointed to say the least, considering this bag wasn't cheap. Also, those cymbal separators inside are very flimsy and I had to immediately insert my own that were stiffer so they don't slip down to the bottom of the bag (where the supplied flimsy inserts now reside). So my final review is this: After doing my own handiwork to beef things up, the bag itself is surely secure enough and design wise its a beauty but in real world usage it's not built to last. Even with light to medium weight cymbals the seams of the straps tore. I'll try another manufacturer next time.
summary: I'm very disappointed to say the least

However, I have found that if you insert a small rod (i.e. screwdriver, allen wrench or punch) in to the hole of the bridge ball of the string to use as leverage, it is relatively easy to pull the string into its socket.  Once there, it takes several turns of the tuning knob to stretch the string into tune, so there's no danger of it popping out once in place.  I believe it is well worth the effort. This is an iconic fuzz pedal and it was designed and manufactured right in NYC.  Yes, Smashing Pumpkins used this pedal but Corgan also used a Fender Blender (which is similar to the Big Muff but has an octive thing going on too).  This is not a subtle pedal.  It's cuts through the mix well if you are running into a cleanish amp.  I find that it gets a little muddy if I run it into an amp that's already breaking up.  I can say the same thing about most fuzz pedals though. This is not a wooly, splattery vintage tone like the Dunlop Fuzz Face.  It really has it's own thing going on. You can also run an overdrive or boost into this pedal to push it even harder and it sounds like Cherub Rock.  Back when I purchased this pedal I'd read that this version of the pedal was redesigned by Fran Blanche (from Frantone pedals) back when she worked for EH.  I don't know whether or not the current production models have been modified from that circuit. It's not the kind of pedal that I keep on all the time, but it's a cool tool for the sonic toolbox.  If I had it to do all over again I would likely buy the Big Muff with the tone wicker switch.  It's about ten bucks more and has a little more tweekability. Still, for what it delivers at this price point it's excellent.

reviewText:
My issue with these is that they are made to fit a larger soundhole / rosette than many guitars have.  I tested each included pickguard on a Martin, a Taylor, an Alvarez, and an Epiphone acoustic and in every case, the curve of the pickguard matched the curve of the rosette only when the pickguard was placed further out from center than I would have liked.  To be precise, the guitars needed a curve matching about a 2 and 1/2 inch radius circle to put the pickguard along the rosette where it looks best, but the Taylor-shaped pickguard is made for a 2 and 3/4 inch radius while the Martin-shaped pickguards are made for a 2 and 5/8 inch radius.  Yes, I realize there is no standard soundhole or rosette size and yes, I know these can be cut with scissors, but I don't trust my scissor skill or wish to change the shape of the pickguards.  In any case, the curvature was not included in the product description at the time I bought them.  Measure before you buy and see my picture for reference.  Hope this helps.

Note - the Hummingbird pickguard matches a 2 and 1/2 inch radius exactly.
summary: Larger radius than I would have liked

I have been using Elixir strings since they first came out, I was one of the lucky people who tested them.  Before Elixir, coated strings just didn't quite make the grade but Elixir figured out how to make them and make them right.  Bright sound that lasts longer than regular strings so the extra price is worth it against the cost of having to change other strings more frequently.

So why only three stars when every Elixir set I ever review is five stars?  Because I made a mistake in buying these!  The quality is excellent but these are HEAVY gauge twelve string set.  I play .13 mediums on the six string and usually buy .12 Medium twelve string set.  These CANNOT be tuned to regular tuning.  As I put them on my neck bowed and strings popped.  Realizing my error in confusion of intending to buy MEDIUM .12 instead of these, I realized these are for players who tune their guitar down two steps.

These are for twelve string players who tune two steps lower then use a capo to play at the normal tone.  If that's your intent buy these and you will love them.  If you want to tune regularly go medium or light, or extra light.
summary: Intended To Buy .12 Medium, Bought These By Mistake

PROS:
great sound, the eq offers a LOT of cusstomization on sound. The tube tone emulator really gives you that warm overdriven tube tone.

Size, nice and light and it looks cool with all the lights. You can easily store three different settings which is great for those of us who have multiple basses.

CONS:
Only one speaker out, that is a big one for me and the main reason I will likely only use this as a practice amp.

4 oms, another big negative for me as my GK cabs are all 8.

No effects loop.

There is a lot of talk online that this is no where near the stated 450 watts. I will leave that to others with the technical expertise to discuss.

All these negatives are right there in the specs so its my fault for not looking into it further.

It is a nice little amp, I won't be replacing my GK with it anytime soon but for a practice or back-up I can recommend it.

I heard about these Cobalts and was eager to try them out after I heard them on Youtube.  They were fairly easy to install, although the wires are quite stiff (which is good...these suckers felt like they could hold a LOT more tension than my old strings).  Once on, I played them on a few songs (one of my favorites being Synchronicity II by The Police).  These string sound a lot brighter with a deeper, yet very subtle hummy-growl to them.  It's hard to explain, but there are several Youtube videos out there that allow you to sample them...the Cobalt material does sound different, but in a very, very good way.

I'll update my review to include any notes on longevity, but so far I'm loving these strings a lot...the strings sound great and what's better is that the material feels a little smoother...they're easier on my fret-fingers, especially for sliding.  Highly recommend!

reviewText: There is confusion in the keyboard world about "weighted keys".  There are essentially two ways to weight keys.  1.  using a spring and 2. using actual weights on the keys.  There pros and cons with both methods.  Notice when you press a spring that it gets more difficult to press the farther down you go.  When you press a lever with a weight attached, it takes an initial budge to get it going, but once it's in motion, the inertia of the key actually causes the key to get easier to push when reaching the bottom (and to hold down easier than the spring).  Most pianists prefer the actual weights on the keys because a real piano uses that method.  The springs are more difficult to play when one is not used to it.  However an organ uses springs, so organists move over to a spring action much easier than a weighted action. So sounds that are sustained like organs, strings, most orchestral instruments (flutes, trumpets etc) and pad sounds are easier with the springs, while the percussive sounds like piano, harp, guitar, drums, and other play easier on the weighted keys.  There would have to be a 2 oz weight for every key to accomplish the weighted feel.  2 x 88 keys is 172 oz or 11 pounds that would be added to the total weight of the keyboard.  Lately, some keyboards are adding a swinging weight that gives more lifelike feel to the keys as in a swinging hammer hitting the strings. Those almost duplicate the feel of a real piano.  Spring keyboards have the advantage of being lighter and cheaper to build.  Weighted keys add more weight and price to the keyboard.  The Williams keyboard uses springs.  It's not easy to tell if a keyboard has one or the other since almost all manufacturers us terms like semi-weighted (which is always springs) and in this case hammer action which here is meaningless.  But usually the price and the weight of the instrument will give it away.

If you have a problem with ground loop hum in your analog audio interconnects, this box will provide ground isolation safely, which will eliminate the ground loops without the risk of electric shock.

I was having trouble connecting my Zoom G5n to my guitar amplifier. Because the Zoom was also connected to my PC via a USB cable, the PC was grounding the Zoom via the shield of the USB. My amp is also grounded, so when I connected the Zoom to my amp I was getting an annoying hum whether I went into the front input or the effects return. This was a combination of 120Hz mains hum and some high frequency whistling sounds presumably caused by signals on the USB bus getting coupled into my guitar signal chain.

Using this box has completely killed the hum. I've not noticed any degradation in the signal quality.
Nice assortment. Can't really beat it for the price.

This is the most maddeningly bipolar controller I have ever loved. The mini-keys are, in a word, atrocious. Arturia would have been far better off making this slightly larger in order to accommodate full size keys (as their Analog Experience: The Player did.)I find the sliders, where one might expect mod and pitch bend wheels, to be inconvenient and clumsy, not responding well, and simply not having the right feel for this product. Despite those complaints, however, I do like and recommend the controller. First and foremost, the assignable control knobs are a pure joy to use, either when coupled with Arturia's Analog Lab software, or with, for example, Native Instruments' Reaktor-- they are a pure godsend, and they make using softsynths a much happier experience. Likewise the assignable pads, which can be used as triggers, or set as latched switches for background sequences. Good stuff all around. On a purely aesthetic note, the look of the thing is classic Arturia, which is to say, gorgeous. It has a cream colored body with simple but attractive wood end panels. This unit does NOT look or feel like a cheap piece of plastic crap, unlike so many of its peers.
  The real joy of the package, however, is in the Analog Lab software. This is everything the Analog Player software tried to be, and better. Completely avoiding the nagging loop-point clicking that their earlier software seemed to be plagued by, Analog Lab is intuitive, well organized, and chock full of classic synth sounds, from pads, to leads, drums, special effects, and oh, the glorious arpeggios. If you like electronica, the arpeggios alone will trip your trigger. This software is among the finest products I have ever used, and I've used a lot of 'em. All in all, I would say that the package is well worth the price. You could buy a cheaper controller, but if you do, you'll probably eventually wish you'd bought the Arturia.

This audio interface is simply one of the best you can find out there. There are many things about it that are advantageous for recording that I find delightful. Essentially, in my mind, I think of it as its own CPU, running plug-ins and NOT taxing your computer's CPU. Here are a few things about the Apollo that make it great:

Design:
I used many different interfaces over the years, and this is by far the most simple and elegant in appearance. The front of the Apollo seems as if to give a nod to the older days of NASA when the name "Apollo" was a household word.

The rear panel of the Apollo has the basics. Two Mic/line inputs, Monitor L/R, Two Line Out, Optical in, Headphone port on the front, and a Thunderbolt port. The minimal approach allows for a compact design, but can also limit usage.

Connectivity:
First off, let me say that I love the usage of a Thunderbolt port for an audio interface. Not many company's have done this, and it allows for some of the fastest data transfer possible. The only negative sides is that they don't supply a cable. For an interface at this price point, they should.

Audio Quality:
In the end, this is what matters the most. With either a mic plugged in or a line level instrument everything sounds warmer, clearer, and bigger than any other interface that I've used. Between the clarity and warmth of the pre-amps combined with all of the "vintage" plug-ins puts this interface at the forefront of the comparable brands on the market. This is, where the Apollo Twin is a winner!

As a freelancer, I occasionally work with a band that plays the Midwest, performing on a near-weekly basis.  These are seasoned veterans who have no interest in gear per se and even less interest in brand cachet.  It's all about money to them.  I couldn't believe it when I first saw the group using these Nady mics (even lower-priced several years ago) and insisting they were as good as Shure SM-57's and 58's.  I still don't believe the quality of workmanship compares (any casual empirical test of build quality will prove as much).  But these Nady's handle the announcing, the vocals, and, when needed, the softer sounding instruments (flute, harmonica), and none has broken or quit on my watch.

I'm a keyboardist, so mic power and fidelity don't affect me.  I'm only a trifle mortified when there are musicians in the audience who catch on to how cheap we are when it comes to the all-important "gear component."  At the same time, my embarrassment, I confess, is not unmixed with a bit of demonic glee.  After all, who's playing--and getting paid for it?

After receiving the Dunlop Dual Design Straplok System already installed on my Gibson Standard electric (7.36 lbs.), and liking them, I decided to try installing them on my Gibson Studio electric (7.23 lbs.). No problem. Just follow the instructions exactly and they will work perfectly. I had no problem either installing them nor using them since the installation. Money well spent making sure my stringed instrument does not accidentally fall to the ground. Besides safety I also like being able to swap out my straps on my guitars. It's a nice convenience. If you are so inclined you can use the same strap for all your guitars. If you are not sure if they will work on your brand guitar seek out an online forum and either search that forum for the answer or join and ask your questions. You've got a pricey piece of wood there and you will want to take care of it properly. What I don't care for, but feel okay with because they work so well, is how big they seem to be. They don't get in the way when being used but look almost out of place. That is why I chose Black for my subsequent sets. Helps keep the product's profile down a bit. Other than that, the product works as advertised. NOTE: As of June 2014 I have installed two other sets and all are still working as expected. Do remember to check and make sure your hardware is secure. After repeated use the screws can come loose and there will be trouble if this happens. Do NOT use any glue in case you need to swap out the Straploks in the future. Addendum October 2015: All strap locks installed continue to work without any issues.
summary: Gibson Good:  Dunlop Dual Design Straploks

I work  at a professional haunted house and I usually use a couple fog machines outside in the wooded trail that we have. I have used everything from the walmart fog machines and juice to chauvet fog machines and high end fog juice.

Last year was my first year trying out froggys and I was excited because of all the hype they have. I also ordered a gallon of code 6 fog juice as well just in case I didn't like one or the other. The fog machine I used on both of them was a chauvet fog machine at 20,000 cfm. Also I diluted each for juice at 1:1 with distilled water and a splash of distilled white vinegar. This was recommended by froggy's to dilute the juice so it won't clog or ruin the fog machine. I also added in the vinegar to help keep things clean since chauvet's can die if not taken well care of.

Comparing this stuff to the cheaper walmart brand there is a difference. It's thicker, doesn't smell bad if at all and hang around more. However the code 6 lasted a lot longer than froggy's. both were used right after one another with minimal to no wind on the same night with the same temperatures in the same location. I also tried it the next night and use froggy's first to see if the machine temp had anything to do with it. Same results. The froggy's just didn't last for me outside. I haven't used it inside but I don't think there would be different results.

I would also like to point out that there are some internet trolls that froggy has or a couple fanboys of froggy's on amazon. My last review I recently took down since it saw too many people leaving negative responses toward it. It was an honest review just like this one and I wasn't being biased. Also I left a 5 star review for code 6 and was thanked by the seller but that is also getting negative reviews as well. Every review for code 6 is positive besides 2. And every positive review has 2 dislikes. I highly suspect froggys is jealous of their competition and trying to spam other reviews on their competition. It's not a coincidence that every single positive review has 2 thumbs down and 1 thumb up from people reading them.

I will never by froggys again and if I see someone with a fog machine I will point them in the opposite direction.

This is an Ibanez Tube Screamer clone.  It gives a nice tube like break up.  Also a bit of a volume boost if you want it, though you can twidle with the knobs to get to unity gain.  It's one of those effects you can leave on all the time.  It has slightly less low mid range than the Ibanez, and slightly more upper mid break up.  Definitely an overdrive, not a distortion.  I like it. All in all, a darn good pedal.  Plus it comes with a 5 year warranty, a battery and a wall wart!  Whoooo-hoooo!  I got it at one of the amazon affiliates for a great price, amazon and musicians friend were a lot more.

Update 11-29-2012
The on / off switch became glitchy.  It wouldn't turn on unless I hit it just right, or it would cut out.  I sent it back to BBE to have the switch replaced.  They did it.  Got it back in two weeks and it's good as new.  All under warranty, just had to pay for shipping back to BBE.  Excellent service!!!!!!!!!!

Glad to see a company stands behing what they sell.
summary: Green Screamer --- A darn good pedal

Originally I wrote a two-star review for this amp, because when I did a side-by-side subwoofer listening test between the iNuke 6000 (1,500w/side into 8 ohms) and my Alesis Matica 900 (270w/side into 8 ohms) I heard no difference in volume.  Both amps clipped at the same apparent loudness. I was disappointed. But the disappointment didn't last very long...

When my band first used the iNuke 6000 as a subwoofer amp at an outdoor festival, it sounded like an entirely different amp than what I had tested at home. It was loud. Really loud! It pushed my 21" downward-firing subs like they've never been pushed before. The kick drum was producing a solid, deep "whump!" while only the first signal indicator light on the iNuke was lighting up.

I didn't have my Matica along to do a comparison, but I KNOW my Matica could not have reached that volume. At just half that volume, my Matica's clip light would have been sputtering like a fluorescent hospital light in a low-budget horror movie.

So why did I get all that volume with the iNuke on the gig and not when testing the amp at home? I have no idea, but I'm guessing there might have been a difference in line voltage between my house the venue, and maybe this amp requires clean voltage. I just don't know. All I can tell you is that I was more than impressed with how well the iNuke worked on the gig. My subwoofers filled the tent beyond my expectations. I was never a fan of Behringer in general, but I believe in giving credit where it is due, and Behringer really came through on this amp.

UPDATE 2017: I've used the iNuke 6000 at several outdoor venues over the past several of years, and it's been consistently and reliably cranking out at full volume.

IN CONCLUSION: I've worked with a lot of different PA amplifiers over the years (AB, Alesis, Crown, Stewart, QSC, etc.) and when I feel how light this amp is, hear how much volume it puts out, and see how little it costs, I have to consider this amp to be one of the most groundbreaking values ever offered in professional audio amplification. (Unfortunately, it's also one of the ugliest amplifiers in existence, too... it kind of looks like what you'd get if a TIE fighter crashed into the Chrysler Building.)
summary: You really get a lot of boom for the buck

I got this guitar for Christmas.  To be honest, I'm not all that great a guitar player, but it's a hobby of mine.  So I don't shell out a lot of money for high-end equipment.  That being said, I love this guitar.  The tuners work well with virtually no slip.  The action and feel is really nice (you'll undoubtedly need to get it adjusted when you first get it), and the sound on it is pretty bass-heavy, meaning it would probably do well for metal styles.  The pickups are nothing to write home about, which if you're a more experience guitarist, you'll probably swap these out right away - the stock stuff is fairly boring and average.  I get a decent amount of sustain off of this instrument, which is a definate plus.  Compared to some other guitars that I've played, this thing is built like a tank, and a bit awkward to manuver with if in an enclosed space.  The headstock feels perticularly cumbersome, and (again) can make things difficuly when you're moving around in tight quarters.  But none of that has any real bearing on the guitar overall.  But is does feel like you've slung a beast over your shoulders.

The only downside that I can find with this guitar is how the neck is fastened to the body.  If you're used to hammering away on your guitar, you'll never get a single note in tune - there seemes to be a tiny amount of play in the neck that affects intonation.  If you have a lighter touch, no problems.  So, you're not going to want to be jumping around on stage with this thing wrapped around you...aside from the fact that doing so may actually maim or kill one of your bandmates because of its bulk.

All in all it is a good beginner to intermediate guitar.  I have no regrets.

This is a nice device with good features. Previously I had owned a USB Guitarlink, which is comparable in price, but didn't work nearly as well and didn't have any of these features. The GuitarLink would consistently need to re-plugged to work. However, I've encountered none of those issues with this device.

In my case, I used the ASIO drivers, which can be downloaded from Behringer for free. The installation is pretty straight-forward. The sound quailty is good and I haven't encountered any lagging or popping. When playing my guitar through the device the sound is clear and responsive. Overall, I don't notice any difference between my friend's similar Presonus unit and this one. Now, the plastic exterior is not as well made as the Presonus or Focusrite models, but for under $30, this was the perfect option for home usage. Unlike the Presonus and Focusrite, no recording software is included. I use Reaper which interfaces with this device perfectly.
summary: this is a better product for the price

A couple of years ago, I decided to learn the ukulele.  Our teenage daughters soon joined me and before I knew it, there were 8 or 10 ukes around the house.  We have ukes from inexpensive models all the way up to the $400 price point....and I've found that no two ukes sound the same.

When I think of ukulele sound, there are three categories to my ear: guitar-ish, ukulele-ish, and toy-ish.  This inexpensive ukulele from Hola! is really surprising!  It is definitely in the ukulele-ish sound category to my ears.

This Hola! uke is very well constructed, and sounds as good as ukes we own which cost 2.5 times more.  It plays fairly easy, and stays in tune as good as any others we have (after the stings have stretched and settled in a bit).  I'm very impressed with the rosewood fretboard and rosewood bridge - really hard to believe these features can be had at this low, low price point.

This uke could be improved somewhat by taking it to a Luthier for a set up.  They would lower the strings - adjust the intonnation slightly - and maybe make a few other adjustments.  It would play a little easier and sound even better - but in our area this is a $75 service....a good bit more than the price of the instrument.

I ordered this Hola! uke as a gift for my niece - she is going to love it!  Considering the quality sound, quality construction, quality materials and super low selling price - this is a SOLID 5 star item!  I think I'm safe in saying there is nothing to compare to this ukulele at this price point - and probably not even 1.5 times or 2 times this price point.

I was very fortunate to receive a slight discount on this ukulele in exchange for my honest opinion and unbiased review - that is exactly what I have provided.  If you have any questions about this instrument or my review, please post a comment below - I will respond promptly.
summary: Wow - Outstanding Uke for the Low Price!

reviewText:
The Shure 55SHII is the direct decendant of the original Shure 55 that Elvis made famous. That first 55 was actually much bigger than the following models and was affectionately called the "bird cage". I have a couple of those large 55s in my mic collection.

Today's 55SHII takes the second, scaled down model, adds an on/off switch and has updated the mic capsule to a quieter, more modern sounding cardiod pattern, which helps control feedback while onstage near monitors or front of house speakers.

The recent line that I've seen don't have the fit and finish that the originals have, but they still have that same classic look. And they sound even better today.

So if it's the classic rock 'n roll look you want, there's really no other mic to get. Grab a couple of Shure 55SHII "Elvis" mics while they are still making them. If nothing else, they will look cool sitting on your desk or a shelf of memorabilia!
summary: Good Enough For The King Of Rock 'n Roll

This automatic humidity system works exactly as it is supposed to !
I put a system in each of my two Taylor guitar cases, along with a digital humidity monitor.
Over the next 6 weeks, I checked the case humidity, using the digital monitor. The humidity always stayed between 47 and 52 %.
After several weeks the humidity paks have remained soft and flexible. If they ever get hard, they should be replaced.
I have read where some folks have restored them by exposing them to more humidity but have not tried this (yet).
Replacement paks are available from Amazon for a very reasonable price. They just slip into the bags furnished with the original system.

This Gator guitar hanger is sturdy, attractive, and easy to install.  It comes with wall anchors for drywall, and long screws.  The hangers are rubber coated to prevent finish damage.  The instructions are simple and I had this installed in under 5 minutes.  There are no screws visible once the unit is on the wall.  I was initially worried that the guitar would hang too close to the wall, however it is a good 3.5" away.  It did take some "oomph" to get the actual hanger prongs parallel to the floor, but it certainly feels solidly locked in.  I was fortunate enough to have a location where a stud was available (and I would highly recommend using a stud for the install), however 2 heavy duty screw-in wall anchors also come with the unit for drywall mounting.  I much prefer this clean look to having the guitar on a floor stand in the corner where it tends to gather dust and dog hair. Ugh.
summary: Turn you guitar into wall art!

reviewText: I bought these bridge pins primarily for the look and possibility a minor improvement in tone and volume. Although I love the look of the abalone and brass, they do not fit well and I need to shave a little wood from a piece of lumber to serve as a spacer to tighten the pins when I change the strings.
this was a poor quality instrument but for the money it was okay.
Fantastic Amp, great service.

I have a cedar topped acoustic and these strings brought it to life without losing the cedar smoothness. No mud, clear mids and highs with clashing. Mounted them with the brass tone pins and this guitar just rings like a bell now. Love it.

I bought this bridge to upgrade the one on my Squier Precision bass. It fits perfectly (I believe it'll fit any Fender bass), and even though it has two extra holes in the front of the plate, which will require drilling, it will work just fine even if you don't drill these out. These screws just add a bit more contact between body and bridge, and will probably sound (and feel) a tiny bit better, but if you don't want to drill, you can still use this bridge

The build quality is fantastic. It really feels solid, it's shiny, and it's a huge upgrade over the Squier bridge. I can't believe it cost only $25 or less

As for the sound, I was obviously not able to A/B test the old bridge vs. this one, but I can be quite sure that there's an improvement in sustain and tone. And even if not, the entire thing just looks and feels better. I highly recommend this piece of hardware
summary: Amazing upgrade for any Fender bass guitar

Highly recommended!

I had this pickup professionally installed in my Eastman dreadnaught, by a shop that has a lot of experience with K&K.

Overall, it's a well-designed pickup. I especially appreciate the fact that it doesn't require a battery inside my guitar, and that its output is high enough to use without a preamp. As long as I don't need a lot of amplification, this pickup pretty much sounds like my guitar, only louder.

Problem is, that's true only as long as I'm not amplifying it very much. At least in my guitar, this pickup is very prone to feedback even at moderate stage volume.

I use it mostly in church. Our band is not particularly loud, but I do have to be heard (and hear myself) over an enclosed drum kit. To control the feedback, I either have to (a) use a rubber soundhole cover, or (b) EQ the lows and low-mids down by quite a lot.

Both options are bad. It's either kill the sustain with the soundhole cover, or kill the tone with the EQ.

In headphones or at low volume, if I A/B the K&K vs. the stock Fishman piezo in my other acoustic the K&K wins by a mile. However, in most cases the Fishman will actually sound better through a PA because I don't have to clobber the lows to control feedback.

TIP: If you use the K&K without their pre-amp, make sure you plug it into something with a 1 Meg ohm input impedance. A high impedance input, such as the 10 Meg ohm ones on some amps, will over-emphasize the bass frequencies.

UPDATE 2/3/2012
---------------
I had a Fishman Matrix Infinity installed in the guitar. The Matrix pre-amp has a secondary input that passes an unmodified signal to the ring of a 1/4" TRS (stereo) plug. Best of both worlds: I can plug in a regular 1/4" guitar cable and use the Fishman when feedback is likely, or access the K&K signal with a stereo cable in situations where feedback is not a problem.
summary: Pretty good, but feedback is a problem at stage volume

I have relied on the Snark tuners for years because they are reliable and inexpensive enough where I can keep one in each instrument's case. However, the notion of polytuning sparked my curiosity, and I found this device helpful. It has a couple of problems. Sometimes, when I strum all the strings, not all of them appear on the display. It also often happens that after individually tuning each string, I notice that strumming suggests that a couple of strings may be instantly out of tune again. For the most part, however, I have found tuning much easier and quicker with this device than with the Snark tuners. Also, although it is meant for six-string guitars, I found it an accurate tuner for my twelve-string guitar and mandolin, although the polytune function, of course, does not work for those.
summary: Not perfect but very, very good

reviewText:
This is a modeling amp.  IT has several presets, to emulate different sounds.  They factory settings for these are pretty good, and all but the first bank (of three) can be adjusted and saved as new presets on the amp.  If you get the fender fuse software (license comes with the amp) you can get some pretty amazing "pre" sets from fender and other users.

This is not a massive cabinet, so you aren't going to get that "big" a sound, regardless. But for a small room it's great!

Common complaint I have seen:  No clean channel/preset.
This is not the case.  There are a couple of factory presets that are "clean" although some people want cleaner.  You can either adjust the gain/vol yourself or download one of several VERY nice very clean presets from the fender forums.  That said, one of my guitars is edgy, it wants to overdrive the amp.  Another doesn't, and is very clean, even on the factory preset clean.

I very nearly got a different amp.  I went to a music store and a salesman showed me a Mustang II.  I was sold when he showed me what all it could do - then showed me the price for a Mustang I!!  For ~$100 USD this is about as much as you could possibly ask for.

It'll keep me busy for a long time.
summary: A lotta amp for the money.

I own a number of low priced harps (under $10) including the Hohner Bluesband (which is quite a reasonable and sturdy beginner's model).  Yet for another $10 this Suzuki is so far superior it's hard to even describe.  The quality of the feel, the resonance of the tone, the ease of the reeds - amazing and beautiful.  Although it's not a learner's "C", this "G" harp has a wonderful lower tone that just grabs you.  My other harmonicas now sound like toys.  This is a musical instrument.  Buy it!  I'm serious.
summary: At $16 you must buy this now!

This has quickly become my favorite bass pedal in my collection. It pairs well with just about every other effect I have and adds a whole new dimension to the sound. If you play bass with distortion, you will find this especially handy. The EQ segment of this pedal thickens up your sound adding definition to a distorted signal so it's more musical and less "fizzy bass." This paired with a Proco Rat and a treble boost makes for a great Justin Chancellor-esque tone. While its effect is, in my opinion, much less pronounced with a clean signal it still adds depth to the sound. This pedal will also provide a creamy powertube style distortion if you crank the drive a bit. My personal preference is to keep the drive dial at about 11 o'clock and use another distortion pedal for a heavy sound while the Sansamp on its own just warms up the clean tone a bit. I haven't played without this pedal on since it arrived.

On top of all of this, the DI out makes recording super easy. If your interface provides phantom power, you can use it to power the pedal as well. I haven't bothered fussing with micing my cabinet since I got this. Definitely recommended if either you do your own recordings or want a distorted bass sound that doesn't sound awful.

Great bang for the buck. I added these to my arsenal of ADJ Mega Tripars, and was able to match the two through freestyler by reducing intensity on the GBGS to 35%, so these are considerably brighter. I created a profile for this fixture on the freestyler forum. These are similar or better than my other lights with double the price: 2 fairly quiet fans, and 7 bright 10w RGBW LED's. Removable power cord and power port output, handy for daisy chaining. The fixtures are plastic, with somewhat thin metal handles. This could be considered a breakproofing feature when stepped on...the handle will bend before the fixture breaks. My only complaint is the auto and sound active mode lacks the ability to apply the dimmer channel. So in sound active, fixture is 100% intensity. I mod my fixtures with a widmx PCC, so I was able to peek at the guts: nice heatsink behind the LED board, 24v power to the LEDs, and a nice clean build with insulation and cord bundling with zip ties where they should be. No "chinese fire hazard surprises" that you may find with other products. Labeled for compliance.

There's not much room on the inside and there is a lot of stuff packed in there with the 24v power supply making these slightly larger than my ADJs. A 5 case of my other fixture only fits three of these, so make note on measurement before finding a case.

These should be great for live bands seeking an inexpensive bright par for a truss.
Excellent quality

I have had this stand for over 2 years and still like it's compact transport capability.  Since I purchased mine, several other musicians have purchased the same stand.  It is well built, and can handle heavy music binders without tipping.  I've used it  at both inside and outside gigs without any problems.
I wouldn't say it's the "best" brand, but the groove tubes generally give me the tone I'm after.

This is a great echo pedal. It simulates a tape echo unit, and has some really nice parameters to get that analogue tape sound. You can adjust how 'new' the tape sounds, and the amount of 'wrinkle' in the tape. Of course there are the usual 'Repeats' & 'Time' functions, but in addition you can specify 'fixed', 'multiple' or 'single' tape heads. The unit also has onboard reverb, and there are secondary parameters behind four of the knobs, which you can access by holding down the Tap and Bypass footswitches simultaneously. All parameters can be controlled via an expression pedal, and you can choose between mono and stereo output.
Love how it shows chords and tunes as well. lots of good features for the musician

First off the Serato Intro Software never did work with my product; I will ask about that in the question box later. However the DJ DDJ- SB2 did work with my "Virtual DJ Pro 8" Licence and subscription. This controller is a power house of sound quality and performance which includes Hit the top 4 rubber pads to trigger Hot Cue, Auto Loop, Manual Loop and Sampler  and the bottom 4 for immediate access to Play, Cue, Sync and Shift. Use the trim knob and level meters to quickly check and adjust the input volume on each channel; It also has  the trim knob and level meters to quickly check and adjust the input volume on each channel. The other thing is you can hit Filter Fade to add 2 high pass filters to the crossfader, so you can manipulate both the volume and bass filters with one hand for effortless mixes. That leaves the other hand free to get creative with loops, cue, samples and FX. I'm very pleased with this controller and for the money you can't beat it but here on Amazon buying it was more convenience than anything because it's the same price most places I checked. This is for newbies or professional DJ's.
summary: Pioneer DJ DDJ-SB2 Controller will blow you away!.. Seriously:)

This pedal was the mainstay of my effects for a few years.  It really does have a ton of range, although it only does one effect at a time, so you'd have to reach down and change the knobs mid-show in order to get the other variations.  My most commonly used setting was with the overdrive-distortion mix knob at about 2 o'clock, which produces a very professional sounding Grunge-type effect.  If you want any of those 90's sounds, excluding the heavier metal sounds, this pedal will definitely get you there.

Besides durability, the guitar projects nicely, is easy to play up and down the fretboard and has good intonation. It's a quality instrument, and for the price can't be beat.

Bought this to replace my ancient ADA MP1 that died on me. This preamp rocks! First of all it's so easy to program - that's a big plus. I think all the presets are OK and a good starting off point. Secondly it sounds real good. It cleans up nicely when rolling off the volume and responds to picking dynamics. I have a POD HD500 as well and I find myself playing the Digitech more often. It's certainly easier to navigate and program.

On the other hand...It's just not a tube preamp, it sounds digital to me, not that that is a bad thing. I'm running stereo into a 50/50 Carvin tube power amp and a 2x12 Bag End cab with ancient Greenbacks. It's a preamp so it's going to sound different for every amp/cab it's running into. Another thing I really like is it has global EQ paramaters that are easy to work with and you can turn the cab modelling off globally as well. I'm not sure about deep editing but I think the HD500 has it beat in that area.

I don't really care for USB/PC/editor thing. Line 6's monkey kills them on this. I messed around for hours trying to get the drivers to work and the USB connection to be recognized. Luckily it's easy to program it manually on the front panel. There's a Beta site out there but it's bare bones and really confusing.

Bottom line: I like it, the price is right, and I would recommend it.

The quality of the wood and the cut itself were surprisingly good. After completely shaping it and sanding it to fit my cello it turned out to be a nice bridge (even though i just have it as a back-up). Excellent price here too.

reviewText: I use these picks primarily for strumming, but they have a great grip, and work great. I doubt they'll ever wear out, and though I use .60-.80 for whatever I'm doing on my acoustics, these are among my favorite picks, and I use these the Clayton's, and a few others, but for .60 picks these are really nice, and I tend to pick them out of the box when I start to warm up with a pick.

This is the best sounding passive DI I own. I tested it side-by-side with several other DIs, both active and passive.  The sound of this box trounced them all with clean, clear, pure tone.  I use JDIs live and in the studio.  On stage, I have an effects unit for my sax that only has stereo 1/4" outputs.  I plug them into the "left" and "right" inputs on the JDI and use the "merge" button to combine the stereo inputs into a mono XLR out.  It works great and kills two birds with one stone.  In the studio, I use it on things like acoustic-electric guitars, and active-pickup basses.  It's a solid workhorse that won't let you down.

I first considered the Cordoba concert ukulele because it was on every list of the best beginner ukes, and I am so happy with my choice! It took about a week to stretch the strings and stay in tune, but the Cordoba sounds amazing. My daughter has a cheaper soprano uke and the Cordoba has a noticeably clearer sound and is much lighter weight. It just feels great in my hands. I tried some no-drill straps, but ultimately chose to add a strap button with no problem. I saw some reviews about quality control issues on the finish, and I did find a rough spot on the back (see photo). This was not an issue for me, but I'd suggest checking for this. Otherwise, I love everything about my Cordoba ukulele and highly recommend it for beginners. From my experience so far, it's worth spending a little more to get a quality instrument.
summary: I am in love with this uke!

reviewText:
It you are not mechanically inclined or handy with any sort of hand tools - do not try to do this yourself.
Along with purchasing the pegs, you need to enlarge the peg holes slightly with a 30:1 reamer (how much depends on the individual violin). It would be very easy to enlarge the holes too much requiring a trip to a luthier to bush the holes. If attempted on a cheap instrument be ready to replace it as the luthier expense would exceed the instruments value.
Good theory, but I thought they'd be wider. I play at a high angle and these still have a tendency to turn a bit and let the strap slip off if the hole is loose.

reviewText:
These strings are okay, but nothing special except for the price, which is a factor when changing twice a week. I don't play enough to need changes that often anymore.

So I've become more particular about trying to match the string to the guitar. This doesn't mean that these strings are bad, it just means I might prefer Brand X Pure Nickel on one guitar because they're darker and Brand Y Steels on another because they're brighter and Brand Z on yet another.

So give these a try and if you prefer them it will be best to check on price by the case of this or any string that you prefer because they should be changed twice a month at least, if you want your instrument in top shape. A bad guitar can make a great artist sound only good.

reviewText: My Les Paul is heavy.. The strap would constantly fall off. So I decided to get a set of strap locks. These installed in minutes, and really don't change the look of the guitar at all. You will need a nut driver to screw the lock to your strap. If you don't have locks on all your guitars, you cant interchange your straps easily any more, so I recommend getting them for all your guitars. The other added benefit I found is that on my hollow body the strap was actually scratching the back. With these locks the strap sits away from the guitar, so it fixes that problem as well. When I buy a new guitar, I get new locks. Are there better locks out there? I'm not sure, but Im committed now as I wanted the same locks on all my guitars.. Has never failed me yet.

I have been looking for that right pedal that boosts my guitars sound without significantly altering it.  I play mostly blues with a strat.  I wanted to maintain the sound of the strat while getting a little more punch.  I have a Blackstart HT20 amp and a Fender Clapton Vibrochamp.  I like the clean sounds of both these amps but sometimes you want just a little boost without altering the tone.  I have a Ibanez TS7 but the mids are very noticeable. I have a number of other boost/crunch pedals as well but none accomplish what I want to sometimes achieve.  The pedal market is overflowing nowadays.  Its sort of ridiculous.  Boutique this, boutique that.  A lot that drives price is supply and demand and not the actual sound/tone.  I saw this pedal on youtube when I was looking at the Klon KTR, which is a few hundred dollars.  I really couldn't tell a difference between the two on the youtube video.  So, for $50 I figured it was worth trying.  I wouldn't stay its the most sturdy of pedals but I am not out gigging every night so it serves my purposes for recording and getting the sounds in my cover band.  You don't have to crank the volume either to get a nice boost.  I found that you start to get a noticeable boost around 10 o'clock.  Even with the volume lower than that, I feel like I get a nice open airiness to my tone.  So I think if you are looking for a good boost, or are trying to get that Clapton/Meyer strat sound while maintaining the tone of the guitar and without buying a $2000 amp, this is a great pedal for the money.  It also sounds great with my Gibson Midtown with P90's.
summary: exactly what I have been looking for

reviewText:
I preface this critique with the fact that I have been playing the harmonica in both private and public venues for over 43 years.  Although I play all genre of music, my preferences are 19th century western tunes and old-time gospel hymns.

  At first, I had my reservations about ordering a $7.00 harmonica made in China; but I must admit I was quite impressed with my investment.  It came in a cardboard box, in lieu of a case, but I didn't purchase it for the carrying case.  In order to give the Hohner Bluesband, in the key of G, a fair assessment, I wanted to play it continually for several weeks and then have something to compare it with in appearance and sound.  From the many that I own, I chose my Hohner Special 20 made in Germany.  It retails for about 7 times as much as I paid for the Hohner Bluesband made in China.

  "The first impression is a lasting impression," as the saying goes; and I was quite impressed with that first impression of the Bluesband harmonica right out of the starting gate, so to speak.  The BluesBand looked and felt remarkably like my Hohner Special 20. They both have a black plastic comb, (yes, even pricier harmonicas come with plastic combs) and they both have stainless steel covers and brass reed plates.  They both are identical in dimensions, weight and touch.  With my eyes closed, I couldn't tell one instrument from the other.  Afterwards, I thought to myself, "it looks and feels great-- but how does it sound?"  "Is it all show and no go?" as the saying goes.  Needless to say, it sounded wonderful.  I was so impressed with the quality of its intonation I could hardly put it down.  It sounded that good -- and all for the bargain basement price of under $7.00!  I was able to use the same vibrato and muting techniques as I do on a harmonica costing seven times as much.  I was so impressed with the appearance and sound I ordered the same make and model in the key of C.

  The only negative thing I have to say about the one I purchased, in the key of G, is that both reeds in the second hole do not work.  I chalk this up to a manufacture's defect or a mistake at the assembly plant.  If any of the reeds in holes four through seven had been defective, I would've had to return it.  Holes four through seven are imperative in order to play melodies on the harmonica.  One can still play a plethora of tunes without holes one, two and ten; but four, five, six and seven -- the diatonic scale -- are crucial.  By the way, all the reeds in the Hohner Bluesband harmonica that I ordered in the key of C work with no problem.  Ostensibly, quality control was on the job.

  Out of five stars, I give the one in the key of G four and a half stars for sound and price --but only because the reeds in the 2nd hole are defective.  On the other hand, I give the one in the key of C five out of five stars for both intonation and price.

  In summation, if you're just now learning to play the harmonica, or you are already an accomplished harmonica player like me, looking for something to supplement your play on a whim -- the Hohner Bluesband is for you, offering both an incredible sound at a remarkable price.

  On the box it reads: "This is a musical instrument, not a toy."  I wholeheartedly concur with that assessment.  If you want a toy -- buy a kazoo.  Here ends my review.  I hope you enjoy playing the harmonica as much as I do.  : )
summary: Hohner 1501BX-G Bluesband Harmonica, Key of G

Con, and it's a big one:
The 5/8" threads that attach to most booms or stands are _plastic_. I doubt they'd survive more than a few adjustments or removals. After only one insertion and removal of the supplied metal insert, the plastic threads are badly worn. After fiddling around with several different 49-key controllers at a nearby music store, it was obvious that this Akai was in a different league (referring specifically to build quality). If you don't like/want synth keys that could be a problem. I didn't have a preference going into it, but after feeling the quality of these keys and the consistency of the velocity in my DAW, I decided quality was more important than type (semi-weighted vs. synth).

Along the same vein are the rotary encoders (dials) and the sliders -- both have an excellent feel to them and are a clear cut above every other brand I tested within a $100 price difference (up and down).

This controller also offered a far deeper level of customizability than others I tested out. Most notably was the ability to change the colors of each drum pad (something like 10 color options) on each separate bank. Perhaps this isn't a necessity, but to me it not only demonstrated the level of detail that went into building this but also helped me quickly identify different triggers/patches/etc. by building my own color scheme.

This easily weighs over 12lbs. as it is built of metal and seems like it could take some abuse (not that I tested it).

The downloadable software was nothing hyper-impressive but it felt on-par with the type of instruments/plugins that come standard in any DAW.

The ONLY reason I returned it was it's lack of deep integration with Logic Pro X. I don't understand why big-named companies don't offer more online support/etc. for services that make a significant difference to the potential customer. The Akai website wasn't bad, it had helpful enough setup instructions to get this synced with Logic Pro X. However, there's no details as to what that means, how deep the integration goes, or which sliders/encoders are mapped to which settings. Seems like a PDF an intern could build in about a day. It felt as though they were merely "checking the box" as opposed to spending a little extra time to build a solid, deep mapping system for both novice and expert. Moreover, the level of integration didn't go past the 1st Bank. The encoders were assigned to PAN and the sliders were assigned to track volume and the transport controls of the Akai were synced with Logic. That's where it ended. Unfortunately (and this could be just me) the Bank 1, 2, and 3 options aren't mappable and there aren't any other dedicated buttons (or even extra buttons lying around) to map to bring up MIXER, INSTRUMENT, PLUG-IN, or FX as you see on some of the other midi controllers.

Obviously you can still map Bank 2 and 3 manually, but switching from and between plugins/tracks/instruments ultimately meant reaching for your mouse.

In the end, I decided to go with a "cheaper" (i.e. more plastic-feeling) controller but one that would allow deeper integration.
summary: Extremely well built, but not as well designed (i.e. only surface-level integration with your DAW)

These LED color burst lights are fine for one performer in a corner. Mabe two people can be lit with these if the lights are monted at least 15 feet behind the performer, and at least 8 feet high above the stage.

However, in the confines of my tiny corner I use for some of my videos on youtube, two of these work fairly well. Frankly, I wish I'd saved up for the 8 bay light, but at the time, I needed these, and they were affordable.

They do respond to sound, but I wish they changed color to the beat, and not just swap chase patterns. Guess I'll have to keep looking that when I can afford it. These will do for the time being, and are certainly better than nothing. I guress.

By the way, these are highly directional lights. However, you can widen the beam by putting a diffuser (frosted tape) over the LED panel. Of course, the trade off is that it'll be a bit dimmer, but you'll be able to light a little more stage area.

The one thing people don't realize about these lights is that they're not meant to light a wide area of stage. They're an effects light. They're just intended to put a wash of light on the performer's back, and send down glowing tight beams of light through a fog. They're also meant to be directly seen by the audience as the lights do produce a noticable flashing pattern that changes.

UPDATE: I've launched a youtube video which shows the Colorburst in my studio. I used it as downlighting on a couple of paintings. Just search The Invisible Thereminist At Thomas Grillo Studios and you'll see it.

Hey, for the low price, that's not too bad at all.

I do recommend not getting less than two of these, unless you're replacing a unit, that is.

For a band of more than two or three performers, I'd get at least four of these, or the 8 bay units so each performer has one or two behind them.
summary: Good for one or two performers

These connectors are real space savers on your pedal board.  And more importantly they provide a super solid connection between pedals as they have no chord to fray or crack. reviewText:
Every violinist should have this! Why did it take so many years for someone to make these? It is accurate and easy to read whether on a bright, sunny outdoor gig, or a dark stage.

My favorite feature is that I never have to take it off. It does not interfere with my violin case. The clamp is definitely large enough to fit a viola but nowhere near large enough for cello.

The only issue I've had is that I accidentally knocked it off once. It fell to the floor and I couldn't get it to power on. Then I noticed the battery door was ajar. Once I snapped the battery compartment shut it powered up and has had no other issues since. The grip could be a little more firm, it just barely grabs the edge of the body.

One of my violinists likes to tune to at least 444 or 446. Since our strings play with keys, bass, guitars, and horns that doesn't make much sense for us. But I haven't tried using this tuner to center at anything other than a 440 A so I am curious as to whether or not this tuner has that capability.
summary: The Tuner Every Violinist Must Own!

He has a Yamaha P155 digital piano, and the Stylophone blends quite well with its own unique little organ voice.  Some of the sounds that the Stylophone makes are reminiscent of the the Nintendo and Atari games I played growing up(not bad kind of nostalgic actually).  It's pretty easy to play.  I'm more of a guitar player, but I've found it easy to pick out songs by ear.  It's great for 80's synth pop & new wave covers. This gadget will in no way replace a real keyboard, but it's a fun addition to any musicians collection of STUFF. I like that you can hook it up to your MP3 player or run it through an amp with effects for more tonal weirdness.  I've actually just ordered the Stylophone beatbox from the UK because the clips of it on Youtube seem equally awesome, and I can't seem to find a seller here in the US. reviewText: OK, this unit failed right out of the box:  It worked for about ten minutes and then the blue light started flashing.  No sound could get through it.  I changed out the battery with a brand new one and---nothing.  Zzounds sent me a new one in a few days.  The return process was painless.  The new unit works well, so far, although you have to remember to disconnect both in and out cords after each session or the battery will drain.  That is a terrible engineering flaw.  Even with the pedal off, you still get a dead battery if you leave your cords plugged in.  Have a four-hour gig?  Better remember to bring a new pack of nine-volt batteries, or get a 9V/100mA adapter with sleeve-hot configuration.  As far as changing out the battery is concerned:  This is the worst effects pedal I've ever owned.  Using a ballpoint pen, you need to push in the spring-loaded rod, on both sides, through two holes drilled in the plastic pedal.  It is truly hit or miss.  Once you get the pedal top off, be very careful.  The pedal spring is loose.  It can pop right out and be gone, leaving you to grope around, onstage, to find it, and you probably won't. All in all, I would not order another pedal made by Behringer.  This unit is made in China, and I suppose its other effects pedals are, as well.  While some Chinese stuff is OK, I suspect the factory churning out these units is strictly bottom-of-the-barrel.  The only reason I gave this unit two stars is that it sounds pretty darned good, once it's operating.  Its design flaws are too numerous to give it any other stars, though.  UPDATE: 5/6/12: The replacement unit went through a brand new Duracell battery in one hour!  We were rehearsing, thankfully, so I put in another new battery and things were OK.  I have a converter on the way, and I'll update, in here, once I try it out.  In all honesty, I have a feeling both units may go back.  In the end, you do get what you pay for, most of the time.  UPDATE: 7/18/12:  I have now had my second unit on its converter for over two months.  It works great and sounds great.  I can now recommend this unit, but only with the converter, as it eats batteries.  UPDATE: 1/23/16:  Unit is still OK.  You do need to put a strip of heavy black tape over the blue light or it'll blind you when you attempt to adjust the controls, onstage. Make sure you can see a bit of the blue to confirm the unit is on/off.

Here are the key highlights of this cable:

*22Gauge wire
*Neutrik Connectors
*Gold tip

There are other "highlighted" features that Planet Waves likes to point out, stuff like the "Geo-tip" and the "In-Out" technology but in all honesty, that stuff doesn't matter to me.

What matters?  I have had a single 20ft cable for close to 20 years and it has performed flawlessly over that time.  It has never kinked, twisted, or failed in any way around it's Neutrik connectors.  It is an awesome cable and I love it.  And it wasn't cheap.

This Planet Waves cable seems to have similar cabling, similar internally constructed Neutrik connectors and a gold tip to boot.  I imagine this cable will perform just as flawlessly for many many years and when I think of how affordable it is, I am amazed.  So, all I can say is that this cable is HIGHLY recommended.

reviewText:
I needed a simple delay pedal to supplement my keyboard rig and this surpassed my expectations. Excellent deal if you just need a simple echo pedal without any fancy modulation or signal routing features.

Pros:
Little to no noise or hiss when activated
nice heavy enclosure
LED doesn't blind you like some other pedals
came in a nice little black box

Cons:
NOT ACTUALLY AN ANALOG DELAY like they advertise. This uses the same PT2399 digital delay chip that many other inexpensive delays use. Real analog delays use BBD chips. This knocks it down to 4 stars.
Repeats are heavily low-passed (lacking in high end). On one hand that *does* help reduce noise but I would have liked a little bit more treble at the expense of a slightly higher noise floor.
Delay time could have been a little longer. The PT2399 chip can't handle really long delay times without sounding nasty, but I feel like with the amount of low-pass filtering on the repeats they could have extended the maximum delay to at least 800ms or so without much loss in fidelity.
summary: "Yellow Fall" delay - excellent for the price

I've installed these pickups in four different guitars: three dreadnoughts and a Larrivee L body. I did find that the adhesive strips supplied for the microphone part seem to lose their grip after a while. I made replacements from more permanent 3M tape and it seems better.

Tone is good, but not great. It sounds better than a UST pickup, but still far from natural. Tone is compressed and midrange-ey, lacking bass. The position of the microphone has a huge impact on the sound and at the suggestion of the folks at Baggs I wound up installing the microphone part in alternate locations to what is shown in the instructions to get the best sound. I have these in two guitars I play out with, but I seldom use them. I have a K&K Meridian microphone setup that works much better where feedback isn't a big issue.

Bottom line . . . I really WANT to like this microphone/pickup and the folks at LR Baggs have been very helpful, but it seems to fall short of the hype. Other people report better results than I have. Maybe it depends on the guitar.

The Behringer is a good value  it works fine and has good features / performance for the price  but like other Behringer products I've used, the sound quality / noise / distortion, leave me wanting a better product. If features or budget are at the top of your list, this product should do the job; if however sound quality is of primary importance then I'd recommend the Scarlet 2i2 (look for sales or a used Gen 1).
