reviewText:
The classic strobe light (in my opinion) is the old Radio Shack model.  With that strobe, you could create very cool effects for Halloween displays.

The problem with this LED strobe is two-fold: (1) the LED bulbs light up and fade slower than a true strobe bulb so you don't get the classic strobe feel and (2) the strobes are actually done two at a time rather than one so the strobe is disjointed.  I don't know how to explain all of this other than to say there are two quick flashes of light with subtle hints of the the light coming on and shutting off, and then a delay followed by two quick flashes of light with subtle hints of the the light coming on and shutting off followed by a delay, and so on.  It just doesn't look or feel like a true strobe.

I gave the unit two stars because it does appear well-constructed and it's cheap.
summary: Not the classic strobe I was looking for

There is so much that I absolutely love about this gig-bag. 1) It is well padded, 2) The cloth is high quality material. 3) The compartments can easily hold everything I need for a gig. 4) The American flag graphic looks awesome! 5) The backpack straps are easily adjusted, and fit my shoulders well. 6) The side handle is well made, and doesn't cut into my hand, and 7) This is the best gig-bag for the price, that I have ever had! There are really only two things I don't love about it, and therefore I could only give this product 4 stars instead of 5. The first problem is that the zipper doesn't go far enough around the main compartment. This makes loading the gig bag harder than it should. The second problem is there is no handle on the back of the bag. This puts a lot of stress on the backpack straps, and makes putting on the gig-bag tricky. Without the loop handle, you have to be careful not to pull up too hard on the straps. In short, I love this gig-bag, but it does have some flaws in the design that seem totally unnecessary. Fix the design and this will be THE perfect gig bag!

reviewText:
We use these at our church to light up stands for performing music or doing readings during worship.

I appreciate the adjustable antennae so that the lights can be directed to specific areas. The light is bright enough to be able to read even if the room is otherwise in darkness. I do wish they had one more LED in the heads, though - with two standard 8-1/2 x 11 pages on the music stand, the outer edges cannot be lit directly (though there is enough bleed over light to see it, it's not as bright as it could be). Just another 20% output would make these 5 stars perfect.

Construction-wise, they're slightly fragile - clearly not made for industrial or heavy duty use - but for standard usage, they will hold up just fine and should last for years.

We love them - we have 7 or 8 at the church that we use. They're especially wonderful because they're battery operated. With all the cords we already have from microphones, it's wonderful not to have an equal number of extra power cords running a bunch of electric lights. There's an extra environmental cost with using the batteries versus plugging them in, but the handiness, adaptability, and lack of extra cords make it worth it.

Definitely recommend these to anyone, and also recommend the manufacturer add another 20% or so lumens.
summary: They work excellently, and provide a good (though not quite enough) amount of light

As the other reviewer said ( I wish I had listened) you have to wind the string with you finger on the top to keep it from slipping out. Even then it still pops out/off and is a pain. The post rings are short, not deep enough and not a good fit. The tuners are loose fitting and wobbly. The machine heads have a lot of slack to them and the don't hold tuning very well. There also seems to be a little more space than there should be between each key. I'll keep them on till I can order a better set and then throw these things in the trash. Save your money or spend an extra $10 and get something (anything) better.IKN Guitar Tuning Pegs 6-in-line Nickel Vintage Style Strat Style Machine Head

reviewText: I do shall sound for EDM shows. Not all promoters like to get on the microphone. Sometimes I don't even turn the microphone on but it's nice to have it available for them if they want to use it. These microphones actually sound really good and they don't give you too much feedback unless you're standing right in front of a speaker. When I first bought it I went out into the crowd and used it and it was fine with no interference and sounded great even about a hundred feet away. The only time I've experienced feedback is when you're directly in front of a DJ Monitor and some DJs turn them up to maximum volume that will create feedback. I think these are an amazing value and I see no reason to get ashore microphone or anything that cost a lot of money if you're just trying to announce a few things here and there.

This is our second Honeytone (we misplaced the other).  We bought this for my son who is currently learning to play the guitar. The sound is clear and loud, quality is good. He seems to enjoy the speaker.

This is the only transducer I have, so I don't know if this is normal to be this weak.  It's not very loud at all.  It works with one of my amps (with lots of feedback), but it doesn't work with another amp (vol and gain at max).  Oh, and it picks up everything.  I could record while talking into the guitar and it will record my voice, along with any guitar handling noise or clothes shuffling.  All these things might be normal for a transducer, but if it's just accepted as being the norm and not fixed I cannot give it a high rating.

I later found out why it doesn't work with my other amp.  My other amp is a KEYBOARD amp.  It must have something to do with the type of impedance or voltage coming into the input.  Make sure to use a GUITAR amp with this product.
summary: Not very loud, but still picks up everything.

reviewText: Great, great cord!

I returned mine. This is why:

For $200 you get a basic bass (not bad, but a $110 bass). You also get a bunch of accessories that are really bad: bad cable, junk tuner, useless amplifier, some picks, very light gigbag. I don't think they are $90 worth.

You may feel that for $200 that's a good deal.. but wait, you end-up paying $200 for a basic bass, and accessories that you will have to change immediately ... because really they are no good.

The amplifier has a 6.5 inches speaker (the product description says 8 inches!). And it's not even loud enough for a bedroom! if you increase the volume more than half, you get distortion noise which is awful. It's a useless amplifier.

The bass itself is ok, finish of the frets was not great, some paint issues. Some people will say "You get what you paid for". Well, I've seen instruments from China of this price range with better finish. I think the problem for this bass is quality control.

About sound, well, I don't know, I had only the amplifier with the set so I really can't tell.

I ended-up returning it, I bought a Yamaha RBX170 Metallic Red for $170 and wow, I feel I spent my money more wisely with a better instrument. I'll spend $99 on a decent amp later, like the Ampeg BA 108 25W 8 inches which rocks!

If you want to stick with the bass in this set, I'd suggest you buy just the instrument without the crappy accessories, and you buy a decent amp like the Ampeg. You'll be much, much more happy spending almost the same amount of money.
Oh.. and for the tuner, buy a Snark SN-1 Tuner, that's $9 and so much better.
Excellent!!!! portable and very good quality

I have Dunlop strap locks on all my guitars. However, I recently acquired a cheap practice guitar with a somewhat loose-fitting strap, I didn't want to invest in strap locks until I got the guitar customize how I want it.  I thus decide on these 'locks' as a cheap alternative to preventing the strap from coming off the strap button. I wasn't expecting too much, but I must say, they are simple effective.  What more could you want?  Nice, cheap, simple alternative.  I like them.

I've had every powered speaker imaginable, from the low end stuff from Behringer and Alto to the Mackie, QSC, JBL, etc.  By FAR this Yamaha DXR series has to be the absolute clearest, most accurate output of anything I've ever played through.  I am a multi keyboardist and keyboard sounds tend to require the widest range possible coming out of a speaker:  clear highs, powerful mids and floor-shaking bass.  Somehow Yamaha is able to do it ALL with these DXR series powered speakers.  Plus they are light enough to gig (mine is the DXR12 and weighs just over 40lbs), easy to set up, can be floor-angled or stood vertically depending on where you need most of your sound.  Seriously for under $1000 I really don't think you can buy a better powered speaker.

I decided to get an SKB20 after two different Martin factory cases fell apart on me. I have a Martin Jumbo Cutaway (JC16GTE) that has some out-of-the-ordinary body dimensions. Thus I was concerned about a proper fit from a general case manufacturer. It does have an inch or so of wiggle room around the sides and is a tight fit depth-wise in this case but the guitar is secure which is all I care about. I imagine it provides a more perfect fit for ordinary jumbo body styles.

I have not taken the case on a plane yet but I would feel confident about it. Build quality and design is top-notch. I have done at least 100 gigs with it so far and see no signs of weakness in any of it's parts. The plastic shell is tough. The latches are well designed, heavy-duty, and properly secured to the case. The interior is soft and properly cushioned in the right spots. The under-neck stowage area is very standard and what you'd expect. The handle is well placed and ergonomically designed- thicker than average with a nice grippy rubber covering.

There is a steel band that runs around the sides and splits at the point where the top and bottom meet in order to provide a sealed closure. I found that you do need to sort of line that up with itself as your closing the case to allow all of the latches to close. Its one of those muscle memory things that can seem annoying at first but after doing it 20 times you don't even think about it anymore.

It also weighs significantly less than the particle board hardshell cases I was used to from Martin. I was pleasantly surprised at how light it was. Between that and the comfy handle, it can be carried for extended periods of time before your shoulder starts complaining.

I expect my traditional electric guitar case to give out one of these days too and I'll happily replace it with an SKB when the time comes.

I did not know exactly what to expect when I received the M-Steel. I have been a customer of Ernie Ball for many years, and the hype around these strings finally convinced me to try them out for myself. I can definitely say that I could hear the difference right away. The strings I took off were still new, so it wasn't just the new string sound. They are brighter, more resonant and a lot smoother to slide up and down the frets. I play a lot of lead guitar and rock and metal rhythm and move my fingers pretty fast up the and down the neck, and these are the best strings for my style of playing.
These are my new standard.

This device is simply amazing. If you don't have access to a professional recording studio and dozens (or hundreds) of effect pedals, but wish you did, you simply must get this thing. This will turn a decent guitar, amp, and laptop into a recording studio with everything you need to get any sound you are looking for. As long as your guitar stays in tune and your amp sounds decent and loud enough for your needs, leave the rest to this pedal. Anything from ultra-clean to ultra-dirty, delays, reverb... everything.

The fact that it also has a looper is gravy (go price single-function loopers). The fact that it ALSO has drum beats is gravy on top of gravy (again, price single-function devices). I know some folks complain that you cant use the drums at the same time with the looper... well... go price out separate devices that JUST do loops and drums. You can get another one of these, run it in-line, and still be $500 ahead and have all the effects AND a backup effects pedal for gigs.

The software that comes with it simplifies the process of setting up custom sounds, and allows you to back up the settings and restore them to the device. If you have two of them, then you can copy the settings from one to the other, or have an extra 50 custom settings (if you really think you need 100 custom presets).

The website also has some custom presets for various genres and specific songs.

This device is, by far, the best value out there when it comes to expanding the sounds you have available to you. It will even make a crappy guitar-amp pair sound good enough to impress your pals. It will make a decent setup sound awesome, and an awesome setup sound like anything you want it to sound like.

If you have a limited budget, this is an absolute must-have accessory.
summary: Turns any decent guitar-amp combo into a high-end setup...

reviewText: Beautiful set of strings. The tone is clear and they have lasted much longer than my previous set of Martin strings.

This is a great small practice amp with active tone controls that can produce inspirational sounds at a low volume. It has usb connectivity but lacks a line out and thats why I give it only 4 stars. If your looking for a spongy slightly over driven, touch sensitive tube amp sound, think of a vintage Deluxe Reverb with volume on 6, the Yamaha will do that with increased gain in the clean setting. The reverb, delay, tremolo and the rest of the effects are good enough and can be mixed. In low light the amp glows red from the inside revealing an MC Escher 3D effect in the grille. A beautiful surprise as part of a fine design. Loud enough for a lead to cut through an acoustic jam it won't be loud enough for a gig or jam with drums. I use a few really old vintage guitars with P90, DeArmond and Franz pick-ups and a ES-335. If you want a fantastic modeling amp to gig with at medium to loud volume, the Boss Katana 50 which I also own does everything the Yamaha does acoustically and more. Its also only $199.00.

These are replacing old Mackie 1501's and boy, do they ever come through! They give your show that refined sound, and the greatest benefit I saw was where formerly my clients would complain about SPL's over 94db, I looked down during the peak of a performance and realized we were hitting 109-110db A weighted, and it sounded just as amazing as at 79db. No screeching, vibration, tone imbalance or any of that. I can now charge top dollar because I sound top dollar! Tried these out as vocal monitors also, they have a handy mixer with inputs for multiple devices where you could run a one man show and mix a guitar, mic, etc. and daisy chain these in STEREO with no seperate mixing board required! I'd use these to mix my own wet/dry mix if I were a performer, because the mixer on the speaker makes it easy. The "deep" setting: all I can say is WOW. I turned off my Mackie 1801 and ran it in deep for the hip hop dance songs, and you couldn't tell with that setting. Windows rattling, floor shaking 110db of bass (signal of -3db line level at the board, 0db on the speaker, i'm sure these will do close to the 131db rating but I like my hearing) Of course, there's never enough bass, so I think we'll keep them in deep setting, of course!

Will V's review SAVED me. The polarity comes physically, internally, electrically-hardwired, INVERSED, with no polarity switch on-board, and no amount of powering off and on and connecting disconnecting will do you any good. This is a contact circuit switch that has to be physically reserved by opening it up and reversing the layout of the contacts. I fixed mine, and it works great now, the three stars is for no switch and no warning that this is hardwired to be an inversed pedal. Check out the tutorial at  /watch?v=LP_UF-Ea-wY, (you have to type in the first part of the address, Amazon censor won't allow the full link but you know what video site I'm talking about) thank you Will V
summary: Works now after easy internal re-config

reviewText:
I have read the other reviews. I have had the Pocket POD for several days now. I bought it as a companion to my new Traveler Speedster guitar (which I will also review). The Traveler Speedster, for those that don't know, is an electric guitar designed for traveling. When traveling, of course, I don't want to carry an amp around, so the Pocket POD seemed like the perfect solution. Along with the guitar and a small pair of headphones I have everything I need to practice when I am in the hotel room, without bothering anyone.

I opened the Pocket POD as soon as I got it home, put the included batteries in, plugged in my new guitar and some headphones and started playing. Plugging the guitar in automatically turns the POD on (there is no power switch). I never looked at the instructions, I just plugged in and used the 4-way button to change to various sounds. I still have not looked at the instructions, although I did download the companion software and play around with making some of my own sounds. The only knobs I have actually used on the device itself is the 4-way to change presets and the volume knob. I don't even know what the others do, since I have just used the software on my PC for other adjustments. I did use the tuner by holding down the button on the bottom right, which seemed to work fine for me, although someone else complained about it not being a great tuner. I have a fairly good ear and it sounds fine after tuning as far as I can tell.

I have been using the Pocket POD non-stop for about 8 hours. The batteries that came with it are still holding up so far. It has a plug for an AC adapter, but it didn't come with one. For the price, that would have been a nice thing to include.

I think the problem with these kinds of gizmos is that folks expect them to produce sounds as good as stuff that literally costs 10 times as much. It doesn't do that. But what it does do is produce a huge selection of fantastic sounds, right out of the box, and the ability to come up with your own. Given how portable it is, I find it impossible to complain. I don't do gigs (I'm not that good) but I would not hesitate to play through this thing using an amp in front of a crowd. If you are so good that the difference between this device and a more expensive one matters that much then you probably already have something better suited for your situation. Still, I'll bet that it would work for even the best musician in a pinch.

The ability to pipe in music or other sounds from another device (PC, iPod, phone, anything you can plug headphones into) is a great feature. You might want to pick up an audio extension cable since it doesn't come with one. That is a cable with both ends looking like the end of a headphone cable. You can also make one out of two old pairs of headphones in a pinch. Using the cable, you can play along with your favorite tunes, or if you have an instructional video or something you can hear it while you try the licks being taught.

Some folks have complained about the sounds that try to mimic bands. They say they have never heard of the bands. The website has all kinds of free downloadable user-made sounds, and you can make your own, so if that is not something you are willing to do then this might not be for you.

If, on the other hand, you are looking for a very portable device that will turn a guitar and a pair of headphones into a mobile sound solution then this may be just what the doctor ordered. There is even an output for playing through an amp, so If you just want to take your custom sound with you to practice in a place that already has equipment this can do that too.

I also saw some complaints about the quality. I have only used the device for about 8 hours so far. When I first opened the box, one of the dials was stiff, but based on another review I figured out that the knob was just pressed in too far and rubbing against the box. I pulled it out just a tiny bit and problem solved. Otherwise, no issues so far. I did download and apply a firmware update that was available on the website pretty soon after I connected it to my computer to create some sounds, so that may have fixed some things. Creating the sounds was pretty straightforward too, by the way.

I suggest you look around and see what other devices can do and, based on your budget and needs, if you land on this thing, get it. It works as advertised, produces great sound, and has some unexpectedly great features. If you are a pro looking for professional quality and sound, I am not sure why you are looking at this, but even so, I believe you will get more than you expect for this price.

If it breaks or disappoints in any way I will come back and update this review, but as of now, I would highly recommend it. If you see the features and just hope it does what it says it can do, you will not be disappointed.

UPDATE: 6/5/2015 ... Still going strong. Love this thing. I have used it for over a year now and it continues to work like new. I did get some rechargeable batteries and I would recommend it. For the portability and flexibility you can't go wrong with this guy.

I have found this to be a very "forgiving" shaker, by that I mean it has enough washyness that allows you to get away with being a little less accurate in time keeping. It's large and has enough material inside to allow for slow shaking, unlike small shakers that aren't able to generate movement at slow paces. This can be played both like a regular shaker, as well at vertically in a manner like playing African-style shakers.

reviewText:
If you are just getting started, this is a great product.  You are a little limited in the number of clips you can produce in live view and the number of instruments and effects you can use in one track. But for beginners this is enough to get creative.  Ableton is very easy to use and there are a ton of blogs and tutorials online.

Like it says, it is an intro to music creation at a great price.  The idea is that you don't have to spend $400+ on a product that you may discard if music production isn't for you. Ableton live intro is loaded with with almost all the features of ableton live 8, you can make some great proffesional sounding tracks.

 As you learn more and advance you will definately notice the limitations of intro and want to upgrade to Ableton Live 8. This is great because with both your purchases you will still spend the same amount of money as jumping straight into live 8, but you would have figured out the ableton is the right software for you and already have learned a ton of cool stuff.  I have spent $500+ on music software in the past that I do not use and never really got to grips with, this time I am happy to spend money upgrading this intro software to live 8.

Ableton is the easiest to use most intuitive daw on the market in my opinion.
Holds me up!

I have used Dunlop Straplocks for 32 years. I bought the original style years ago for my Strat, Les Paul and Partscaster; the last two having the most weight.
These things have lasted through gigging and anything else i can throw at them with no problem. I ordered strap pins only a few months ago to put on a few more recent guitars and one of the push button locks finally went out. It was on the strap I used the most for the heavier guitars so I got some mileage out of that thing. I ordered a whole set of new ones here last month and put the locks on a new strap and the buttons on another guitar.
I suggest these over the other brands - watch what touring bands use. These things lay flat and there are no protruding parts to catch. If you happen to be without a strap with locks on it, these new pins can be used like regular pins but are larger so a strap will be pretty much secure.
The price is good, price them anywhere else and include shipping. I always buy strings, picks or other stuff to get free shipping.

I first purchased the iConnectMIDI2+ about a year ago because this one wasn't available. I was so satisfied with it that I purchased this one a couple of months ago. I have several iOS devices and I want to make use of the audio pass through feature. This unit, the iConnectMIDI4+, has connections for three computers, whereas the iConnectMIDI2+ only has connections for two computers. But iKingdom Corporation made the design decision to NOT increase the number of audio pass through channels to support the additional computer connection on the iConnectMIDI4+. The iConnectMIDI4+ has merely the same audio pass through channels as the iConnectMIDI2+. Because I do my recording in DVD quality audio (48kHz,24-bit) this means that I can only use audio pass through with two computers together on the iConnectMIDI4+, which is exactly what the iConnectMIDI2+ is capable of. The third computer connected is pointless as it cannot participate in the audio pass through feature while the two others are.
Excellent quality

reviewText:
When I saw someone using a Snark to tune their guitar, I knew I had to get one. I love it! It's the best tuner I've ever used. The display is bright and easy to read, the head swivels all around so you can angle it just right. The padding is soft enough that it won't damage your instrument. It's easy to use - just press the yellow button to turn it on, and again to turn it off. It will also turn itself off after a minute or two of inactivity if you forget to turn it off.

I use it to tune my guitar, bass, and ukulele and it's excellent. Highly recommended.

I purchased this digital piano from amazon and have since had it for one day.  I plan to update this review over the next couple of months as my impressions change while having it.  As a brief summary of myself, I'm a moderately skilled and self taught piano player who wanted to get a instrument for my apartment so that I could continue developing and have an outlet for creativity in my home.

7/10/2014:

The piano arrived yesterday and the box that it arrives in is HUGE (~6 feet long) and extremely HEAVY (~100 lbs)!  Check your machismo, as this box is just too wide and long to get an appropriate grip to hulk it into your own home by yourself--much less up a flight of stairs.  That's my warning if you live in a flat that isn't on the ground floor and has no elevator access--also, if you DO have elevators, check to see if a service lift is available otherwise you may have trouble fitting this box inside a tiny elevator stall with you.  I actually had to assist the UPS delivery guy to get the package off of his truck and into my kitchen--he was a big help and I couldn't have done it without his help.

Assembly wasn't too hard, first of all make sure you have the box with it's label upright before unpacking the items inside.  This will make sure that the actual keyboard unit is easiest to pull out of the box--additionally, the instructions to put together the piano is located in a small packaged cardboard box that can be easy to miss or confuse with the smaller boxes that contain screws or the power cord and adapter.  My best advice when unboxing is that you remove all of the items from the main box first, set the wooden frames and foot pedals in one corner of the room, the keyboard unit in another corner, and the manuals/screws in another.  Then repack the styrofoam protectors back into the box and save one last corner for the bubble wrap/bags/packing tape to throw away later.  When you start construction, you'll build around the foot pedals, so the area/corner should have plenty of room and be well lit to work on the front and back of the piano.  Lastly, I recommend keeping the box if you have the room as taking apart the keyboard isn't too complicated (in retrospect) and is a potentially safer option than moving the piano whole later on.

After putting together the keyboard, plugging it in, and starting to play, I have to say that the sound is terrific.  The digital piano not only emulates notes but also the background sounds of the inner workings of the piano including the dull hammer strikes and accompanying resonance of nearby keys.  It's very easy to forget that you're not actually playing on an actual piano.  However, when you do remember, it's a bit of a audio/sensory dissonance.  At certain times of lucidity, it'll feel like your just calling a person over the phone who's playing the exact same notes you're attempting to play using a piano-shaped block of wood.  It almost sounds too good, too full-bodied, for what you've got in front of you.  It's only been a day, but I've caught myself on more than four occasions checking the sides of the piano to remind myself how thin it is but how resonant it sounds.  I imagine this is something I'll get used to.

I'll conclude with some issues, there's a definitive learning curve regarding how to truly appreciate the features this digital piano offers.  Two tone layering, duet mode, adjusting brightness, and learning how to incorporate my USB stick all made for a very overwhelming experience.  The biggest issue is that the display only works by paying attention to a couple of red flashing lights/beeps, which makes it hard to know what mode your in or what signal went through.  This is something that will certainly take time to wrap my head around as I've never had to learn such a system for a piano and my personal keyboards have the advantage of an informative LCD display, which this device lacks.  I also noted that certain keys that perform useful functions (such as transposing) are not labeled and must be committed to memory or left as an item to consult in the manual.  In fact, as much as I was pleased to have the music book, the piano manual has yet to left the music stand and I continue to reference it.  I imagine with extended familiarity this will be smaller challenge.

8/7/2014

I've now owned this piano for about a month.  Let's see, my immediate impressions after going back to my old upright is that that the Casio PX850 provides a substantially improved playing experience.  I would list the improvements thusly:

+This Casio provides me all of the benefits of an authentic piano sound(s) without having to worry about all of the long-term issues that come typical with an actual piano.  Things like notes going out of tune, broken hammers, dented felts, keys that get stuck in the down position, inner dust collecting, broken strings, etc. are all comfortably forgotten issues now.
+It's fun to play for hours, then kick up the transpose a couple of notes and replay the same songs and have the sound feel completely different without having to learn or struggle with different scales.  It's just a great way to play for fun.
+The keys are the length of a grand.  I never noticed this feature but I really appreciate the extra space for my large hands.
+I can adjust the mellow/brightness of the piano on the fly.
+There's always a clear unmuddled sound emanating from the PX850 even on full sustain.
+Headphones are great!
+The speakers are situated just underneath the notes, when you play, the keys actually vibrate just like a real piano.  The feeling is completely uncanny.

-Yeah, the lower register keys with higher tension will clack when you play them hard.  Can't be heard at past 45% volume.  Not sure if this was a first day "issue" but I noticed it fairly recently.  Doesn't really bother me.  It's not really an overpower sound, but I know this very same noise has annoyed a bunch of other customers.
-All of the features are still nebulous to me.  I can record onto the Piano or the USB, and I can transfer songs from the USB to my computer, but I can't transfer songs I record on the Piano to the USB (or at least I don't know how yet).  There's also a bunch of very nuanced things I can do like change the tempermant of the piano and I've yet to touch duet mode.  So far I've been just happy enough plugging in the machine, turning it own, belting out a few songs, then turning it off and unplugging it.  The fancy stuff hasn't really been a selling point to me.  Surprisingly, I haven't even used all of the different sounds yet.
-The piano has a giant CASIO PX850 logo plastered on the back in white.  This won't bother you if your Casio is up against a wall, but mine is actually isn't and it's a shame seeing such a high contrast text plastered on my black cabinet.  I was hoping that only labels on the machine I had to deal with were the ones on the front next to the ominous red lights I can't turn off.
-Can't turn the red lights off?  Shame.  I wish they just sort of shut off after a few seconds.

Overall, this unit out performs my previous upright piano.  I'm upgrading the review to a four until I become more familiar with the more advanced controls.

10/14/2014

Apparently I screwed up when posting my long September review.  So just to summarize, the piano is still holding up very well. I've upgraded to a 32 GB USB to further explore the recording options, and overall I'm still highly satisfied.  As far as cons go, I think the number of red lights that are on at the same time are a little excessive, but I never notice them when I'm playing.  Still happy with this purchase and the piano is holding up well even under very forceful strikes and regular use for about 3 months.

3/7/2015

So it's been a little over half a year.

Here's my update:

Good points:
+The piano is still very much in working condition, with minimal wear.
+My piano playing has improved dramatically
+The lid is wide enough to rest my old laptop on, which has dramatically increased the utility of recording music
+I've learned to easily record my play, modify transpose, use dual voice features, adjust the volume of each voice, use the metronome, etc.
+Everything is still in tune... which, I mean, is expected for an electronic instrument--but still, kudos, Casio.

Bad points:
-The keys in the octave just above middle C are beginning to creak very slightly.  I can certainly hear a greater give in the keys I routinely play compared to the keys I don't.  It's way more disconcerting that it is actually distracting.  I can't hear it when I play, or with the headphones on, but when the piano is turned off and I press the keys I can make out definitive differences in keys I've played a lot on vs keys I haven't.
-Sometimes I'll try to record a song and only realize after I've finished playing and moved the USB to my computer to view the waveform that I wasn't recording while I was playing.  I've had this instrument for a 3/4ths of a year and I'm still having an issue with the unintuitive feedback user interface.  Maybe I'm just a dummy (trust me, I'm not counting that out) but seriously, there should have just been a single dedicated red button you push to record and you push again to stop recording. Instead, to record, I have to push a button called AUDIO SETTINGS then wait while the lights next to AUDIO RECORDER and SONG RECORDER buttons flash five times, which means it's reading my USB drive (obviously, right?), then I push AUDIO RECORDER again and then a yellow light comes on for SONG RECORDER and the AUDIO RECORDER red light will flash once and then (hopefully) it will record whatever I play next--UNLESS if it completely refreshes my piano settings to the default settings.  Also if the red button next to AUDIO RECORDER keeps flashing, you pushed it too many times and have to push it again so it only flashes once so it starts recording.  I mean seriously.  I have a 15 year old YAMAHA keyboard that records with just a one button press and stops when you press it again.  It cost $30 bucks. It's something that still frustrates me.
summary: Will update review over the next couple of months

It's all about the sound. Different price points give you different features and more inputs including independent channels for each, but the sound is the same. This board sounds every bit as good as my Mackie CR-1604 that was eight times the price of this board. Plug a mic in and sing through it and hear the deep solid one that Mackie is famous for. Even their vocal plate reverb for voice is just right.
I was shocked that Mackie made a board this cheap. They also have a ProFX12 which is twice the money and has a USB and a proper power supply. It also has 6 mic pres with their own EQ's instead of 4. The list goes on. You could actually run a small band through this Mix12FX with some microphones, a keyboard plugged in, and even a guitar or two that had their own effects pedals, or effects sends from amps.

The limitation on any one of these lowest priced boards is that they share faders on the additional channels. So the first 4 have dedicated EQ, and the MixFX-12 has three band EQ but the other channels don't, and they split the fader into a stereo so one fader controls two channels; they share the same fader. An argument could be made that you can pan those additional channels hard right, or left and have a dedicated fader, but then you would lose the other channel that it shares. With a center position on the fader you have two separate channels that go up and down the same on one fader. No independent levels for each. My CR-1604 Mackie has separate faders, EQ, etc. etc. on each channel.

This Mix12FX does not come with a USB but USB based boards generally only output the final mix. It is not like it is equal to an interface where you can isolate each and every channel in the computer. So the net result is you have one premixed at the settings you have on the board with a single stereo mix only, or you could say it is the main outs only.

Everyone talks about the pop when you start it up, and the fact that there is no power switch. My Adcom MKIII power amps from the 70 which are high end amps all pop. I grew up with amps popping so it is not a big deal to me. However the instructions state that you should plug in/turn on the mixer with all levels turned down, and no instruments plugged in before you turn on your amp. If you are a performing band and going on break, just slide down the main outs and leave it on. Also a switched power strip is a good idea, or in line switch. You are saving a bundle on this mixer, it is unbelievably cheap especially considering you are getting 12 channels while still maintaining the classic Mackie quality. This board sounds every bit as good as my CR-1604.

I recently purchased the Behringer XENYX X1832 for about two and a half times the price of the Mix12 Mackie, and it has a ton of bells and whistles including EQ's on all the channels (6 dedicated independent channels with Mix pres with shared EQ on the others) with an additional 9 band graphic EQ for the final mix or monitors, yes it has USB and the list goes on. I had originally ordered a 12 channel but I did a lot of research, and some of the reviews stated that they did eventually have some problems with some of the channels. So the advice was when dealing with cheaper boards especially one that gives you so much for so little, get more channels than you need so if one or two fails you still have enough of them to get the job done.

Mackie is known for excellence, and my CR-1604 that I bought in the 80's still works perfectly with no problems whatsoever. They are generally more expensive than the competition and are better built so I was surprised to see this Mix12 giving you so much for so little.
Personally I plan on using this as an easy carry around mixer for open mic night. I can plug a drum machine, a mic into it, my guitar effects pedal, and my keyboards etc. and then hand the house PA sound guy a single output that is coming from the effects send to plug into the PA. That's a line out signal which is the level you want for sub mixer setups. That way I have control over my tone and reverb and volume levels for the right mix. Then I tell them to just set the fader to the proper volume level and leave the EQ, effects etc. out of it as in just set it flat. I'm not a control freak I just know that tone settings etc. can make the difference between a lousy sounding performance and a great one. So why leave it up to someone else who might even be in the bag when he is playing with it, and may not even care or worse. :-)

I wanted to wait until I tried it out for sound quality before I bought a carrying case, but this one is a winner for sure. I bought the Gator cases Pro G Mixerbag 1212 which is 12x12x5 inches. It fits it like a glove. If you didn't know any better you would think Gator made is especially just for this mixer. It tucks into place it is that perfect of a fit and won't wiggle around at all with its padded sides and edges. It also has an extra zipped in pouch for carrying cords etc.

So if you are looking for a small, inexpensive, incredibly lightweight and portable mixer for your smaller band, or for a solo performing musician, or even as a playback mixer for your home studio into powered speakers etc. this is a great choice. The Mackie Pro FX12 for almost twice the price with separate EQ on all the channels, and 6 mic pres on independent channels is even better yet and is currently the Amazon number one seller. Highly recommended.

I play a Melancon P90 artist with 2 humbuckers, pre-amp and LRBaggs piezo. I've spent nearly $4K on two amps and four pedals to use just with this guitar.

This review is geared for Blue Yeti mic users. The consensus by other Yeti users seemed to be a mix of those saying it works and others saying the mic is too heavy. For $15 I took a chance and as you can see from my included photos it definitely holds the mic.

The mic stand is of average lightweight quality but the joints feel nice and sturdy and no tightening was needed at the main joints. Movement is solid and smooth and once you lock down the moving joints it's quite sturdy. As you can see from my included photos it easily holds the mic at a 45 degree angle, vertical, and inverted with no noticeable sag (although it does have a slight play at the mic attachment point which doesn't really cause much issue.)

The stand doesn't have full swivel movement but it definitely has enough back and forth movement to adjust it to your liking. Take note that the stand itself is of a smaller size with the length of the arm from one joint to another at about 14.5". Also the base where it clamps down opens to roughly 1.75" so make sure that your desk isn't overly thick. The stand does comes with an adapter so that you can mount the Yeti with no problems.

Overall, for the price it's a great stand. Since it pretty easily holds the heavy Yeti, it should be even better for smaller, lighter mics (NOTE: I recently purchased the AT2020USB as well and it works well with this mic as well.) The main reason I purchased this was to get rid of the slight knocking noise the Yeti would pick up from my keyboard/mouse use and this stand has essentially eliminated this, even with the stand clamped on the same desk. Great stand, great price, would definitely recommend. As long as you don't buy it with high expectations of a professional quality stand you should be happy.

First off, those that are complaining that these don't measure up to the Hohners and Seydels need to do a reality check, this set comes out to a little over three dollars a harp if you count the case as a freebie, at that price what do you expect solid gold?

As far as the set itself the first thing I noticed was that the case seemed well made with both a carry handle and a shoulder strap, after a few days use the carry handle is still unblemished, but where the shoulder strap meets the case the fabric is abrading rapidly (see product photos for a close up) the rest of the case is well constructed and should hold up well barring any abuse.
the harps themselves are decently constructed, the engraving on the plates is rather cheesy and cheaply done and should have been omitted altogether to improve the harps looks, as for function they play easily but their volume is about half what you would get from the above-mentioned Hohner and Seydel harps and the tone from the Johnsons sounds "thinner" than from the others. The tune is off on some of the harps but they are ok for general playing.

If you want a set to go on the road with in a semi pro or a professional setting these are not what you would want, if however you are like me a amateur that plays to while away the time or to entertain family and friends who just wants a set of the different keys to play in pickup sessions with friends this is a perfect set for you.
I just bought this as a temporary replacement for some saddles that were rusted beyond all hell. get the job done but don't expect to much from them.

reviewText:
UPDATE: I've downgraded this to one star because Focusrite units are not compatible with each other... Although I own two of these units, they cannot be used simultaneously to give extra inputs/outputs. I think its totally pathetic and a deal breaker. Scarlett units are not compatible with each other!?!?! That doesn't make any sense. Focusrite needs to get it's act together.

===============================

I've been using the 2i2 (1st gen)  for many years and I found it to be workable but not fantastic. The 2i4 is a decent upgrade for a few reasons... the mono switch is very useful for checking mixes on Auratone or Avantone cube speakers - I'm really happy that the 2i4 has midi i/o connectors - I don't understand why Focusrite doesn't include midi on the 2i2 - it doesn't make any sense imho. I love the extra goodies from Softube - some really nice VSTs. Focusrite is making a mistake bundling Protools after all these years. A deal with Presonus Studio One would have been far more progressive because it's the #1 DAW that is now finally destroying the Protools monopoly.

Lee Oskar makes good harmonicas, and this one fits in the tradition of quality.  I like the low F, since the standard F is a bit shrill, with the high notes being up there in the stratosphere with piccolos and bat squeaks. Ditto the Low D. Truthfully, I don't know if the Lee Oskar line is significantly better than the equivalent Hohner (Orchestra model, maybe), but having replaceable plates is a good way to keep costs down a little.

When the case arrived the first thing I noticed after unpacking is that the latch was not engaged, and when I tried pushing it in the button wouldn't budge.  So, figuring it was in the locked position somehow, I put in the key and turned it but it did nothing.  After closer examination, the little cam inside the latch fell out on the floor.  That would explain why it arrived unlatched.  So, the latch mechanism left the factory non operable.  That was strike one.  Strike two came shortly thereafter when I noticed the fabric inside the case was extremely thin, you could literally see through it!  No way this material would protect a violin, especially seeing there were no suspension pads in the bottom.  The last strike was the obvious cheapness of the zippers, that were very stiff and hard to get going.  I packed this thing up and shipped it back the next day, a very easy and simple task thanks to Amazon.
  Take my advise and save up a little more $$ and invest in something a bit more substantial.  I figured for the money that it wouldn't be a professional case, but come on - - I wouldn't recommend this case, even for a beginner with a cheap Chinese fiddle.  There are better values out there, and almost anything would protect your instrument better than this one.
summary: Non-functioning latch, very cheap construction - - LOOK ELSEWHERE!

reviewText: Great tool for singer songwriter solo type acts.  My older son likes it a lot.

I got 3 of these 20', and 6 of the 10' snakes for use on the road.  I do live sound for roughly 2-3 events each month, and I carry with me quite a few cables to each event cuz you'll never know what you may need more at each site.  The problem is the long xlr cables can be quite heavy, quite easy to get tangled, quite confusing to deal with when you have to use lots of them, and are time consuming to roll up (especially those of length 30-50').

Since I found these, I have left most of the longer xlr cables at home to lighten up my cable loads.  My typical live setup would have 8 powered speakers divided into 3 groups (main left, main right, monitors), and running 8 set of xlrs and keeping them nicely organized on stage is tough.

Now I would run 3 of these snakes (either 10' or 20') from my mixer out, 1 for each group.  Then have a 15' xlr from the end of each snake to individual speaker.  The stage now looks much cleaner, and the shorter end 15' xlrs are much easier to roll up.  If I need to cover more distance, I just use more snake as needed (it's why I bought 3x 20' and 6x 10' snakes)

The only issue I believe you'll encounter with any cable is how long it'll last with tugging and pulling, and the end connectors of this snake are not built to last.  So I opened up all 8 connectors and dropped in a generous amount of hot glue to keep the wirings together, as well as serving as extra welding.  Just drop in the hot glue, then quickly close the connector back the way it was, before the hot glue harden.

Btw, the monoprice instrument cable does come with hot-glue reinforcement, which I was pleasantly surprised to find, so you won't have to do the hot glue for those like you have to do for these snakes.
summary: Very affordable snake. Will last with minor reinforcement

Well, these are the cheapest of the cheap, and what you have to know is that the PU is the cheapest part anyway, and you aren't done - you have to have a signal processor which costs much more than the pickup. The reason pickups by Fishman and Baggs are expensive is because they have impedance buffering and other processing built in, which they mis-label "pre-amps" perhaps to confuse us innocent musicians, because piezo pickups have plenty of gain already and don't require any more pre-amplification - what they do require is an impedance buffer or impedance transformer. The piezo material itself is apparently dirt cheap. These and similar PUs have an ultra-hi-impedance output signal at 10 million ohms (that's like radio waves - which is why the processor is best very close to the PU so as not to pick up radio waves on the cable, which can happen with some processors) which has to be processed down to a much lower impedance in order to feed the lower-impedance inputs on most amps and mixers.

If you try to use this pickup without the appropriate signal processor, you will have a tone with excessive high frequencies and little bass, and you will have to use multiple levels of EQ to get it to sound anything like acceptable. This is the reason for the bad reviews, when people say "this thing sounds horrible!". Yes it does, unprocessed.

The processor in question needs to have an input impedance of 10 or 20 M-ohms (millions of ohms) and an output impedance (to connect to amp or mixer) of something several orders of magnitude lower, like 600 ohms (mic level) or 10 k-ohms (line level).
The box Behringer sells for about 25 bucks has an input impedance of only about 1 M-ohm, not enough (check the specs).
The Boss AD-2 works well (and I am using it), for a hundred bucks. It's the most cost-effective solution. I think it probably works for _any_ instrument with a piezo PU.
Fishman and Baggs make boxes that are supposed to work, according to the specs, for about 300 bucks. I tried one Fishman model and returned it for various reasons - too expensive, didn't like the proprietary power supply, ate 9v battery in two hours, etc.
Grace Designs makes some for a thousand bucks or so. Probably pretty nice! Guess maybe I'll never know!

So, this pickup is almost free compared to the processor you need, but it will sound really lousy unless you have something to plug it into with an ultra-hi-impedance input. Read the specs on your gear.

Now, these pickups are cheaply wired and the connection in the jack will break easily. This is a solder job requiring a new jack, but no big deal. Also the plastic clam-shell housing for the pickup can crack apart easily. If it does, put it back together with cyano acrylate glue. No problem.

I am actually using two of these wired in parallel to the same jack, a DIY job. I took the housings apart and filled them with epoxy to prevent the solder joints breaking. Although I cannot explain the technical reason, this actually improved the sound of the unprocessed signal - but not enough to not need an impedance buffer.
summary: Understanding impedance levels is the key; signal processor necessary.

But just know that you're very unlikely to have them match if you use more than one. If you want matching then choose one of the darker colors where it's the stain that matches up.

Get a measurement of your neck/headstock and compare to this before buying. Otherwise plan on the need to tune your guitar each time you take it off the wall.

As an amp stand it is designed to lean backwards, away from the amp, so that gravity keeps the amp in a solid three point of contact position. But for a mic stand, it means if you need to pull it slightly closer to you and you have the adjustable leg all the way out, the leg falls out and you have to put it back in. In short, you can't go wrong with the boom arm, but you need to be ready to deal with the base that it goes with.

I bought one of these to replace a broken headset on our wireless system for the Pastor's mic, intending to save up for a genuine Shure mic when we could afford it.  So as a result, I really wasn't expecting it to sound that great.  But boy was I shocked.  It sounds GREAT!  The output level is higher than the old mic, so I had to turn the gain down quite a bit (the broken mic was not a genuine Shure head mic either), which is a bonus.

It seems well made.  The cord seems to be very flexible.  I don't yet know how durable it is - time will tell.  But the audio quality out of this thing is amazing for the price.  I only had to EQ out one frequency that we have feedback with EVERY mic in our church.  The pastor sounds like himself, as he should and I can easily get a 72dB level into the mains without feedback.

I really like this mic, and was pleasantly surprised.  I even bought a 2nd one after hearing how this one sounds.  (I figured it was cheap enough, that I'd have a backup ready instantly in case this one gets damaged.)

PS: This is an omnidirectional mic, so it probably won't work well for singing with a monitor system, but it's excellent mic for spoken word IMHO.

reviewText:
I've been in bands for 15+ years, and sometimes songs get written and changed and forgotten from week to week. I've tried recording with my phone by itself, which sounds hideous. I've done elaborate multi-mic setups mixed to a computer, but then you have to wait for someone to take the time to mix it all down and send it to everyone. Huge hassle.
I bought the Tascam DR-05 because someone in one of my other bands had one, and he would email songs to everyone within a few days of practice and they sounded pretty good. I purchased this model, and after the second time I used it, I had songs that I didn't have to do any editing to. They sounded clear, with no distortion, and you could hear each distinct instrument. We play loudly with a lot of distortion, and I set the recorder up toward the back of the room on a camera tripod (it has a hole for the mounting bracket) and I raised it up fairly high. I am VERY happy with the recordings that I've gotten. The interface on the actual recorder takes a little bit to get used to, but once you do, it's not too complicated.
Just as a side note, right before I purchased this I bought the Tascam iM2W, that is a microphone that attaches to an older iPhone, and you can download a Tascam app to make your phone into a portable recorder. It sounded awful, and I couldn't get the software to work correctly, or record for more than a few minutes at a time. I only spent $15 on it, and I'm sure it would work for some people, but definitely not what I was looking for.
Do not hold up in professional use! The connector are falling apart.

reviewText:
I wasn't sure about this preamp initially. I give it a 5/5 for what it is, not to imply that it is one of the best out there.

Pros (for me)
- Good sound
- Good headroom
- Low distortion
- Low noise
- DI is good for bass and electric guitar
- Balanced in/out
- Useful VU meter
- Useful send/return
- Headphone monitoring
- Notched Gain + Linear trim

Cons (for me)
- Big and ugly
- The space is spent on all-in-one kind of stuff. If you just want the preamp, get the 2 channel 1U rack.
- I wish they made this unit in a full 1U rack unit with all the same inputs/outputs
- No TRS output. XLR output only

I use it for vocals, acoustic guitar, and electric bass. It handles everything very well. No complaints on pre-amp performance.

This design may be useful to put in a sound booth if the performer wants to monitor themselves and the cue mix from the engineer. In a big studio they're likely to have all that hardware in the monitoring room, but for smaller studios and home studios, this could be a useful tool. For the monitoring room it's a big box that gets in the way. I'd much rather have a 1 or 2 channel full 1U rack version of this, but I do appreciate it as a standalone box for practicing DI instruments or testing mics.

This is a step up from my other cheaper preamps. If you are on the SM7 bandwagon, then yes, it is powerful and clean enough for that mic. But don't think that "clean" means there is no amp his at all. At 50db Gain I measure an average (across the freq spectrum) noise level of -100dB RMS in my DAW. This is quite good.

Make sure you use balanced inputs. You'll need a female XLR to male TRS to put the output of the preamp into the line input of your A/D converter. You can go straight XLR to your mic input, but you may get different sounds and distortion levels. Use line input if you can and make sure to adjust the gain on your input device to unity gain (different for every device and every pot).
summary: A solid Preamp with lots of extra features

Wow, VERY happy with this pedal as an amp simulator for use with FRFR speakers.

I'm a total tone tweakhead and have been using completely programmable rigs for years...  But lately I have been doing a bunch of impromptu gigs with lots of great guitarists, so to find a place in the mix, I've been playing a lot of Guitar Synth, and have been desperately in need of a manageable pedalboard built around the synth but also able to get great guitar tones through the FRFR speakers the synth needs.  (Or even direct into the PA)

The Fly Rig 5 has totally answered the call.  I take the guitar out from the synth, through some pedals into the fly rig, remix it with the synth and run that through an eventide H9 to a pair of QSC K10s or the PA, and have managed to dial in some great guitar tones that get lots of compliments from other musicians.

Basically I use the SANSAMP section as a clean fenderish amp that sounds great by itself or being pushed by pedals and the PLEXI section as a "dirty channel" that also sounds great being pushed by pedals.  The PLEXI "hot" control happily is INDEPENDENT of the PLEXI channel, so SANSAMP plus HOT is a great clean lead sound.  And my RAT and my Wah, and my Overdrive, and my Compressor all sound great through both clean and dirty channels.  I then set up the tap tempo DLA section for a nice short "thickening" delay and route the output through the H9 for sfx... and YEA!...

IMHO, best for the size direct sound, lots of foot controllable variety, and ALL in a REALLY small package...  Whats not to like?

PS: FYI... Richie Kotzen version IMHO looks nicer for running into a REAL amp... but for PA or FRFR, I think the FlyRig5 is better.
summary: Direct to PA or FRFR speakers from a pedalboard... this is currently best in the class!

reviewText: Very small and hides on the back of the neck of my guitar - You almost don't even notice it's there, but it works great

Well I thought if the youtube demos were close to what i got in my order it would be a keeper.  Sure enough this amp seems like the real deal.
It was plain to see that the carton had been dropped on one corner so i was a bit worried but the inner packing was quite good and absorbent as it should be as it traveled a long ways to get to my house.

I saw enough on the demo video that i was able to put the amp through most of its paces without reading the manual, but if you are not familiar with tube amps i would read it first and do some google homework...actually for just about any guitar amp you've never owned or played before.  The three channels are all very good and each one has a variety of tones available.  If you like a more metal sound then the stock tubes are geared towards that although the clean channel is surprisingly crisp and sounds great.  I bought the bugera 212K  140 watt cab to go with it and they sound great together. Because I prefer classic rock and blues to metal i changed a few preamp tubes and a couple of power tubes with some i had lying around.  No bias required! Now that is amazing.  There was a nice improvement with each change I made for my tone preferences, and again I was pleasantly surprised. i have 3 distinctly different channels now. For me I like the Humbucker tone from my Les Paul and my Telecaster Thinline the best. If you are thinking about this amp I cant really see any reason to not to try it.

Hopefully the infinium technology will stand the test of time. My metal head son thinks its awesome too.  It sounds just perfect at any volume.  Now I will be selling a couple of other tube amps I have and keeping this one.  Bugera makes awesome amps for GAS folks on a budget. My V22 is also awesome.  Apparently swapping the rectifier tubes for the modern smaller JJ's is supposed to also be an improvement.  So the thing I like is that it sounds great as is, plus it can sound better if you upgrade it as your budget permits. I had an amp I wanted to upgrade and make work and I spent a lot of money on it trying to do that and nothing i tried really got it to sound as good as this amp does right out of the box. The best I could was hook up a chain of pedals to improve that amp, but thats not required with this Trirec. This amp is versatile at generating tones for a variety of music styles.
Don't spend more on some imitation, this does the job and is a solid EHX pedal.

My title is such because when Amazon shipped the guitar, I was sent the Cherry Sunburst model when I had ordered the Ebony! Amazon got me taken care of almost immediately, so I'm really happy about that.

In any event, the guitar is a GREAT value for the money. It has great tone and sustain, the neck is fast and wide making it easier to play, especially if you have big hands. I had a Squier Strat Standard at one time and it does not even come close to this guitar (or the Epiphone SG-310 I had prior to the LP-100) in quality OR sound. There's just NO comparison.

Speaking of the SG-310, I actually think it sounds a bit better than the LP-100, however, both are very versatile and can play just about any music. Quality and construction are excellent. This is NOT a "beginner" guitar. You can perform live with it and I think it will hold up fine for YEARS!

I miss my SG and will most likely pickup another one very soon, but I don't regret getting another LP (I had one for over 20 years). This truly is an excellent guitar for such a little price.

I've been playing since about '72 and it's easily (along with the SG) one of the best guitars I've owned. You really do get Gibson sound without the Gibson price tag. There are higher-level LP's (and SG's) with the neck thru bodies (the LP-100 and SG-310 have bolt on necks) and I may "move up" someday, but I have no complaints at all with this guitar. Didn't have any with the SG either. Oh, yeah, higher-end models use different/better wood. Just don't think this guitar is the "cheap stuff"...you would be very wrong if you did.

I give it 4 stars because I think the SG-310 beats it in the sound/sustain department...but JUST barely. There's a reason the LP has been a music staple for DECADES and this model carries on that tradition.

All in all, the LP-100 was a VERY wise choice for me.
Until now I haven't found a better string brand for my bass guitar, durable, great tone and reliable. I don't want any other...

Update Notes: 10/2010: Another buyer asked me to look into the power draw for battery usage reasons. After using the TWO independent battery conservation modes on the 661 (turn off the leds and minimize the big display from 5 rows to just one row of data) the jumpy current waveform settled down to 315 mA DC +/- 15 mA. For battery usage, you can use a 315mA draw for conservative recording power usage estimates. So that perspective users of the 661 can get a feel for it I've uploaded 5 most often seen sample screenshots with notes in the pictures section above. The notes cover what each screen does and how the function keys work. The instruction manual shows you how to wire pushbuttons and resistors to the 4 terminal remote plug which is VERY hard to find (most are 3 terminal - left/right/ground) - you can use the 3 terminal because the only 2 points you need are ground and the tip, but here is the 4 pin version for $0.28 on amazon 6FT 3.5 mm to 3 RCA AV Camcorder Video Cable Sony JVC 6 with this cable and the instructions in the manual you can build your own remote with LEDs and extended switches beyond the marantz remote from the PMD660 Marantz RC600 Mic Mount Remote Control which could be operated by computer or other automated systems. Basically the 4 terminal plugs are becomming more common now. The resistor values chosen for pushbutton operation are common values and easy to find. UPDATE 8-2010: I've put alot of hours on my PMD661, made a custom case for it, and now I must report a MINOR negative about a whole class of products (the 661, the H4n, certain flashlights, etc) While doing flashlight testing on the Fenix TK-40, 'Menace' pointed out that it seemed to drain AA batteries without being used AT ALL while a similar light, the TK30 did not. I confirmed his findings using an inline ampmeter - a small amount of power was flowing with the light turned off. As I measured other products that used the AA NiMH cell, the problem proved to be a bigger issue than just one flashlight. This "trickle" power is just like your car - leave it in a garage at the airport for 30 days and don't expect the battery to be full when you return. The amount is small, but placing a plastic strip between a battery and the spring then routing it out of the battery compartment will stop the power from flowing. The "off" power is higher on the PMD661 because it has a timer and can turn itself on for play or record functions with preprogrammed times which other recorders can not do. Update 9-12-2009 - I just returned from a cruise ship using the 661. I used a Canon hs-10 avchd camera for capturing the main stage video and the 661 to plug into the ship's mixing board for audio. The ship's audio engineer was excited to see the 661 and hapily pulled out an XLR patch cord set to give me the house mix line level out, which was recorded in the same lossless format (24bit/48 khz) used by the camcorder audio making synchronization in adobe premiere pro a breeze. The final benefit was hearing the show audio as it left the mixing board to the amps instead of being picked up by the camera set on a tripod in the audience full of echo and laughter, clapping etc. The final production to blu-ray disc sounded like I was right on stage with the camera. The marantz ALC circuit performed better than expected and prevented digital clipping while maximizing dynamic range. End of edit. [ACTUAL PRODUCT REVIEW BEGINS HERE] When Marantz added a line level XLR input that bypassed the microphone preamps as opposed to just a mic level input in the 660 (prior model) I finally jumped at it. Since I work alot of mixing boards I have access to the final stereo mixdown at line level voltages. Whats the big deal? Recording at line level gives you 20dB more signal to noise - thats 100 times better for those who don't speak dB - compared to mic level xlr inputs. Also recorders that put an attenuator in front of microphone amplifiers tend to be noisy - marantz is not built this way (the H4n I use for MIC level recordings is - it is not well suited to line level input because it must attenuate the signal to 0.8% before recording it) If you look at your dvd player at home all the outputs are line level simply to get rid of noise. With such a fabulous recorder, why in the world would you want 100 times more noise in your recordings? There are many other factors Marantz did that made the 661 the optimum professional recorder to get - the display is bright and easy to read under all lighting conditions, they used a 1/4" headphone jack so the little 3.5mm headphones wouldn't pull out at the worst moment (another pro move) - and they improved the case quality. There is also a digital input for people who are 100% digital already, however it stops at 44.1/48 KHz sampling. Given these features, the PMD-661 sits head and antlers above all the other compact recorders out there offering professional connectivity at an economical price. It's also fully customizable - the bright display is dimmable through 8 steps for indoor club use at night, and it features dual rca line level outputs for analog playback. About the only thing I would like to have seen would be a worldclock input for synchronizing analog recordings to digital cameras, but the size of the bnc connector would have nixed that option in this handheld product. Prices are starting to drop - I bought in early but you can save 50 bucks off the original price. Good job Marantz (from a former dedicated tascam fan!) PROS: +2 levels of power saving (dual VU meter cutoff and 5 line down to 1 line OLED display) - both are independent of each other +runs on AC power through a 5V converter and also runs off USB power when doing file transfers +Easy to create multiple folders and levels within them using the 4-way rocker buttons for character selection - in fact naming your settings is also easy. +remote control is customizable with just resistors and switches if you know how to solder and need to operate it by computer or other external devices +XLR ins are well designed and quiet compared to other products on the market. +1/8" line level TRS input as well lets you use a 3.5mm trs male to male jumper for recording computer outputs +digital input as well [COAX] - I purchased a Cables to Go 40019 Optical to Coaxial Digital Audio Converter (Black) when needed for $13 +2 ea built in mics as the 4th source +tripod mount +pre-record buffer captures 3 seconds of audio prior to entering record +standard SD card format can be ejected and read on a pc quickly instead of doing USB transfers +easily updates firmware when improvements are made +12 hour runtime on 2700 mah nimh cells with full power conservation recording mp3 from XLR in (tested) +When batteries are exhausted it closes all files and shuts down politely. +internal stereo speakers can be used to monitor recordings or 1/4" headphones +rugged, well built design including the battery door which has a large latch to prevent accidental opening or loss +ALC design is well engineered and not noticable in recordings - seems like it uses fuzzy logic to prevent clipping. +coaxial manual level adjustment allows for separate l/r level difference and ganged level adjustment of both simultaneously Cons -timer based recording draws more "off" power - inserting an insulator made from a plastic battery case easily prevents draining batteries until you need to start if you do not use the timer functions. -can not entirely shut off the display - most minimal power usage is to shut off LED vu meter and just have one line of text in the OLED window with essential data on it. -lacks a 1/8" mic in but has a 1/8" stereo TRS line in instead so all mic level voltages must go in via XLRs -4 input sources but only 3 personalities means one input won't be used without reconfiguring (usually digital in) -lacks digital out (other than USB and removing SD card)
summary: A compact digital recorder with XLR line level inputs - finally

reviewText:
I've read the pros and cons on Amazon, but there is no substitute for trying these pins on your own guitar. Given the reasonable price, this was an easy purchase to make. Cosmetically these look very nice, not too gaudy and bit machined-looking due to the knurling of the tops. If they offered these without the knurling, but polished to look more jewelry-like I would like that better.

My two primary concerns were fit and tone, and I'm satisfied with both.  The pins fit my Taylor 714CE perfectly and don't have the tendency to pop out the way my factory-provided ones did. They fit all the way in the pin-holes making a nice tight fit. Because of the way these are machined, you can visually confirm that the flute of the pin is aligned properly with the pin hole even when completely seated.

Tone, however, was the primary reason for my purchase and I am very well pleased with the results.  I've analyzed before and after audio files and they visually confirm what my ears are hearing.  There is a 3db increase in sound output (I did not know this was possible from a mere change in pin material), and at the same time the strings are more balanced across the spectrum.  I've not lost any bass, yet the trebles are louder and while the strings still maintain the overall sound of a chord, each string is heard more distinctly at the same time. The waveform confirms that individual strings are more distinct as they stand out on either side of the main frequency spectrum. The sound is less "mushy" might be another way of stating it.

Yet, this effect is variable depending on how I strum the guitar and I can brush the strings to get them to sound more homogeneous, or bear down on each one to get the effect of each individual note.  Best of all, these pins have not changed the fundamental sound of my Taylor, which I really like and would not stand to lose (much like our sound tech's EQ, for this guitar, which maintains fidelity, and just amplifies it properly).

All in all I'm pleased and will be ordering more of these for my other guitars.  I can't say if sustain has improved, or diminished, it sounds about the same; however, when doing lead-runs on the G-B-E strings the increased volume is very nice to hear (louder, crisp, bell-like).

I can't be certain, but I believe after many other changes to my Taylor (L.R. Baggs Anthem pickups, D'Addario Phosphor-Bronze Light Strings and decreasing relief with the truss-rod and lowering the saddle height) I finally have the sound I've been working towards for a year now. I can close my eyes and listen to my playing with complete reverie, while time stands in abeyance.
summary: Good Fit, Great Improvement In Volume, More Balanced Tone

This is my first patchbay and I'm quite pleased with it. For years I've been crawling around behind the racks in my small studio wiring and re-wiring gear every time I want to reconfigure my signal chains. But no longer will I be covered in dust bunnies and spiders, thanks to the S-patch Plus. This thing really is a game changer, especially for those of us less experienced with what can be a rather confusing "simple" tool- it's well built and packs a lot of common-sense functionality into a small space.

The best part about the S-patch is the freedom it gives you to choose Normalled, Half-normalled or Thru functions with the flip of a switch on each input-output pair. This is really convenient, especially if, like me, you're new to patchbays and want to experiment with functionality and signal chain options. The switches are sturdy, as are the jacks and the metal casing of the unit itself- no cheap plastic or thin faceplates here. I've noticed no loss or degradation of signal when tracking or mixing with the unit and I've found the signal flow diagrams printed on the top of the casing to be very helpful as well.

My only complaint is that the unit doesn't come with Rack Screws, which isn't a huge deal, but it would be nice. It does come with stick-on rubber feet in a little bag, which I'm not using because I have it racked but they would be nice if you had this sitting on a desk. Additionally, some folks have commented on how there isn't much room on the face of the unit for labeling each channel. This is true, but that's the price you pay for a single rack space size unit. I got around this by purchasing a 2 foot long, 1.5" wide, 1/8" thick strip of aluminum at the local hardward store for 3 bucks. I used a jigsaw to cut it to ~19" long like a standard rack unit blank. I drilled out holes in the ends for screws and mounted it just above the S-patch on my rack. Then I stole my wife's labelmaker and created stick-on labels for each piece of gear connected to the patchbay, and stuck them vertically to the aluminum strip. This plate can easily be removed to access the diagrams on the top of the S-patch when you get confused on what the heck-swoggle "half-normal" means.

One word of caution, especially if you're new to this: while any TRS bay will pass phantom power from a preamp to a mic, you run the risk of "hotpatching" your mics if you plug in cables while the phantom power is engaged. This can really damage your preamps. If you're really careful, you can get around this by simply never patching a live mic, but this is always going to be a gamble, especially if you're like me and your brain is in 67 places at once during a session. So while it's tempting to put all your preamps "behind" the bay, it's better run the output of each pre to a channel of the patchbay which is then normalled to your interface / board. For example, in my studio if I want to plug a mic into an outboard preamp, I use the following chain:
Mic --- xlr patchbay (much safer for phantom than trs) --- Preamp --- S-patch channel normalled to line input on my interface. This means that my mics always run directly to my interface via my outboard preamps UNLESS I break the normal via patch cable. Any phantom power thus flows to the mic from the preamp "ahead" of the S-patch. Remember, phantom power flows the opposite direction of mic signal!

Overall, I'm very happy with the S-patch and I already can't imagine my control room without it. It's also already full, so I'll likely buy another soon.
