I put these strings on a cheap but decent Peavey bass with active pick ups.  The most noticeable difference between flat wound and round wound strings is the smooth feeling these strings have.  They are very comfortable.  As far as sound goes, I really like the sound but I wouldn't say that there is a stark contrast between these and round wounds.  I am assuming that if you're reading this review and are considering buying these strings, you probably understand the difference between flat wound and round wound.  If you don't, just google it and read up a bit so you know what you're getting.  Supposedly the flat wound strings are a little duller sounding.  I put some flat wounds on my telecaster and I definitely can hear a difference.  With the bass flat wounds, the difference is more subtle.  If you're worried about a drastic change in your sound with flat wounds, you probably don't need to be concerned unless you're an advanced player with a discerning ear (and if you are, then you don't need advice from me).  BUT, I should add that the D'Addario bass strings are "affordable" while the guitar strings I bought were Thomastik-Infelds and pricey.  That may explain the difference in what I perceive as change in sound (i.e., the Thomastiks are better quality than D'Addarios).  Is that actually true?  Probably not. But it's worth considering depending on whether you're looking for a change in sound or just some more comfortable strings.  I hope this helps. (I want to clarify I think D'Addarios are fine quality strings that I've used many times before.  I'm just stating differences I've noticed in order to help you decide what to buy.)

I can't even begin to describe how beautiful this guitar is. Not just to look at either. It feels beautiful, sounds beautiful and I am in love. I have heard so much talk about Taylors, Martins, Gibsons, Seagulls, etc. I haven't yet had the chance to play those brands but I honestly do not believe they can be any better than this guitar. And to be honest, even if they are I don't really care. This guitar, in my opinion, is absolutely perfect. I came on to Amazon looking for the GIBSON Hummingbird and was prepared to spend over $3,000 for it. Luckily for me I saw this Epiphone Hummingbird first. I know Epiphone is like the poor man's Gibson so I figured I'd try it out and see if I like it before shelling out the big bucks. I now have zero intentions of shelling out those big numbers because to me, this guitar is perfect. I will probably never purchase another guitar for as long as I have the pleasure of owning this one. I have found my soul mate. My one true love and this guitar is she. The guitar arrived ahead of schedule and I live in Bermuda, meaning the guitar first has to be shipped to New York and then shipped again to Bermuda AND (like a normal post office) it usually takes Bermuda two or three weeks to figure out how to get the package from the airport to the city (a 20 minute drive). Never-the-less, it arrived well before time and it was packaged very well (double boxed and padded with extra cardboard and bubble wrap). I was surprised that it was already in tune and playable right out of the box. I expected it to be tuned down so the strings wouldn't be so tight for the trip but it was tuned (and perfectly to standard tuning I might add) right from go. I've had it for a few days now and I just can't seem to put it down. I don't want to put it down. In fact, she is sitting next to me right now as I type this review. If you are looking for an excellent bargain of quality for price, this is it. I highly recommend this guitar to everyone. I would give it a million stars if Amazon didn't limit me to only 5. Actually, I'm not even going to recommend it, I'm going to tell you to buy it (straight up).

I own a few laptops for doing audio production and deejaying on-location.  The UCA-222 interface acts as an external sound card without dealing with 1/8" connectors and the typically noisy on-board sound cards in laptops.  Once I connect the UCA-222 via USB, the computer recognizes it after a few seconds.  IMPORTANT!  You MUST reconfigure any audio players or software to be routed through the UCA-222!!!  Once you do, the difference is incredible.
I own three UCA-222's and they are reliable and have never failed me.  I've never used the optical connection.  However, the input/outputs...even though they are unbalanced RCA connectors....are dependable.  NO noise floor....ultra quiet!  It has an on-board headphone connector and volume control, but I never use it.  I connect the laptop to the UCA-222 via USB.  Then connect RCA cables from it to the mixer.  Clean, line level audio.
These are good heads. I have played them on several drum sets and have been pleased with their sound, look and feel. This is a super solid price too.

Updated Review:

I bought a pair of these bridges for my Squier jazz basses. They are well made and much heavier and more solid than the stock bridge. I've installed both of the bridges and encountered the following notable issues.

1. The screw holes do NOT lineup exactly with the stock bridge. That being said, I still managed to get the bridges installed without drilling new holes. I lined 3 of the holes up exactly and was able to get the outer 2 to screw in.

2. The saddle screws are cheap. With the bass up to pitch, the threads will skip if you tighten them. I had to loosen the strings, taking all tension off the saddle, carefully screw in the screws, then bring the bass back up to pitch. Not ideal, but it works.

Overall I am pleased with the purchase. It's a sub $20 bridge. So if you consider the price it's a great value.

It only operates with the batteries, but the original set I have are still going after weeks of use. It's small size allows for keeping it in the case for my bass, then either headphones or ear buds will work. It takes a normal 1/8" mini jack plug; the 1/4" is only for the instrument.  Highly recommend for anyone who wants to practice anywhere without worry of bothering anyone, or need to carry around a small practice amp.  My bass is passive only, so needing a powered bass is not necessary. I haven't tried the aux in, which is also a mini jack.

I have had lots of ukuleles over the years.  Everything from standards to baritones. Everything from laminate to solid acacia and solid koa Kamakas.  This Cordoba Baritone is one nice looking and sounding baritone. The best I can determine is that the top is solid mahogany (really beautiful) with a matte finish (a very light satin-which I love) and laminated mahogany sides and back. The nut and saddle are some kind of plastic and not bone (which you may read somewhere).  The tuners are just average but do have a big tuning ratio so you can get the exact note you are looking for.  The ukulele comes with a better than average gig bag. I bought this baritone to use it as a big standard tuning ukulele. In order to do this I removed the strings and replaced them with some Aquila re-entrent Aquila strings (ANBP).  These new strings are all nylon and have no steel windings as does the original strings. So now I still get the ukey sound (g-c-e-a) and can use standard ukulele tuning and ukulele chord formations. This baritone comes with standard guitar tuning (d-g-b-e) so your chords are the same as guitar chords minus the two bass strings.  What I wanted was a big projection ukulele sound with the bigger size frame....... It's perfect. I have read elsewhere where the quality of the Cordoba ukuleles vary from one to another, so you may have to check around to get the one you are happy with, but mine came to me perfect in every way... Good luck to you also.

As the Mad Magazine parody of Rudyard Kipling's "If" went (or something close to it): If you can keep your head while others about you are losing theirs and blaming it on you.,,then you probably don't understand the situation.

When 0 out of 6 say that my review was not helpful, I have to ask myself why.  I think I know, the answer, but I'll stay with my original review.

I recorded me on guitar and vocals with both this mic and my laptop's built-in mic.  I sent it to a musician friend (who's now doing some tv production) and he had a difficult time distinguishing between them.  So, my rating is based on using the mic for this particular purpose. I'm trying hard to remember which laptop I used. It was probably my Asus A202E.

This mic may prove outstanding in other situations, but this was my experience for recording me and guitar.  Quite frankly, I would have reported the results whichever way they went and I was shocked that they were so close. So, I'll live with the 0 of 6. If readers find this experience unhelpful, then so be it.  However, those buying this mic to record guitar and vocal might repeat my experiment to see what happens in their cases.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I'm at a complete loss for how many stars to give.

I purchased this mic to record me--acoustic guitar and vocals.  The mic installed with no issue than taking a few minutes to locate and install the proper drivers. I recorded something.  It sounded fine. I wanted to see how much better it was than my laptop's built-in mic, so I recorded the same clip by using my Asus B23E's built in mic.

The two clips sound different, but my ears don't prefer one over the other. The AT2020USB+ is a cartiod mic.  It records what's in front of it.  So does my laptop.

So, how many stars do I award?  It's not that the AT2020 sound bad. It's that the current state of microphone design has these little built-in mics sounding so good.

This review is based on a particular application that is not terribly demanding. Perhaps serious differences would be immediately apparent in other situations.  However, I find no reason to keep it to record my voice with acoustic guitar accompaniment when my laptop does so well.

For what it's worth, I sent the two clips to a friend telling him what they were (AT and laptop) asking him to guess which was which.  He got it right, BUT he wrote, "The first one seems to have better high frequency response, but it took listening multiple times, finally with headphones (I know they say don't do that but it is easier for me)." So, it isn't just me.
summary: No better than my laptop's built-in mic for acoustic guitar and vocal?!?!?!

reviewText:
Skill Level: Intermediate
Key purchased: G

This is one smooooooth harp! Both in ease of playing & its overall feel & appearance.
One of the more weighty diatonics, it just feels good in one's hand... Just enough heft... very solid.

Quite airtight. Bends fairly easily.

I also own Suzuki Manji harps, and in comparison (tonality being subjective, of course): this is a "cleaner", more "pure", focused-sounding harp. While not equal-tuned, I prefer to play it for music one usually associates w/equal-tuned harps: melodic pop-rock, lead style, even classical pieces.
I think of this Promaster as the more formal, luxury, richter-tuned version of the Suzuki Olive (Manji's equal-tuned "sister").

The Manji (with its wide open back & side openings) sounds louder, with an "organic" tone, better suited to gritty, blues music (it's intended purpose).
Manjis feel "looser" to play -to me- while Promasters have a stiffer feel... not in a negative way, but I think of it as a controlled, "formal" sound/feel.

Since so many are familiar with Manjis, thought I'd use the comparison to help with this Promaster review.

The Promaster comes in a protective light grey hard shell, molded case with darker grey plush lining. It's curved shape is pleasing aesthetically and makes carrying this harp in one's bag or pocket very easy.

Overall, I'm very pleased with this harp... As I am with all Suzuki harmonicas. Can't go wrong with the fine, Japanese precision engineering and attention to detail.
Easy accessibility for cleaning & repairs, and replaceable reed-plates are a major plus. Price point for this high-quality instrument is appealing.

Thank you for reading,
-CC, Amazon Prime Member-Reviewer

reviewText:
Cello prices are very expensive in the DC area string shops, and many of them are Chinese made (professionally set-up).  My daughter's school orchestra teacher told us she needed to move up from her 1/2 (used) cello and I thought about the quest to find an affordable ($650) first cello for her, we actually drove hours to another state and had to puchase a bow.  If my child was a serious string player who practiced and played for the love of the instrument then I could see spending the money for the 3/4, however my child doesn't practice consistently and this isn't a full sized instrument.

The sound isn't as good as my child's 1/2, more muffled than clear, no ringing end notes.  We replaced the strings with pro-arte brand strings and noticed enhancement in the sound.  Good, not great sound enhancement.  The E string broke while the adult "helper" was tuning in chamber orchestra, the pegs are stiff and tricky like most new string instruments.

Tip, don't purchase the more expensive perlon core style (dominant) strings with this beast.

 I then purchased the prelude strings in the red package, now we are talking.  I had forgotten my own lesson with the first cello after we had first purchased it, get the heavy duty strings that last for students (and helpers) who are still learning to tune.  The sound is brighter with the new red pack of strings, you can hear the cello, especially since most students get the cheap strings that are "brighter" sounding for their violins that tend to drown out the few cellos.

The bridge is very thick and appears to be carved from a 2x4, however it gets the job done with little finesse.

Price is the selling point for this cello.  The price is right and it is able play after easy set up.  Sound is deep and mellow.

***I strenuously suggest getting better strings!, the ones included are more fishing line than cello strings.
summary: Great for the price-order better strings-ready to play

In my experience with many different types and qualities of instrument cables, I have found Mogami to be unparalleled in terms of their build quality, durability, near-silent operation, and seamless reproduction of my instrument's tone profile without coloration.  Prior to discovering this brand, I begrudgingly purchased Monster cables under the false assumption that they were better than anything else on the market.  Once I learned that one of my favorite guitarists uses these cables religiously, I decided to give Mogami a chance.

In short, doing so was the best decision I have made in building my collection of high-quality cables.  Performance-wise, these put Monster cables to shame with flawless sound reproduction and virtually silent handling.  With respect to reliability, these once again far outshine anything Monster or their competitors have to offer.  While I admittedly liked the fully gold-plated design of the Monster cables, I found the interface between the solid metal connector and the cable to be a weak point in the construction, and as such, needed to replace a single cable twice within the span of three years.  With Mogami cables, I have not once experienced an issue with build quality in the nearly 2 years I have owned this product.  The contacts are VERY heavy-duty and will hold up for years regardless of whether you're a bedroom studio audiophile like myself or a touring musician.

PROS:
1. Heavy duty construction with no obvious weak joints to fail unexpectedly
2. Crystal-clear sound transmission with minimal interference or handling-noise
3. Great durability, reliability, and quality

Cons:
1. These cables have a somewhat intimidating price-point; however, this is certainly a case of "you get what you pay for."
2. If you currently use transistor/solid-state equipment, you might not experience the full benefit of upgrading your cables beyond the "midrange" options available from other companies.  These cables truly shine when playing through valve state equipment or high quality studio gear.

Overall:
A must buy for any musican who is serious about every facet of their rig and is willing to shell out a bit of cash for truly outstanding gear.  Not advised, however, for those playing through entry-level equipment.  I hope all of you enjoy these cables as much as I do.
summary: Blows Monster out of the Water!

That being said - this is a real instrument, stays in tune, has accurate intonation, and has a deep mellow tone with a bright attack.  The fret ends are smooth and the neck is straight.

For around $100 this is a great buy.  By way of comparison, my other guitars are a custom made Campellone archtop, a custom William E. Moll Flattop, a Takamine Hirade classical, and a 1978 Fender Telecaster.

Very impressive compressor for the money, just the right amount of control and it makes a very noticeable difference on the higher gain channels.  The tone switch offers two distinct sounds and the independent tone knob allows for a wide range of options. Works great in series with the Donner noise killer gate mini-pedal!

This pedal was a solution to one long standing problem. gigging guitarists know the inner battle of carrying gear around : either u break your back carrying 50w amps & cabinets for the best tone, OR u compromise on tone by carrying some multifx processor which sounds like digital sht.
This baby solved every problem & brought pleasure to my ears. the distortion in this is really all analog tube tone, that fat & warm sound we all love from tube amps( far better than the options of some rubbish multifx). Ch1 gives me the whole range of low gain, sweetly overdriven jeff beck sounds to pretty rocking rhythm sounds at full gain. The warmth of the overdrive blew me away, it really responds to picking dynamics of passive pickups. The lead sound of my custom built guitar with john petrucci's liquifire pickups going thry ch1 is sheer heaven, that singing lead sound we all dream of.
Ch2 gives u enough gain to go all the way from dreamy long sustained lead sounds to somewhat aggressive metal rhythm sounds. Even at full gain, the sound is well rounded & musical. it does not become abrasive, it doesnt give u ear fatigue after a concert.
The 3 band EQ helps u shape the tone to your guitar quite well. its a very musical sounding EQ with no harsh or artifical cuts/boosts. The ISF is surely a gem of a feature : u can get the sound of a warm dark british amp as well as the modern tight sound of american amps, & even some interesting inbetween sounds. This means u won't get bored of this pedal anytime soon, there's tons of sounds to be explored in conjunction with the EQ. FINALLY, the most important feature for me is the cabinet simulator. It is really impressive & helps me get rid of carrying heavy amps around. I just add a reverb/delay in front of it & i can just vary the ISF to get a tight fender/mesa sound or the warm woody sound of marshalls. I even recorded a couple of songs with this & i must say that the cab simulator sounded even more accurate thru studio monitors. when playing rock rhythms, it even simulates the feeling of a cabinet pushing air with each palm muted chug ! Try adding a compressor before this unit & u can rockout a crowd with the tightest of crunching rhythms.
Finally, some people criticize the footswitches as being somewhat delicate : this may be somewhat true. the unit has never failed me until now but i do understand that they don't seem to be sturdy to jump around on top of it. but considering all the other incredible sounds from this baby, I don't want to nag about it. I'm pretty sure all kinds of guitarists(other than death metal) would love this unit once its explored fully.

reviewText: I just bought 72, which will probably be a lifetime supply as these babies never wear out! I love them and find the surface (for me) a better grip than Gator Grips or anything else I've tried. Plus, they are pink and the guys don't walk away with them!!! The finish of this guitar is high quality, it is basically flawless. This finish is highly resistant against scratches  . The electrical circuit is good and decent, no hums nor electrostatic noises while adjusting the knobs or switching the pickups. The pickups provide relatively  high output, enough to create some crunchy  clipping in clean channels with some amps. The timbre is suitable for blues , jazz and heavy rock.  Excellent sustain.  After a while i decided to change the pickups for more "acoustic" humbuckers that have less kilo ohms, (maybe less inductance) and slightly less output but more bright timbre,  this is just a matter of personal ever changing  tastes. I like the fact that this guitar only has two control knobs, which  makes it  a very simple, no-nonsense elegant and classy guitar ,  this is one of the reasons i decided for this Artcore model instead the most expensive ones

I had to invest some time in adjusting the string action, the nut and leveling the frets in order to get a easier to  play guitar and near perfect  intonation. But this is something you must do with 85% of the guitars on sale regardless of their price tag. Besides this, my only complain would be the tuners weren't smooth, which caused some problems and annoyances , but instead of buying new tuners,  all i had to do was to apply some wd-40 inside the tuners  to make them ultra smooth and precise like any other high quality tuners, so i just don't feel the need to buy new tuners at all, i simply don't. The tuning stability also improved with this . After this i don't see a reason to not use this guitar at professional level.

These are good times to get high quality and decent guitars at a very affordable price

reviewText:
This is what I've done to get the sound I like from my Hot Rod Deluxe II setup: first I replaced the combo's Special Eminence speaker with a Celestion Vintage 30. Big improvement - it sounds like the newer HRDs have a quality speaker already installed, so this may no longer be necessary.

Next I bought this extension cabinet. Again, big improvement. Far more balanced now from top to bottom, with tight, full bass. It really smooths out the rough edges, and provides a larger and deeper sound. The extension cabinet has transformed the HRD. Sonically it's now classy and big. Also a significant cosmetic improvement. The combo and the extension cabinet look great stacked.

In my opinion the extension cabinet is almost a must. Start out with the combo, but seriously consider adding this extension cabinet down the line.

This Hot Rod Deluxe setup now sounds pretty sophisticated, whether it's playing clean or being driven hard with drive/distortion. I'm impressed.

After buying one to make sure it fit on my K & M Heavy Duty Music Stand Regular Black, and then reading another review here where they mentioned having more than one hanger on their stand, I purchased a second as I play a concert uke and a banjolele. Now I can keep both of my ukes on the stand, and safer from being knocked around. Not only do these fit the K&M stand, but they also easily fit on the Gearlux Collapsible Orchestra Music Stand - Black, so when I won't be traveling for a bit I put them on the Gearlux and get two more instruments off of my floor. UPDATE just regarding stands-that-fit: I have had to replace my K&M traveling stand, and unfortunately these hangers do not fit on the bottom shaft of the Hola! HM-MS+ Professional Folding Orchestra Sheet Music Stand + Carrying bag. They do fit on the upper shaft, but the bottom shaft is so tall that unless you stand while playing it's going to be tricky if you are trying to change ukes quickly (like during a performance). I did glue a thick piece of leather to the inside of the 'rod' side to keep from scratching my stands, I'm surprised the manufacturer didn't put something there to protect the stand. And keep your eye on the plastic cover for the screw as they can fly off - I lost one right away. It does seem to take forever to tighten the screw on the skinny post so I usually leave them on the traveling stand though I have to remove the 'Y' part or the stand won't fit in it's bag. It would be awesome if the 'Y' could fold up, then I wouldn't have to deal with trying to screw them on when in a hurry while setting up. I also bought some clear tubing from Ace and put it on the legs of the K&M to protect the ukes getting dings from knocking into them, as I am usually sitting when playing so the ukes hang pretty low. Highly recommend! Update 12/2017: I have yet to have a problem with these ukulele hangers (other than the black cap has gone missing from one), and am going to buy a third to keep on my 'home' stand. I leave the first two on my traveling stand all the time now that I've been performing more - it's impossible to put them on/take them off quickly, either removing from the stand shaft or removing the hook. They keep the K&M stand from fitting in it's bag, but I'm going to make a wider bag so everything will fit.

Seriously people!  You could get a really nice powered speaker for 1/4 the cost of this.  This is marketing hype.  If you think it's great, then you have never used a modern high quality powered speaker like a QSC, Meyer, JBL, etc

First of all, this claims to be a line array.  A line array is designed to throw the sound farther, but they don't tell you that a line arrays ability to throw sound farther is limited by its length.  The bose is 87 which means its a line array to about 320Hz.  But what does that mean?

If you have the system dialed to sound good at one spot as you move closer, the bottom four octaves (20Hz to 320Hz) get louder.  However, as you move farther away those frequencies disappear.  The reason is that the line array phenomena is that it cuts the amount a sound decays in half as you move away.  However any sound lower in pitch than the frequency (2X the frequency whose wavelength is the length of the array) in this case 320Hz doesnt get that benefit.

Oh wait,  They say its easy to move  A 45lbs bass module, plus the 24 lbs power stand, plus the bottom half of the array at 18lbs and the top half of the array at 16 lbs totals to 103 lbs!  By comparison a traditional speaker stand (Ultimate Stand TS-90B $90) weighs 8lbs, and a QSC K8,10,and 12 1000W powered speaker weigh 27,32,or 41lbs.  Thats half as much!

So they are supposed to be really loud  According to their comparison system the L1 M2 with a B2 module produces 115dB continuous, and 121dB peak.  The same QSC K8,10&12s peak at 127,129,or 131Hz.  Remember folks every time you add 3dB is twice as much power, so the K8 is 4X as powerful and the K12 is over 8 times as powerful.

Then there is the cost  This system costs $3,198.00  For that you could buy a pair of K12s, Ultimate Stands, and a 8 Channel Touchmix mixer for  $2,680.00 and have a real PA for less money that weighs less.  JBL, and may others have similar systems.

I wrote this review because I am a musician who has a sound company.  I am forever tired of going to venues where they have this junk, and expect us to sound good.  I don't work for or receive anything from QSC, JBL, or anyone else here.  I just know what the professional companies use, and abuse day in and day out.  I own some K12s and love them.
summary: If you think this is great, you've never used a modern powered speaker.

I've been playing electric guitar on and off since the 60's.  After selling my previous guitar (a yamaha pacifica), I went to a music store and tried about 10 different guitars.  My criteria was that I wanted at least 22 frets, I wanted humbucker pickups that had coil tapping so I could get both that "strat" sound and the full Les Paul sound, a whammy/trem bar, and a really playable neck with no buzzing or octave intonation problems.  I tried LTD's, Ibanez, Fenders, PRS, BC Rich.  Initially, I liked the Paul Reed Smith SE custom ($719), but then I tried the Schecter Hellraiser.  The neck on this guitar was perfect.  Thin, easy to hold and play.  And 24 frets!  However, the Hellraiser was around $800 and I had wanted to keep the price around $500.  So I ordered the Schecter Omen 6 Extreme FR.  It plays great, the neck feels just like the Hellraiser, it has Schecter humbucker pickups with coil tapping, and that amazing Floyd Rose locking whammy bar.  I love this guitar.  While I usually play rock and roll, I spent a couple of hours today just playing clean chords with no distortion.  The sound is amazing on this guitar.  Very rich, deep tone.  And if you pull up on the tone control, the humbuckers go to single coil pickups and sound much like a strat.  I am so impressed by the playability of this guitar.  I have used the whammy bar over and over again, and the guitar just refuses to go out of tune.  Compared to a regular bridge system, where if you bend notes too hard you have to retune, this stays in tune seemingly no matter how crazy you get with your bends-because the strings are locked at the bridge and locked down at the nut at the head of the guitar.  Of course, if you crank up the gain on your amp, this thing will crunch with the best of them, and sustain even at fairly low volumes.  The finish on the guitar is impeccable, and stunning.  Even the tech who replaced my strings for me (I wanted lower gauge strings) complimented the finish on the body of the guitar.  I have not found a single problem or complaint with this guitar. It plays better than guitars costing twice as much. Highly recommended, especially for the price.
summary: Best electric in this price range

Before explaining my 3-star review, I should point out that I am a HUGE fan of the Vox Amplug devices overall, and own several from both generations of this product.  However, the Amplug2 Bass unit left me a bit disappointed due to some noise issues, and the lack of tonal variety compared to its guitar counterparts.

The underlying tone offered by the Amplug Bass is actually quite good.  It had a power low end response with my Squier P-Bass and sounded very full and robust through my Sennheiser HD280 headphones.  Whereas the guitar models have different drive and effects settings, the bass model offers a selection of rhythm patterns to play along with, plus 3 "gain" settings for "high, normal, and low" gain.  The front of the packaging promotes the device as offering "boost and compression" to aid the tone.

The rhythm patterns were decent enough, and I believe there is an AUX IN jack for jamming along to MP3 tracks.  There is a tempo adjustment too, which is a nice touch.

I struggled with this device in two key ways.  First, there was an almost unavoidable "hiss" on my unit, almost no matter what the setting.  Other users noticed that this gets worse if the tone or volume are turned up, but for me it was annoying at all times, and above and beyond what I had heard from the other Amplugs I own.  Is it possible that I have a bad device and other Amplug Bass models would be less noisy?  Sure.  But I do not have the ability as a reviewer to go buy 10 of them to compare and contrast - I have to evaluate the product as it was sold to me, unless it's just clearly broken/defective.  I assume all models have this issue to some degree, and it's unfortunate.

Second, the different "gain" settings were not what I expected.  These are more like difference in volume than in the level of sustain, dirt, or saturation.  I'm not sure I expected a full-on overdriven or "fuzz" sound offered by the Amplug, but why not?  Other Amplug models go from clean to dirty with chorus and delay effects.  I'm not very experienced with bass guitar, but the Amplug Bass seemed to offer one type of bass sound that you could make louder or quieter, and change the tone filter a little.  I expected a little more variety.

By contrast, Zoom makes a product (the B1on) for $50 that offers several different amp models, plus a suite of effects, a 30-second looper, and  more sophisticated drum patterns, and it can also be run on batteries.  The Amplug Bass is compact and powerful, but is too limited and has too many flaws to compare favorably with some of the other alternatives on the market now.
summary: Decent clean bass tone marred by excessive noise and limited tonal options

My DOD Gunslinger is made in the USA... and it's works fine without this product... but plug it in and yikes... ground buzz galore.

*Update*  6/25/2018... One plug in unit... very bad. I made a choke out of a guitar cable and used it as a patch cord in conjunction with an 8 foot ground rod and ground wire... separate from my electrical panels ground... and got rid of 99% of the hum and ground noise. reviewText:
If you sing for a living, you deserve a Beta 87. It captures every nuance, rasp and grain of your voice in live performance, on par with many studio mics costing as much or more. You don't have to baby it, it's built like a tank and performs flawlessly in any weather.

A built-in electronic bass roll-off circuit lets you set the EQ on your mixer once and forget it. The clarity and quality of your voice remain basically the same. No Bruce Banner when it's far away, no Incredible Hulk when it's close, it's always balanced, warm and clean.
To guarantee break-proof operation, Shure offers no switches of any kind on its wired mic line. So you should choose the pattern or circuitry you want by the model.

The Beta 87A is supercardioid (for venues or stages where the monitors are to your side)
The Beta 87C is cardioid (for club dates, bars or pickup bands, monitors are directly in front of you)
The SM87A  has no bass roll-off circuitry, it has a black casing so you know the difference.

Not to be obvious, but there's no reason to use this wonderful microphone unless the rest of your P.A. system or audio interface is of equal quality.
summary: Studio mic in your gig bag

Although I didn't purchase this amp through Amazon, because at the time the availability was several weeks, and I wasn't willing to wait. This amp was exactly what I had hoped for. I've owned Marshall JVM and Soldano SLO heads before, and I always had a hard time deciding which I liked the best. And I've had Line 6 heads. And innumerable combo Amps, solid state modeling and tube amps both. On the 100 watt Marshall and Soldano I always used the Marshall Power brake (input attenuator) so I could glow the tubes and not have the neighbors call the police. The DSL has a Pentode/Triode Switch on the back that in a way acts as a power brake, sorta. But it allows you to cut the amp back from 100 watt to 50 watt. So you can crank it up and still get that distinctive Marshall sound. I've had the amp almost a year now and I have really enjoyed it. The clean channel is pretty clean and crisp, with both Strats and Les Paul's, and The Dirty channel is pure Rock legend. This is a great amp. And I paid more than the $899.00 Amazon has it offered for. So if you've wanted a Marshall but couldn't afford one. Now is the time. This is a good deal.
Also check out the 1960 Cabinet to go with it. Amazon has it at $899.00 as well. Both are great buys.

Update: July 2016. the older these get, the sweeter they sound, just like the pickups on a vintage guitar. I have two of these now. Both are still rock solid. And sound phenomenal. And playing through the 1960 cabs, with the 4 Celestion speakers, even turned back to 50 watts, these are killer heads. Using just Classic gain on either channel, the sounds you'll get,  you won't need much in the way of pedals. I seldom use anything other than a Steve Vai Bad Horsie 2 pedal. Distortion and reverb on these amps is killer.

Nice weight, well machined, and a nice sustaining tone.  Not as heavy as some brass slides, but the tapered body is really what makes this slide special.  The taper seems to help when barring five or six strings, particularly when playing dead thumb bass, alternating bass or the like, I prefer this slide (and metal slides in general) for use with resophonic and acoustic guitars.

While the guitar had a good overall feel about it, once I plugged it in and started to play it, I was
as disappointed in it as so many others who just could not get by the dead pickups.
I like another reviewer was torn between a blacktop (at a lower price) and this guitar. The problem
with the blacktop, is that it had worse reviews than the 72.
This may all come down to personal preference, but the guitar was sent back.

From dealing with quite a few necks, these are not bad.  They're also not 200$?  So bearing that in mind here's some things to note.
 Classic shape decent maple, good level fretboard (hard maple) 10 mm standard tuner holes to fit standard modern sealed tuners, assembly is good, frets are medium, seated well but a little harsh on edges (just need a polish/touch-up) satin finish, standard top access one way truss.  Nut is plastic...(best to upgrade) but at least it has one. dot markers are flush nicely.
  The base/pocket end on these is 2.2 mm which is just over 2-3/16"  strat, just barely under on 2-14" not enough to shim. On 2-3/16" you'll have to sand a little, either body route or neck,but not much. Overall very pleased with these I've done 4-5 replacements with them all good.
Truss rods set at 0 tension so will need adjusting with string tension on it.
  Pretty easy to get a tint if you desire, tru-oil whatnot, even heard of brown shoe polish...the wood is sealed but not lacquered etc.  if you don't have a drill press (like me) check YouTube on how to drill neck holes as getting that right matters a lot.

These are absolutely fantastic.  They play very easily, highly recommended for a beginner, but for an advanced player such as myself, it's nice to have something I can pull out at a bar and play some drinking tunes on when I'm 7 pints in. It's easy to get nice clear sounding notes that are not squeaky.

Compared to metal whistles, these don't have much of any unpleasant overtones and it's easier to blow exceptionally clear notes without any warbles or squeaks.  The lower register sounds more dynamically even in comparison with the higher register, making this a very well balanced playing whistle.  Overall the sound is almost like a hybrid of a traditional whistle and a recorder, and gladly it doesn't sound exactly like a recorder.

The look is not traditional of course, but it is very nice.  Theses are lighter than a metal based whistle and feel good in my hands. The holes had a bit of plastic filaments left over from the factory, but this really didn't impact the sound and feel once I scraped them out of there.  It's obviously a cheap construction but it doesn't matter as the sound is absolutely not cheap to the ear.  The tuning capability is a really nice extra feature, and its nice to be able to take off the top piece for easier storage in a pocket.

Overall these are fantastic.  Beginners should absolutely go for these over any others. Advanced players can certainly use these in their collection, especially as their plastic construction makes them ideally suited for playing outside on a cold St. Patricks Day.  Also the case it comes with is fantastic.  It's a simple synthetic leatherish case with a zipper and three pockets in the inside for whistles.  I've never had a case for my whistles and this one allows me to store upwards of 4. So I can roll out with C, D, Eb, and F ensuring I can always play along. Only wish is that woodi made these in more keys, beyond that I can't ask for anything more.
summary: Incredible whistles at a great price

My one and only real complaint is that the old can used to be metal, and the new can is cheap plastic. This is the entire reason I gave it 4 stars, and not 5.  While this seems like superficial complaint, there is a reason for it.  The plastic comes open easily and the lid has popped off a couple times bouncing around in my guitar case.  My concern is that the stick will dry out or it will just grease up stuff it doesn't need to be greasing up.  My can arrived with the lid popped off, so for several days it was bouncing around in the mail without a lid.
GHS, "Come on Man", don't ruin a good product with a crappy container.  A ziplock bag would actually be better.  I hope my old metal can turns up around here somewhere, because the new stick will go into the old can.

These are my favorite Fender pickups. I'm a huge single coil fan. These Tex Mex pups came stock in a Fender Road Worn Start I got in a CL trade for my '72 Deluxe reissue Fender Tele. The Tex Mex have a cool Americana sound. They are a little hotter (not high output or anything to do with heavy metal!)  than traditional '50s Fender single coils. The bridge has more output and that's my favorite position. I love the raw quality and great clarity these pups have. I can spot the Tex Mex sound anywhere. I can't say the same for any of the other dozen Fender guitars I have own. These pups are inexpensive and that's punk. SRV's brother, Jimmie Ray Vaughan, has his own Fender MIM signature guitar with these. He uses the guitars straight from the factory and doesn't use effects. I think that's a great endorsement of this product. GREAT PICKUPS... No matter the cost! I have American Fenders that are 2x or 3x the price of my Road Worn w/ the Tex Mex and the Road Worn is the last guitar I'd ever sell! P.S.  these pickups sound the same in both urethane and nitrocellulose guitars. Try them if you like classic raw Rock&Roll sound!

reviewText: Gave as gift

The lowdown: This pedal is very solidly constructed and does exactly what it says on the tin. If you need some dynamic Marshall crunch in a floorboard friendly package to add some zazzle to your amp, here you go.

A little more than you need to know maybe: For the last several years my primary amp has been a Marshall Haze 40 tube amp. The Haze has a nice clean channel (if a bit overly bright) but a really muddy OD channel and a significant volume drop when switching from clean to OD and volume spike when switching from OD to clean. Playing with the knobs, etc., I can overcome some of those issues and switch channels without completely changing volume and tone to a distracting degree, but it takes some serious work. So I borrowed the Dirty Little Secret to see if it could help me with that problem. My thinking is that throwing a Marshall in a box in front of the clean channel would allow me to keep the basic volume and tone of the clean channel and then hit the box and get the same good crunch I would out of the OD channel. And the Dirty Little Secret almost completely delivered that promise. The crunch is 95% as good as the natural OD channel when I have it dialed in right on the amp. But there was a certain solid-state sterility that crept in when I'd hit it. That's the reason for just one star shy of 5.

This pedal is built like a tank and the sound is 95% there. I doubt it would warm up a solid-state amp and it added a little sterility to my tube amp. The difference is close to the "only dogs will hear it" territory. But it's there. And I think it's almost worth noting because the Dirty Little Secret has a lot of competition that gets you 80% there for half the cost or less. Is 95% vs 80% worth that price difference to you?

PS. Total side note: I've become nearly allergic to music gear marketing departments' obsession with the dang volume knob on your guitar. I swear everything from dirt boxes to tuners to killswitches "clean right up with your volume knob." There are reasons to want dynamics in your playing, yes. But if music marketing departments are to be believed, everyone's just running around fiddling with their volume knobs constantly.
summary: Does What It Says But Not Actually A Tube Amp

I bought this Capo as my very first Capo as I started learning Guitar since July 2014.  Did extensive research and found this stylish and many good reviews.  Now after about 5 months of practice, I feel this Capo is good to some extent as it is impressive and eye catching. But But......

I didn't like it that much as it is pretty inefficient if used on the first fret.  String A & B buzzes a lot.  I have to re-adjust capo close to metal fret, then far away, mid way and somehow I do get a position where strings dont' buz, but when I start playing guitar, they somehow start to buzz again. Real disappointment there.

Also, when I press this capo on the string with my hands and strum then there is no buzzing at all.  The moment I let go and strum, then strings start to buzz again.

Conclusion: this is a very nice goodlooking, eye catching, impressive-stylish Capo, but it doesn't have that "required" press on the string if used on the first fret.  It seems okay to be working on second fret and other ones BUT NOT on FIRST FRET.  Why its a disappointment as I really needed it for the first fret play as my favorite song is played with Capo on first fret.
It is good but not good.  Why waste so much of money when it is not doing it's job on the first fret?

reviewText:
I own lots of battery powered amps because I played charity concerts at beach in Thailand (no power, eh?). In my collection I have Roland microcube, cube RX, cube street; Vox Mini 3 and DA-7, Yamaha VA10 and THR10. And many 9 volt super minis for fun. The only one better is the the THR 10 as far as sound quality goes, but it costs 3 times as much.
 There was a complaint about no Ableton lite, but since I already had the Mustang 1 it didn't matter to me. The mini 7 has plenty of volume, plenty of range of the 24 programmable choices (Yamaha has 5). Yamaha is better for acoustic electrics. Not tons of bottom end, but more intuitive, more on the go adjustable and save, more for performance some place rather than the "stay at home" feel the Yamaha has. And you can add a foot switch to change between 2 programs if you wish.
 I am not into metal and all that. Hendrix is as far as I go. It does have some very fine Fender amp simulations which you can tweak 7 ways to Sunday, and the Twin Reverb is tasty.
 Guitars I have run thru it include Guild Starfires, Fender Teles, Reverend 6 guns, Ibanez jazz box, Parker, Ovation VXT. Acoustics: Breedlove, Larrivie, Tacoma, Crafter etc. Pretty broad spectrum, and all sound good, or better than other choices in small amps. The Roland RX is quite nice, but heavy and again almost 3x the price.
 It will not sound as good as a regular size Fender twin. Duh. But for what it is, it is brilliant. And the price is ridiculously low for what you get. Mustang 1 is better, but try hauling that to the beach!
Rich clean, sustained and definited sound either sub or over octave

reviewText: Bought this for an extra unit to keep in an extra bass case for jams. Very bare bones. Accuracy seems decent, but since it doesn't have a chromatic mode, you can't use it to check intonation or do anything fancy.

My 7th grader is in his second year of playing trumpet and after getting soaked for a year by the local music store for a 2nd class rental instrument I figured that I'd have a go with this Mendini instrument. It cost about 6 months worth of rental fees and since we own it the "pride of ownership" motivates my son to take good care of it.

Overall, it is a beginning student trumpet so don't expect it to last 50 years. The valves have plastic carriers so you know that they'll get brittle over time. Still, if this trumpet makes it into the last 2 years of high school I think it'll have done well by us.

The finish (Nickel) is nice and easy to keep bright. It has a nice, bright tone until you really wail on the the high notes, at which time you might notice a little buzzing. Since most students can't punch up the notes like an adult I don't think this is a concern. The valves needed a little breaking in but are otherwise quick and accurate enough.

The accouterments are all decent enough; the case is basically a formed foam block with a nylon carrier. It's nicely lined on the inside and protects the instrument. There's not much room in the outer pockets so you'll have to carry your music books in your backpacks, kids.

If you've got a kid just getting started (or maybe you want to pick up the trumpet) then this is not a bad way to go. Expect to move on once you start booking gigs though.
summary: Buy one of these instead of renting!

reviewText:
I have a Makida cordless I use over and over to not only install, but to set up an even torque to start tuning. Mine has a high and low speed.
Step 1: I set to the lowest setting and use a star pattern to seat the head.
Step 2: Raise torque to 2 or three and repeat until you hit you desired pitch. I use a lower speed for this. Tap each point to double check the pitch as you may have a tight thread.
Step 3: Bottom or resonant heads are often thinner and don't require as much toque. Repeat from step one until you hit the desired tension. Some drummers match the pitch, others raise or lower it a 3rd from the batter side.
***Snare resonant heads are a different animal. Set your top head pitch and dial in the bottom to the tone or snare response you desire: flat, crisp,fat,etc.
summary: Use with a VARIABLE TOUQUE drill.

This bass is simply flawless.  I must confess I was kind of hesitant to buy a bass online sight unseen.  But I had an Amazon gift card so I figured I'd take a chance.  I didn't expect Fender USA quality at at this price range, but wow, you'd be hard pressed to tell the difference with this bass!  I've been playing for many years, and I have expensive American made instruments that sadly do not have as good a "fit & finish" as this inexpensive Squire bass.  Maybe I got lucky and got a rare "good one"  but I was blown away at how well this bass was put together.  Some observations:

1. No dings or finish flaws.

2. Neck is straight with a nice amount of relief out of the box  (.012" as per Fender specs)

3. Frets are polished smooth and level with no sharp fret ends!

4. String action/height out of box was a tad high (About 1/32nd above Fender's "recommend" specs)

5. No fret buzz whatsoever, even after lowering action.

6. Tuning keys seem to be of pretty good quality.

7. Sounds great and plays like butter!

 If I had to nitpick, my one complaint would be the volume and tone pots.  They  work just fine but "feel" a bit on the chintzy side.  But at this price, I am not complaining.  Ultimately, this bass is an awesome value that (to me) feels and plays just as well as an Fender Am Std.

If you're just looking for a strap button to screw in to your kids guitar these are perfectly fine as long as you'll be drilling the hole.  I bought a used Bullet Strat and it was missing a strap button so I ordered these because the price was right.  Unfortunately the screws are too small.  I was still able to use the button, but had to scrounge through my drawers looking for a suitable sized screw.  Also, the black finish was worn off of one in a few spots, it almost looked used.  It gets the job done though now that I found the right screw size.  So to summarize, if you've got a lightweight guitar and you plan on drilling the hole, or if you have plenty of spare screws that you can use but you don't have a strap button, these will get the job done cheap.  If you want a nice button and don't want to drill a hole or look for a proper screw, pay a little more and get something else.
summary: Tiny screws, poor finish, but still usable if you have your own screws.

reviewText: The only strings I use for my electric. They work well.

We had 20 and 25-foot XLR cables for our 4-mic system, but really only needed...about 6 feet. These were perfect:  6 feet including the connectors. They are difficult to tangle as the jackets allow for flexibility.

The first orange cable we received was torn in spots - bare wire exposed - and the connectors looked like they had been run over by a truck. We received a replacement that was perfect. Also, all of these cables come packaged inside a plastic zip-locked bag. But the first bad one was missing the bag. I suspect it was a warehouse/storage issue and had nothing to do with LyxPro. ALL of the other 5 cables - 4 colored for mics and 2 for speakers - were prefect.

Not sure, but our mixer and speakers allow us to up the volume a bit without overloading. It could be a result of the cables! So far, so great. We've only used them once so far, so durability is to be determined, but I'm betting they're going to last for years.

The fit is slightly tight, but in my opinion, that makes them more stable.

I would highly recommend these as an alternative to the more expensive ones on the market.
summary: Good quality, inexpensive, tight-fitting connections, tangle-resistant mic cables in nice colors - great!

I returned this. I read a review but realize now that you must consider the source. It was an awful instrument. If you are a musician..to any degree, do not buy this.

This would have been a great instrument - even spectacular - if the intonation wasn't such an issue. I was getting at least 10 cents sharp on each string with the fretted 12th note versus the harmonic. The C string was actually 30 cents sharp on the attack which I've never even seen before. The fretboard starts to change direction after meeting the body like a previous reviewer mentioned. That didn't seem to effect the intonation as much but who knows.

If the intonation was good I would have kept it because it sounds great, looks great, plays OK, tuners are good. It has a woody, mellow, but still present sound.

What a shame that these kind of instruments vary SO much in quality. I will say at the very least none of the frets were buzzing...
summary: Otherwise fantastic instrument ruined by intonation (10-30 cents sharp)

reviewText: just what I needed

This was the first shock-mount that I had ever purchased. I did a -lot- of searching for what would best be used with my AT2020 (USB) microphone and I was very happy that this was what I ended up getting. It sustained quite a few years and the issues that came up with it felt fitting for how long it lasted.

Pros:
The metal rings/bars that make up the main structure are sturdy and didn't present any type of bending/breaking.
The firmness of the threading into the microphone was fantastic. I didn't experience anything shaking or dropping of the microphone once it was tightened and in place.
This item lasted far longer than I thought. None of the components experience any major problems that made it unusable even after 2-3 years of consistently being used.

Cons:
After about 2-3 years one of the bars welded to the outer ring came off. This didn't really impact its usage, but it seemed fair for how long it lasted.
The elastic bands had weakened over time. The microphone was almost always sitting at the same angle and started drooping. Although, this was still supported and didn't seem to have any negative impact on shock absorption.
summary: This is a fanstastic shock-mount for the AT2020. The cost is worth the quality.

This was one of my first throw down PA systems i bought. It is a tough little package to be sure - it's taken some abuse over the last five years.
Why not a Five Star?
The 1/4 inch cables are not well shielded. The cables will pick up interference and it will wind up in your speaker. Use XLR and 1/4-xlr adaptors.
The mic. I hope they threw it in for free (but I doubt it) Spend $55-60 and get a better mic.
The speaker pole mounts are plastic. A freelancer slammed a speaker on the stand and it rammed right through the insides of the unit (TG it missed vital organs). I got metal mounts to replace the plastic mounts.
With that said: they've been in the rain, in the heat, in the cold, in the van, at small weddings and near violent protest rallies ... and the package just keeps on going. Outside of the cables, cheap mic and speaker mounts I'm pleased.

Gain knob for channel 1 is very loose, unlike other knobs. 1/4" inputs are too close together for some cable sizes, which limits what you can plug-in.

Only channel one contains the pre-amp, it does not apply to channels 2/3 and 4/5, even though it says it accepts unbalanced inputs for those channels, they are line-level only.

I do my research before purchasing and this needs to be clearly stated on Amazon. Also, too much noise on the pre-amp for my taste, I was looking for a clean channel boost. I either I got a lemon or expecting too much from this unit.
summary: Please note: Only Channel 1 (mono) is amplified

I am OK with paying more for a good product. Unfortunately, I kept reading mediocre or just plain bad reviews for name brand volume pedals. Strings breaking (why, in the 21st century, would anybody have a pedal that operates with a PIECE OF STRING?), volume pedals that do not fully turn off the volume, and on and on. Finally I decided that I didn't want to pay $100 plus for something that wasn't guaranteed to do what it's supposed to do, and I started looking at the non-name brands. This appealed to me because it was $20. The Quik Lok pedal arrived a few days later.

It does exactly what it's supposed to do. It turns the volume all the way off, and once you press it down, it's all the way on. There is no "tone suck" because it's completely passive. It's a potentiometer that's operated by a treadle mechanism with an in and an out jack. That's it.

The pedal is smooth, the volume control is accurate, and essentially it does exactly what a volume pedal is supposed to do for about $50 to $80 dollars less than the name brands cost. Drawbacks? If any, the fact that it's mostly made of (very dense) plastic may make some people crazy. It doesn't bother me because I'm not 14, nor am I Trent Reznor, and I don't feel the need to destroy my equipment every time I play. It works fine and it's sturdy enough for normal people to use.

For my purposes, it is excellent. This is something I use to create loops and do layering, and it is excellent for fading the guitar in and out and getting rid of the pick attack. It's opened up some new doors for me and I'm definitely pleased with it.
summary: A basic, good, no nonsense volume pedal that does what it's supposed to do

Previously I was running a firewire solo with Cubase SE3 on a system with 2gb RAM and a P4 2.8Ghz with a 64Mb video card. Recording was flawless, and Native Instruments plugins were zero latency. Ran about 16 tracks audio and, say 8 tracks MIDI. SE3 worked well. Got a budget laptop HP G series with a 2.3 dual core cpu. No firewire ports (whats up with diminishing firewire support?!! Bring it back to the Laptop please!!). So I thought I'd get an Audiogram 6. Seemed cool. USB 1.1 (2.0's are a bit  scant in supply). Came with Cubase AI 5. Cool! I'm a fan of Cubase. I did not like Cubase 5 because there were no MIDI effects, VSTs were cumbersome to assign as it uses a different VST folder/version (better? Really? No). Yes you can assign a vst common folder, but you don't get full functionality with the VST plugin (like I hated with DirectX). Enough about Cubase for now. So, you get this budget laptop, with a budget mic, in a home (budget) studio, with a set of budget speakers/headphones (not budget for me. I'm picky about speakers and headphones.) My whole cabling is TRS or Mic (XLR). Am I going to expect awesome Professional Studio quality from a largely budget system? No. That said. I found this usb interface to be a lot of fun. I am very skilled at tweaking ASIO and achieving low latency while stripping out the issues that lead to clicks and pops. Ran VST Instruments with recorded audio and MIDI, and it worked well. My dual monitors flicker now and then (due to the audiogram). Set the priority to normal, and the latency to normal. When set to high, you get some pops and the latency improves by a whole 4ms (that's nothing! No improvement) If you run windows 7 64 bit (or any os for that matter) please install and use the Yamaha ASIO driver. I have toyed with trying ASIO4ALL driver, but my system is so far so good. I was blown away at the clarity recording from the mic! The on board compressor is very handy! Recorded voice with pauses to see if I could hear noise. Nope. Purely quiet. Don't be fooled by the small hissing in headphones when recording. That hiss is only routed to the headphones and does not appear on the recorded track, so crank it up and sing at whatever level (no need to back away from the mic at times). In sum, firewire is miles ahead of this usb 1.1 24 vs 16 bit for example, and a couple other things. I miss firewire, and plan to return to the FWsolo when I build my next desktop recording computer. For now, the Audiogram is a worthwhile replacement. It is simply irritating to have to fiddle with it to adjust to varying recording situations. Love the sound. AI 5? I went back to SE3. Much better (old, I know. Saving for Artist 6, but not sure if Audiogram 6 can handle Artist 6. Steinberg says it can). Hopefully I'll be back to Firewire by then. Are you a home budget musician recording your own music to enjoy? I would suggest this one. Are you a beginner to the whole ASIO tweaking thing? You may get frustrated. Cubase has been confusing for some ( I understand). I like Cubase (after spending a great deal of time learning how to setup and use it efficiently). Enough said.

This was purchased as a gift for an aspiring voice-over artist.  We've only begun to work with the microphone, but we like the construction of the microphone and we like what we have heard so far.

These strings are great. I have tried other brands but keep returning to these because they seem to feel the best especially when new. These strings keep their tonal clarity for a long time (I hit the strings hard) and the price cannot be beat.

Aside from the case, I've pretty much never used most of the stock accessories, but even given that the overall value of this kit is great. It is definitely not silent, but still quiet enough that I can practice without disturbing anyone in an adjacent room, even at night when others are sleeping... that said, your mileage will vary based on who you live with (or around, in the case of an apartment dweller). The only thing I really don't like about the violin itself is that the outputs from the pickups seem to be in mono, so when I try to use headphones to practice I only hear the processed signal in one ear, which just feels weird to me and makes me feel "off balance". If you use this for recording like I do that's remedied easily enough by recording the channel sound comes through on as a mono track then making it a stereo track with the same content in both channels. It also works well enough through an amp, which is a mono sound source anyway.

Three things that I did to make this a highly satisfactory setup overall was to get a different bow, install a set of Wittner fine-tune pegs, and pick up some rechargeable 9V batteries. I haven't been able to find some kind of headphone adapter that will handle the mono-to-stereo conversion for use while practicing, so if anyone who reads this knows of such a thing, please let me know. Otherwise, as stated earlier, this is a perfectly workable violin, and a great deal given the price (even after the other investments listed above).

I used to take piano when I was 4 until I was a teenager. I'm only getting back into learning now, and I decided I didn't want to spend too much money until I'm dedicated to piano again. This is perfect for a beginner. It's not going to teach you entirely how to play piano, but the lighted keys are fun for playing along with something complicated you wouldn't normally try. It doesn't work as great as I hoped, especially on "Waiting" mode. If you play in time with the song, the key does not register and you have to press it twice. I haven't found an option to mute the instructional playing and allow you to play alone with the background music. But you can always play without song mode and set your own background tempo. This keyboard does not teach you how to read sheet music, or anything about the notes, so don't expect that when buying the EZ-200. You need to purchase a book or take lessons if you can afford it. I love that the keyboard has a metronome, and you can change the tempo easily. Overall this is a nice keyboard to practice with while learning.

I have now put two of these tubes into tube microphones that I have modified.  In the quest for the best sound I can get, I have also spent much more money on a few NOS tubes.  After allowing days of burn-in and critical listening, I really wanted the NOS GE 12AY7 tubes I bought to sound better, but the plain fact is that these Electro-Harmonix 12AY7 tubes out-perform them in every way.  For a start, the EH tubes have a much lower noise level than NOS tubes I have tried.  Secondly, they just sound sweeter in this application.

In the past, the only other tubes I have used that match these for audio fidelity were milspec JAN Philips ECC88 (6DJ8) tubes, made in the 80's (different heater pinout, but similar in spec).  If you are wanting to replace the stock Chinese 12AX7 in a tube mic, these 12AY7's are a great option for a clean sound at a very reasonable price and will save you the trouble of finding a good NOS tube when many of them are of dubious quality.
summary: Better than many NOS tubes - Save yourself the money.

This is essentially a rebranded Laney Cub 12R with a spring reverb instead of digital and a different speaker.  Well worth the asking price! I've read that the sound really opens up if you plug this amp into a larger cab.  Also of note is the FX send and receive that are uncommon at this price point.

The downside, and the reason for the 4-star review instead of 5-stars, is the fit and finish from the factory in China.  There's a QC issue somewhere.  But for the money, I think it's worth the risk of receiving a dud.  You can always get a replacement.  I've had mine for about a month now and it's broken in nicely.

I bought a Dunlop medium/heavy assortment pack and zeroed in on these .88 green Tortex picks - they have a really nice feeling surface texture, and the .88 gauge makes individual notes ring beautifully.

I am going to try the lighter yellow gauge - if you are experimenting with picks, you should definitely check out Tortex.

Update 10/4/15

Tried out the yellow .73 gauge, and was surprised at the difference in sound vs. the green .88's.  The .73s  produces a more "trebley" sound, with a more pronounced click when striking the strings, which is not unpleasant!  Will be keeping a supply of both gauges handy.  :)

reviewText:
i ordered this whistle because its made in ireland. i love pennywhistles and up to now have mostly had english ones, so it seemed time to get an irish one.
it was a thrill when it arrived. whats not to love about a green fipple on a beautiful brushed-brass body . the overall quality is nice. the mouthpiece is not glued on so its fairly easy to adjust the tone (slightly). calling it "tunable" is a bit of a stretch, but "slightly adjustable" would be pretty accurate. going from lower to upper register and back is smooth and painless. the notes are crisp, with a fair amount of chiff. overall its a likeable whistle. the first one i got had a horrible buzzing sound in the low E and D notes, which would not cease. regardless of fingering, tuning, breath, etc. i pulled off the fipple and found no trace of plastic or metal bumps or snags to mess up the sound. i think it was just a lemon. i returned it and got a replacement and its seems fine.
the windway is pretty narrow which builds up moisture quicker. i have 2 clarke originals, 3 generations, 1 clarke celtic (sweet tone with celtic paintjob) and some no-name wooden whistles, and this is the only one i notice the issue with. its not a big deal, but you definitely have to blow the fipple out more with this than any of the others. that being said, it feels solid and well made. the larger finger holes make half-holing easier.

UPDATE:
now that ive had a chance to play it for a while, its evident that this whistle has a bit of a buzz on the lower E and D as well. not as bad as the first one , but its still there. its the only whistle i have ever played that does that. its tolerable but annoying. it may just be a quirk with feadog whistles. or maybe bad luck. comparing this to others, the clarke celtic whistle blows this one away. the sound is much cleaner, and moisture in the fipple isn't quite such a problem. i really want to like this whistle, but its nothing to write home about.

I evaluated this on the basis of making music demos using a professional DAW (Tracktion 3) on both a laptop and desktop. (I bought it for remote recording with my laptop.)

Regarding latency, the built-in audio interface responded to buffer settings in my DAW, with the default setting at 52mS. I was able to reduce the settings to about 20mS, which is still too large for real-time monitoring. However the "direct monitor" function on the mic worked fine and my DAW compensated the latency and lined the recording up correctly. On my laptop I had to run Tracktion's "auto-detect" function to set the latency compensation correctly. (You can confirm compensation by holding your monitoring headphones up to the mic to record the sound of your DAW's click track. When you zoom in, the recorded click track should fall within a millisecond or two of the beat markers.)

Regarding noise, I recorded myself speaking directly into the mic and compared against my usual recording chain (1" condenser/preamp/24 bit sound card). After matching levels, the G-track's noise measured only about 6 dB higher. However the character of the noise had a high-frequency emphasis which I think is an artifact of some USB mics. So subjectively I think you can expect about 12 dB worse signal to noise ratio compared with a professional condenser mic. The mic is probably not a good choice for recording quiet sources, but is ok for its intended use of close-miked vocals. You probably won't be bothered by noise recording loud instruments like drum or amped guitars. (Also note that the popular Shure SM57 dynamic mic also has significantly higher noise than the studio setup against which this comparison was made.)

Sound character was fine, though as with most condenser mics I like to apply a broad EQ peak around 1-2kHz to flatter vocals. The mic was not too sensitive to plosives -- as long as you hold the mic away at least 8". I'd recommend a pop filter or wind screen, homemade or otherwise. I didn't try it on guitar or other instruments, but suspect the high-frequency emphasis would work well for most applications. Anyway I'm a firm believer that a mic's character can easily be changed to suit your needs with EQ plugins. (But don't expect to magically gain the transparency and low distortion of high-end mics.)

The various switches and volume knobs are very useful and logical, the headphone jack is well-placed, and the mic has a nice heft and shape which feels comfortable in your hand. Solid little stand too. A surprisingly high-quality kit for the money.

Tube Swap is not as easy as it looks took out factory tube and put a 12AT7 Lower Gain Lower Noise Floor, in socket. had to remove top, bottom, and Rubber/Teflon board reinforcements (glued in place), removed knobs, depressed switches, to slide board assembly out, 2 addl screws to withdraw tube neoprene support, to access tube....Not difficult for the average tech but, seemingly could have been simpler. Nevertheless,  it sounds great, still warm even with a 12AT7.

This crash makes a perfect left or far right side crash/ride. As a crash it opens instantaneously with a lot of attack, then decays so quickly that there is almost no sustain. In fact, it sounds more like the crashing of a pair of marching cymbals.

Where this cymbal excels in my opinion is as a crash/ride. While I lament how thick and heavy cymbals have become over the years, that factor works in this model's favor. It has a beautiful ride would with a nice wash, and a gorgeous bell tone. In fact, the bell reminds me of some of the older Zildjian rides and crash rides I played back in the 1960s. So does the sound and the feel under my stick.

You can lay into this cymbal both as a crash or as a ride and coax some interesting sounds from it.  It's somewhat low pitched, which is unusual for a crash cymbal, but another point in the favor of using it as a ride. If I had to, this and a pair of hi-hats would get me through a low volume gig. That says a lot about this cymbal's versatility.

This is a really FUN piece of equipment. That said, it is NOT a toy, but truly a musical instrument in its own right (though you might disagree with me and that's okay).

All the faders and controls feel solid and the entire interface is about the size of two laptops, making it easy to travel with. I'm a guitarist and not a DJ, but I think a traveling DJ would find this to be a great piece of gear instead of hauling around huge turntables. The controls are also intuitive. I had this up and running in about an hour (including figuring everything out) - so the learning curve is not that high, which is cool.

All in all, I am having a great time with the DJControl. The "air" function is interesting and I actually prefer not to use it, but it certainly does not subtract from the ingenuity of this device. If anything, it adds to it. Five stars from me.

I play mostly acoustic guitar, and until now had used daddario exclusively on my steel and nylon stringed guitars. They had always sounded good and the company has a good range of strings to select from.

About a year ago I got a mid 70's Yairi dreadnought. The guitar had been played hard all these years and the top was open and it sounded warm and powerful. I realized that there would likely be a search involved to find just the right strings to make the most of this well worn beauty.

There were string gauge recommendations/limitations inthe soundhole of the guitar. Given the age of the top I wasn't going to exceed the limits. My normal dreadnought strings are Daddario EJ17's (13's, Mediums), but they were outside the limits. I tried EJ16's, the lights, but I felt the warmth was not what I had hoped. Older guitars often have this magic where you get fantastic projection without brittleness or strident tone. The EJ16's didn't bring out enough of the vintage character I felt the Yairi could provide.

So I began searching other manufacturers to see what was available. These strings were a very close match to the gauge limits so I ordered a pair. Just what I had hoped! Warmth coupled with projection. These strings were a perfect fit for my vintage Yairi.

I'll also mention that the B and high E strings feel unusually thin for their gauge...thinner than EJ16's. It's not bad, just a observation. They are every comfortable to play. You can really feel them under your fingers and they fret easily.

The downside to these strings are that their tone tends to fade more quickly than my others, hence a 1 star deduction. The sound is so good and they are reasonably priced...despite this flaw I'm sticking with the 2003's.

I've been using these strings for a year and I've never had a broken string. All the sets I've used in that time...about 10...have been uniformly excellent.

If, like me, you're on a search for a warm, smooth sound that still has projection and power (and you have the guitar top to facilitate this), give these a try. They are perfect for my old Yairi and I've had a positive introduction to Ernie Ball!
summary: Fantastic for my vintage dread...warm, full sound

I purchased a sampler pack of six different versions of the venerated Dunlop Jazz III pick. It came with the old red nylon, the textured carbon fiber, a green tortex, a black XL, and a regular and XL Ultex. I like the ease of picking and slippery release but not the tone of the red one, the tone of the carbon fiber but not the drag, nothing about the tortex one, and the size of the XL. The Ultex picks have the smooth weightless release of nylon, the tone of the black/carbon fiber with added "snap" or "tik" and are absolutely rigid, and the Ultex Jazz III XL is the perfect pick for me at the moment. I know it's for me because I forget I'm holding a pick, and just naturally hold it in the perfect spot where it stays without thinking about it. My accuracy and speed and dynamic range and power are all increased with this pick.

I have been trying a lot of different string brands lately and I think that I have settled on this brand and set as my personal favorite, but I haven't tried my Savarez 520's yet.  I am using an Antonio Arapicio guitar and am very impressed with the tone quality, volume, and pitch sensitivity that the Augustine Blue labels give me.  Volume is definitely stronger than my D'Addario composite strings.  With regards to pitch sensitivity, I struggled to keep intonation stable as I went higher on the fretboard with the treble strings when using the D'Addario composite strings and the Augustine Golds.  Now that I have tried the Augustine Blue Label I think I managed to find that perfect match for my favorite guitar and all of my intonation issues have gone away.

I only have two complaints about the product:

- The G string feels a little dead compared to the other strings (a common issue with nearly all strings in my opinion)
- The D string that was shipped with my second pack of Augustines was cut a way too short which created additional difficulty in stringing the guitar.  There was literally nothing left to trim when I was done stringing the D string. My other Augustine Gold strings did not have this problem so I suspect this was a one-time issue.

All in all, I am enjoying these strings.  Of course, just because they feel perfect for my guitar doesn't mean they are perfect for all guitars.
