reviewText:
I struggled with what kind of microphone to get to use with my video camera. This seemed expensive, but it is a great. The sound when mounted on the camera is far superior to the on-board camera microphones. What I like is that I can put it on a boom (no wire) record audio on the internal SD card.  So, it will plug into the camera and record from the microphone onto your camera video/audio.  Or, you can record a separate very clean track on the internal SD card, and then sync the audio. I recommend this microphone. Buy the add on "cats tail" windscreen.
If you have questions, feel free to ask. I will respond. I use this microphone a lot, in many different situations.
summary: Great Mic... I use it as wireless shotgun

reviewText: 5 years of abuse and they're still going strong. Can't argue with that. After a bunch of disappointments with Monster Cables and other brands, I've switched over all my daily-use cables over the years to Planet Waves cables, and I'm pretty happy with the way things are going. Haven't had one go on me yet.

It can be an octave divider (up to two up or down)
It can do parallel intervals (a la Trevor Rabin on Owner Of A Lonely Heart)
It can do intelligent harmonies (just make sure your guitar is IN TUNE so it can track your playing!)
It can do Digitech Whammy-esque divebombs (up or down)
It can do chorus-like detuning
It can do whammy bar flutter-copies
It's a BARGAIN
It's very welcome on my pedalboard

If it's what you're looking for (it's not Lexicon, it's not TC, nor does it profess to be) and you know how to use it you really can't go wrong.

Get one and have fun! Because it's not programmable I'm getting another.

Nice, large display.  Easy to operate and easy to see as you tune your instrument.  I use it for my hammered dulcimer and plug it into clip on plug that attaches to a bridge on the dulcimer.  A must for any stringed instrument (that you want to play in tune!).

The 215 Dunlop is precise and thick enough to have the weight needed
for clear tone. The straight tube style helps with intonation and full chords.
I like cut bottle glass slides as well but while the vibrato is faster when
go for it the 215 keeps you in tune with the other players.
summary: Glass slides are my first choice ...

I would buy this again and recommend to anyone who needs a Power Supply.

I have had my Hog 30 for several years, which I use with a SS Stewart's Sons open back banjo, modified with a Fishman pickup and carbon rod reinforced neck [for steel strings] to eliminate warping/note flattening.  It is fed through a LR Baggs Para Acoustic D.I. preamp to clean up some of the vibration related buzzing [notch filtered on A in my case.  Better sound in = better sound out with this amp.  What I haven't seen in other reviews is the mention that the amp runs off AC as well as battery, which allows a little more power and volume than battery power alone.

I use it mostly for open mic nights at a local outside venue on Hatteras Island [read frequent windy conditions]; from elevated stage it easily covers 50-75 feet out 160 degrees with more than sufficient volume at about 6.5/10 with the Baggs at 5/10.  And the Baggs allows me to control amp output where I sit, rather than at the Hog 30 controls.  Takes a little longer sound check to dial in at another venue, but I take notes on settings for future gigs.

In regards to the input jack issue, the rear input jack is primary and the front is an alternate.  If you plug in two devices, say mic in front and instrument in the rear, only the instrument sounds will be heard from the 8" speaker as there is no mixer circuit, strictly either/or.  I hoped otherwise when I purchased it, but it is what it is.  Works well as a single microphone/vocals /harmonica or acoustic instrument system/ PA system unit though.

reviewText:
This pedal is quality. The little screw on the bottom is very helpful if you happen to use batteries, which I don't, but I love that feature. Boss pedals have a similar design. The sound is incredible through my Randall RD5-H. I leave the drive on around 1 ish, tone on 0 and volume on 10 to boost my already overdriven amp. It's perfect. Has all the character of a TS you would want. The switches don't really matter with my amp overdriven but you can tell a difference in their sound when your playing through a clean amp and using the pedal for a light crunch. I suggest putting everything on 5 and exploring the sounds from there on clean. To noisey for those setting on a dirty amp though. This pedal is very solid and I'm just super stoked about it. It kills the sound of my ultimate drive, which is a really good pedal but it's more of a distortion pedal and it doesn't make my tone shine like this mad driver does. The mad driver is an actual overdrive though, so that helps a ton. Don't be on the fence about this or some other ts "clone" or ts itself. Save your money!

Cheers
summary: Exactly what I was hoping for.

reviewText:
I can't believe that I haven't reviewed this awesome pedal yet!

I started getting into guitar effects a little over a year ago and I've got a nice collection going, but I can't say enough good things about gear from TC Electronic, and this pedal is no exception. This pedal can give subtle phaser like tones to crazy sweeping jet like swirls. Like most of TC's other compact pedals, there are four knobs to dial in the effect you're looking for; this is a very versatile device. There is also a three way mini toggle that changes the voicing from "swooshy" and unpredictable to an emulated tape flange mode. The third position is enables the Tone Print settings.

I own the Corona Chorus and Flashback Delay (both from TC) and only recently began to experiment with the Tone Print feature, and while it's not the main selling point of these pedals, it is quite cool. For as simple as it is to dial in your own settings, the Tone Print makes it even simpler to apply presets that were created by TC with collaboration from some of their signature guitar players. It is a cool feature and I've found some great settings for all three pedals.

Like usual, I was in the market for a new pedal, compared a bunch of flangers and TC came out on top. Super versatile, virtually indestructible and great tone! You can't go wrong.

This is a really excellent, low noise microphone cable. My entire studio is currently wired up using this cable and GLS connectors. The signal through them is very clean and very quiet. I've made about 20 cables so far of varying length and still have plenty of cable left. Definitely the way to go if you need a lot of cables of different length and connector type.
summary: This is a really excellent, low noise microphone cable

reviewText: worked as intended

This is a phenomenal kit that makes the awesomeness of custom made pedal cables accessible to anyone.

The is a reason why custom made cables are preferred for a pedal board.  Depending on your pedals and layout the perfect amount of cable between pedals and the orientation of the jack is rarely the same.  this kit gives you the flexibility to achieve that perfect layout without having to go to all the work of buying the cable and jacks and then stripping and soldering the connections.  It additionally gives you all the tools you need to get the project complete including the wire cutter and screwdriver needed.

Some thoughts on the kit itself.
* Wire cutter.  Worked surprisingly well.  Built like a cigar clipper the cut that I get out of it was a LOT cleaner than the one I got from using my wire snips, something I totally did not expect.  Awesome.
* Screwdriver.  The weakest part of the kit as it is pretty cheap and a bit undersized for the screw heads.  No biggie as I have a ton of screwdrivers around the house and another fit perfectly.
* Cable.  On par with other cables I've gotten in the Planet Waves line.
* Jacks.  Very solid and obviously all L-shaped.
* Adjustable.  After putting together my first cable realized I had the orientation of the jacks misaligned.  Loosen the screw rotate and retighten and everything was ready to go.
Durability.  Well a pedal board isn't generally something that is torn down after every gig but the should last as long as you aren't constantly pulling on the cable.

Other thoughts:  I hope that Planet Waves releases some straight jacks as some of my pedals would be better off with those over L-shaped jacks.

Summary:
I can't recommend this kit enough if you are interested in looking at an easy way to clean up you board with custom cables.
summary: Better than pre-made pedal board cables.

reviewText: Pretty good construction.  Holds my condeser mic without a problem.

The main case is rigid aluminum. Two plastic side panels are held on with 3 screws each. The sides will probably break if the unit is dropped, but will withstand normal stomping. The flat bottom panel is a flat piece of steel that slides snuggly into grooves on the aluminum chassis. There are two strips of semi-firm rubber on the bottom which are a bit too smooth to prevent the switch for sliding around.

Inside the unit, the latching switches are SPDT (single-pole, double-throw) with the common lug and one side lug connected to the jack. The jack is a single TRS plastic panel mount component. One switch is connected to the TIP and the other to the RING. Some devices might expect a TRS plug for their switch inputs. Some will require two TS plugs. In the latter case, you will need a 1/4" stereo (TRS) to dual mono (TS) "Y" cable or the equivalent adapters to use both switches.

As a side note, the SPDT switches give you the option to wire them to a second SPDT momentary switch and have them work together. I just finished this mod and now have four buttons the top two are the original latching buttons and the lower two are momentary. The top switch reverses the state of the lower. It's useful when you want chose between making a temporary change or latching it on/off. If you want to know more about this mod, ask in the comments.

Overall, I'm satisfied with this product. For the price, it's fine.
summary: Let's open it up and have a look...

reviewText: The LR Baggs Anthem-SL is the best pickup.  I've had it in a D-28 since they released it.  I've used undersaddle pickups for a long time (for ease of use) and never cared for them.  I enjoyed condenser mics better especially recording if available, but there can be short comings at shows.  When the Anthem came out they really pushed the microphone like sound, and I decided to give a shot.  It does sound great, not quite 100% condenser quality, but far better than previous on board mics and undersaddle a I've tried in the past.  I haven't had feedback problems either which is usually a short coming with other pickups.  My only cons for the Anthem are: 1. It does dampen sound, though a small amount, it's enough to be a little frustrating.  2.  Battery pack inside the sound box, baggs and fishman both need to figure out a way to remove the battery from inside the sound box.  Either use a watch battery and make the unit easier to remove and reinstall or have some apparatus the connects to system by strap knob, tying pouch to strap.  Taylor's & Martins Aura systems with a bored out rear pin is the best but I have wondered about removing more wood being a negative aspect to resonance.  I also purchased the floor direct input pedal as baggs used it in all their promo videos, the two pieces together really do sound great and it's great to be able to use a battery in it for one less cord to have.

reviewText:
Without getting into the physics of strings, OK a bit, the wider a string is, the more tension it takes to tune it to a given pitch. If you tried to tune your [thinner] E string down to B [or even drop D], think about how 'loose' it stars to feel. If you play 5 string bass, that B string should be nice and wide, like these, that use a .135 B. Sets with thinner strings are OK, but will be at a lesser tension. This doesnt matter for some, is preferred by some, so your mileage may vary.

Great strings, not flippy floppy!!

To say that I merely like them now is an understatement.  I absolutely have to use them now!  I have discovered that after getting used to their size, they are the most comfortable and easy to use picks I've ever used.  They have really allowed my soloing to go to the next level.  Alternate and speed picking with these babies is an absolute breeze.  I would dare say they are quite likely one of the best kept secrets in lead guitar.  If you try them, use them almost exclusively for about a week and let your fingers get used to their size.  I don't think you will be disappointed.

I ordered this guitar "expecting" a 'telecaster' type and instead to my surprise they shipped me a "strat". I was a little frustrated because I already have two strats. BUT,  I decided to remove the plastic (which is a real pain btw) and try it out anyways. To my pleasant surprise it's by far the best sounding and highest quality strat I own. So I decided to keep it. I would have given them a 5 star rating but they should be more careful in the future to make sure they send me what I ordered. I contacted Amazon customer support and told them what happened and that I decided to keep this beautiful guitar  anyways but that I wanted to re-order again and asked them to make sure this time that it's the right one (they told me this is fulfilled by Amazon so someone can check it before it goes out.  Bottom line is you can't find a better strat for $89 and I believe that the Telecaster model will be just as good. I will review it after I get it. The strat model and rich deep tones through my G5. I was really impressed and as usual I read comments from other purchases in this section very closely and most are raving about this legacy guitar. Now I am actually glad that they messed up the first order. :-)  Buy this guitar!!

reviewText: These do exactly what they are supposed to do--hold your music.  Sometimes they get in the way of the notes, but they are clear so usually if you tweak their position, you can work around that; the lower part that clips to the stand will keep them from falling off if you have to wiggle them out of a flush-against-the-music position.  Minus one star for not fitting my Peak collapsable music stand, which has a thicker than normal tray. But they really are made for the Manhasset, so I probably shouldn't penalize for that! But I'm going to, since usually when I need these it is for an outdoor gig, to which I have brought my own portable stand, rather than a bulky metal Manhasset stand! Good product, serves it's purpose.  Awkward to store and transport because of their length and shape. I'm always afraid I'm going to break them in my gig bag. Better than my old alligator-clip style clips, which had to either clip at the top of the music (going down the page, like these), or on the side, holding horizontally.  I like that these clip at the bottom, and seem more secure. You can also clip thicker music with these because of how they attach to the ledge of the stand. I don't know if there is a better product available or not, but I want to leave room for the perfect music clip, so I'm sticking with three stars.

Picked up one of these for $50 new (had some coupons from guitar center).  Dropped it into my Marshall JCM2000 DSL401 (2002 model, so, prior to the heat fix), and... WOW.  The improvement is undeniable.  Smooth leads, crunchy riffage, classic British tone.  Simply put, buy one.

It's my first XLR mixer, and it's pretty good. The 1/4 inch Headphone out port has a lot of hiss and I can't seem to find the culprit. I'll contact the manufacturer to find out what it could be, but if you use it for feedback on how your mic sounds, expect a hiss in the background. The FX included are alright, but I don't have a use for them myself. I bought this with a Sennheiser E835 and it sounds a lot better than my Blue Snowball. Since it's a mixer, you have 4 controllable channels to mess with.
I have my Main mic on Channel 1 with the low cut filter engaged (which also supplies Phantom Power if your mic requires it) and a 1/8 to 1/4 inch adapter with a standard cable connected to a device such as my phone with the guitar switch engaged. I use this to spam MLG Airhorn effects whenever I win a round in CS: GO.
One thing the manual doesn't say to get this working is that you need three knobs turned on to get sound out of your mic: You need your channel gain knob engaged (item 4 on instructions sheet), channel volume (item 11), and the master volume (item 18). For line in on channel 2 from an external source such as from a guitar or tape deck, you need the guitar switch engaged and it's recommended that you don't increase the input gain, only the channel volume.
Overall, it's a pretty neat toy if you want to break into podcasting or something, and an XLR mic and this mixer combined during sales isn't more expensive than a USB mic such as the Yeti, but sounds better than one.
summary: and it's pretty good. The 1/4 inch Headphone out port has ...

reviewText: I really like this pedal. It has so many different drum grooves, styles and bass lines. It's great to practice with, especially as I live in a condo, and have to practice on headphones. Easy to use as well. I also get tired of playing to predicable jam tracks. Boring. The algorithms in this box keep changing the patterns up like a real rythym section would. I don't know about live use thought. I think you can only store three patterns. I don't think soloists playing live would like this.

My daughters clarinet had 2 cork joints that needed replacing and there is not a repair person nearby. So I took the leap and tried it myself. It was very easy to do. The most difficult part is sanding the joints. There are many tutorials online to do this repair so I did not use any of the directions included in the kit.  But just take your time and don't force your 2 pieces together to check your joint or else you will tear your new cork gasket. Just gently bring them together and if you see the joint start to get pushed down out of place stop and sand some more. You'll get it with patience.
summary: Easy to do, no more leaks.

reviewText:
The amount of plastic used in the construction of the mic gave me some serious concerns about its build quality. Not to mention the fact that it just felt a little funny in the hands. Once we were plugged in and running, however, it quickly became apparent that sound quality was not compromised, and I got over my tactile apprehensions.

The receiver can be rack mounted and includes the necessary rack adapters. While we were pumped to fill another void in our rack, we were a little disappointed when we realized that rack screws were not included.

Amazingly, not all wireless mics include a mute button. Thankfully, this one does. This simple addition provides an opportunity to avoid some potentially awkward hot-mic/feedback issues. On the topic of feedback, it is almost non-existent with the Concert 88; unless you're trying, of course. A lack of feedback is great, but good mic technique is also not necessarily rewarded. The mic appears to have been designed more for speaking engagements than singing. Having to sing almost directly into the mic for true representation does open the door to plosive issues. A foam wind screen is certainly recommended.

Unfortunately, the mic does not come with its own holder, and does not fit into any of the molded plastic holders that fit our other mics. We can use a spring loaded clamp holder, but even that is not a perfect solution. I find myself frequently holding the mic in my back pocket when not in use, which is obviously not ideal.

I do have some longevity concerns but, overall, I am pleased with the performance of the system at this price point. I would recommend it as a budget solution; particularly for speaking engagements.

reviewText: Bottom line:  It's good but, frustratingly, not $150 good. It's an improvement over built in DAC/mic but not a huge improvement. It's fine for speech and podcasts and YouTube videos, but not really good enough for a musician. It is noticeably noisy (hissy) even when the phone is in airplane mode. It has weak midrange and bass response, although it's tweakable in the MOTIV app up to a point. It is heavy and cumbersome unless you hold the phone in your hand or on a tripod. It won't work with many cases on. Zoom makes one that is at least as good for $30-40 less. Alesis and Rode make better ones. I am a Shure fan and own many wonderful Shure mics, but to be honest I expected a lot more for $150. This mic is not good enough to justify the price or to make me want to use it. Casual videographer and podcaster might find it sufficient. An iPhone really needs a full outboard DAC to record decently. This seems to share processing duties.
summary: Not $150 worth of mic, just ok.

I don't know anything about Turbosound speakers, and I haven't previously purchased anything by Bugera.  I have a little hybrid combo, a Kustom Contender that's 18w with an 8" speaker.  It actually sounds pretty good, but the 8" speaker really doesn't cut it.  Instead of shopping for a new amp I decided to try this amp with a speaker cab.  I went back and forth between this one and the Fender cab with a 12" Celestion.  I decided to save $40 and give this one a shot.  After a few months, I've got no complaints.  I can't find any faults with the build quality and the speaker sounds really great.  I have no issues whatsoever.  My little amp is giggable now, or if I want something louder I can get a little head - I'm thinking about one of the Quilter heads, which I've tried and really like.

Anyway, this thing is a great deal.  I went from feeling really disappointed with my practice amp sound at home to loving my guitar tone.  I tend to play clean and get my dirt from pedals.  I don't do high gain at all.  I play blues, alt-country, roots, reggae, rock, soul - a little of everything, almost.  I think this Turbosound speaker sounds great with clean, edge-of-breakup and mildly dirty tones.  The cabinet has plenty of bass response without getting woofy or boomy.  My rig sounds great with a strat, tele, jazzmaster and my Guild hollowbody.  Excellent stuff.

reviewText:
This Windsor violin is a great entry-level musical instrument for a grade school child wanting to learn to play the violin.  The look of this violin is definitely one of quality, with an attractive spruce top.  The violin also comes with a case and a bow.  I appreciate that this violin is available in different sizes as well, so one can choose a size that is perfect for their child.

We had little trouble tuning the violin for play using an app on our phone to insure each string was correct.  It literally tuned in less than 90 seconds.  I will note that this instrument does need to be tuned pretty frequently although some have told me that is typical for a new stringed instrument -- kind of like a break in period.

Bottom line is this is a great value for a beginner, to make sure someone is truly committed before spending more money on a higher quality instrument.

These are great modern production 12AX7's from Shuguang. GT buys them in bulk, tests them, prints their name on them and charges twice as much as the typical vendors.

This is a beast 10" guitar speaker! I had the opportunity to install this speaker in my 20 watt Fender Mustang 1 amp (with 8" to 10" speaker baffle mods) and it took my fun bedroom quite amp into a mind and (ear drum) blowing beast. It is the best Telecaster chickin pickin speaker I have found yet! I mostly play Brad Paisley stuff (Nails it!) with some Slash thrown in. The Fender Mustang I with this speaker is like having Dr. Z Maz 38 amp in your home office under your desk. Cleans are superb all the way up to 10. Chest caving bass, with a slight mid range bump. No flubbiness at all yet still smooth and not stiff. My favorite speaker yet and I have tried nearly all of them from Celestion and most from Eminence. Just know that this is a super LOUD speaker even with a 20 watt modeling amp with volume at 5 will chase you out of your house. Mustang 1 is Definitely gig-able with this speaker for a small hall or church. I ordered a Celestion Gold 10 for a benchmark comparison and will update my review after I get a chance to get the Gold broken in good. Make sure you break in the Ramrod on 8 with heavy bass for about 50 hours before you give it the real sound test. It warms up and bass fills in a lot after about 50 hours of beating. Its a little stiff out of the box but that's expected. Its a keeper! Buy it!

These are some of my favorite picks to use for heavy strumming on my acoustic. Honestly it all depends on the sound you're going for when you play. Thicker picks are going to sound more full but have less flexibility for difficult strumming patterns, and will be more accurate. Thinner picks will sound a lot thinner and more bright but less accuracy and attack. The Tortex picks are some of my favorites because of their durability. They last long and maintain their shape really well. They also have a great coating allowing for a steady grip on the pick. I use almost all gauges of these to some degree and even the Tortex Jazz 3 1.0 picks and Ultex 2.0's. By far my favorite pick brand on the market.

I have several Tusq nuts on most my guitars, all of which I`ve had to meticulously sand/test, sand/test(Fenders, `80 Guild, `70`s Yamaha), and I can CONFIRM that this nut fits the LTD "B" bass series AS IS. There`s like .25mm sticking out on each side that`s barely noticeable, and easily shaped if it bothers you. It didn`t bother me, I was just happy it just happened to be the exact height. The old one was a little thicker, and I think where the string rested was back a hair farther, but a dab of wood glue and a quick intonation and back playing it before the glue even set(yes, it held just fine). Stays in tune better, which I expected, but I just record with it. A worthwhile improvement.

1st, for the record I prefer NOS (new old stock) tubes. Back in the day 50's of everything using tubs the many huge factories had great competition and devoted huge resources in research and development and quality control.
Now that the world only has a few tube manufactures those lucky factories are now left with no competition and for the most part only guitar amps and esoteric  / vintage home and studio audio use tubes so tubes will never be as good as back in the day of analog past.
However the challenge associated with finding a quality 50-year-old tube is not for the faint of heart especially with stereo amplifiers that like matched tubes.

Enter the JJ...I am a home audio nut and fully embrace old tubes especially my vintage single ended class A amps that don't care if the tubes match but I find my beloved vintage Magnavox stereo amp that requires (4) El-84 tubes these JJ's work well and fit the bill.

The sound of the JJ in my Magnavox amp is close to NOS but I have the assurance that the tubes match.

I probably only have 100 hors or so on these JJ's so I do not know what kind of life I will get but so far so good.
I purchased this amp 2nd had loaded with China EL-84 and the JJ was a great improvement and did not kill my wallet.

If acquiring NOS is not practical for you then try the JJ as it is as good as it gets with a new production tube,

Recommended Product!
summary: Not NOS, but works good in old home audio amplifiers

Before I replaced the strings and this I recommend for all guitar when replacing strings is to
clean the frets and the wood of the fretboard; finally applying rub in) a nice coat of sweet almond oil or any fretboard conditioner which I leave on overnight. Next day lightly polish the fretboard - re-string and ...BAM!!! or rather Twang !!! a super great looking and sweet sounding guitar.
Then again it's just me and the way I like my guitars to be upgraded.
So...dont try this if you don't have experience with electronics but yes condition your fretboard.

I put these on my Dlx Players Strat but it wasn't a piece of cake. First problem... no instructions came with the package. Found a method done by another searching online. Served as a guide. Second, after removing the old Fender Tuners I noticed the new tuners didn't fit into the slots. This meant drilling out the holes by another 1/8 of an inch. Blue tape both sides as to prevent marring. Third, the new unit using a tightening center nut rather than screws to the headstock. There are also with two dimples. I used a ruler clamped to the headstock for keeping straight alignment and another clamp to press the dimples into the tock for drill bit placement. Then carefully drilled two holes per tuner. Take you time on all of this as not to damaged the finish on the headstock. These rest was simple. Install the tuners and tighten the nuts is now a breeze.  If you are not mechanically inclined then I strongly suggest you go to a Luthier as this is more than a simple replacement job. For the price you think they at least provide specs and some instructions.
summary: No instructions - your on your own

Some harmonicas are shipped within a display box, blister pack, or something like that. This one was just shipped in its plastic case. Plastic cases are vented. Air can get through, and dust. After a short time of playing, I noticed that I kept inhaling dust and who knows what else. Irritated my throat. Slightly odd taste. This might be a great harmonica. Some people really love it. I got a dusty one. Bleah. I really hope some vendors ship these within sealed boxes or other packaging.

I am very fortunate that Amazon granted me a refund. Most harmonica sellers don't do that. I reported the harmonica as defective... which, in my opinion, it was. I ordered 5 other harps in the same month, and didn't have any problems with them not being clean. In my opinion, an unclean harmonica is a defective harmonica.

So I got a refund. Thanks, Amazon, for that.

Compared to the other harmonicas I ordered.. various Hohner models and one made by Seydel, this one just felt really cheap. Not especially well-made. Like the Seydel Blues Session models, this one is ergonomic, and lots wider than most harps. Some folks might find the size and width to be uncomfortable at first. It will take some adjustment.

The Seydel I bought was a more expensive model than this one. I paid $60 for a Blues Session Steel. Bought one from Amazon. Big difference between the Seydel and the Suzuki, but that's to be expected, considering the large difference in price.

This Suzuki harp is meant to compete with the cheaper Blues Session Standard (not the Blues Session Steel) made by Seydel, and the Hohner Special 20. I don't know how it compares to the Blues Session Standard, since I don't own one. But, I do own a Special 20, and like the feel and tone of that one more than the Bluesmaster. Plus, the Special 20 was shipped in a display box, not just a plastic case, and was clean when I got it. No issues.

Maybe this is a great harp, but I'm not going to take the chance on ordering another one. I'll stick with Hohner and Seydel.

it performs well...however, the unit came obviously used in some way. the rubber cable protector at the termination end was broken off and the unit had smudges and a hasty wrapping job around the pop filter. while the unit performs well and seems stable, the issues above diminished my confidence and makes me question quality control and the ethics of selling a (what seems to be) used item at full price.

Normally, I love shure and their products have been excellent. This is the first time I've gotten a less than great experience. I understand that the rating here should only reflect the units quality, but the unit itself came broken and used, and quality control is a MAJOR part of a products assessment.

So, the unit feels strong, stable, lightweight, very bendable and malleable, but again, sturdy and strong. It sounds fantastic and will be perfect for many applications including violin, voice etc.

If you play something other than classical, it might not occur to you that you need this. But the next time you sit down to play, look at your right foot (if you're right-handed). Is it pointing down, instead of lying flat on the floor? Are you supporting the weight of your guitar body with the toe of your right foot instead of the whole foot? If so, the world won't come crashing down; I played like that for years and never thought about it. Still, wouldn't it be more comfortable to rest your foot on something? (And when something's convenient, maybe a stool or another piece of furniture, you probably do already.) This is my first foot rest, and probably my last, because it does exactly what I wanted. My only disappointment was the color. When I bought it, I thought the triangle in the middle of the big pad would be white. It's not. Now that I look at the photos again, I can see that this area is not actually white, just shiny.
summary: I played like that for years and never thought about it

reviewText: I am a retired senior and an active musician, I have played (traditional jazz) for many years and play several gigs every week, but I recently sustained an injury to my left thumb (overuse-playing banjo) and may need to change instruments so I am a beginning trombone player.  I am having fun with my new pbone, seems well designed, well constructed, very light weight, rugged and a good starting instrument for a beginner.  See U-Tube video clips with the pbone.  The pbone is not just a toy but also a fun, serious instrument with a decent tone at an economical price (I believe probably a better value and more durable than a 'lower-end' student brass trombone).  Pbone comes with a plastic mouthpiece (which I am still using), but you will likely want to buy a better metal mouthpiece later (~$30 & up) - there are many to choose from.  And now for the hard part...  you will need to choose which color for your pbone!

The Blues Bender is one of the best "under $20" harmonicas available. It can bend, has acceptable tone, gapping, and plays well out of the box. FAR superior to all of Hohner's many $10 harps (Bluesband, Piedmont, Azul, Hot Metal, Pocket Pal,...), the only other equally decent cheap harp is the Suzuki Folkmaster. The Suzuki is slimmer with a reedier sound that's quite nice, but the Blues Bender is smoother and more comfortable to my playing style.

Never ever by any harmonica cheaper than these two (each around $15), as they almost always arrive badly tuned and grow quickly worse.

However this inexpensive Hohner is respectable, fun, and makes a good 1st harp that can oblige a new player's burgeoning abuse and still deliver exciting sounds without falling apart.

They're also great beater harps to keep in a hot car or book bag without fretting over its fate.
summary: Perfectly good starter harp! Better than most similarly priced rivals!

I've had this for some months now and it seems to work just fine.  The sound is decent and it tracks discs well.  I like the mechanism for putting in a CD, it's a slot like I have in my car rather than a tray that pops out.  But the controls get on my nerves.  To skip to the next track you have to dial in the number of the next track and enter it or hit the button with the number of the next track--nothing like a simple "skip" button on the face of the player, though there is on the remote.  You can't eject a disc until you've first hit "stop" and given it time to digest that command.  If you're searching for something toward of the end of a track, you can't back into it by skipping to the next track and then hitting reverse, you have to go to the beginning of the track and hold the advance button through the whole track.  That's a pain if the track is more than a couple of minutes long.  I've never had a CD player that operated this way before.  Why Marantz does it this way, I'll never know. These seemed like minor points when I first got the unit, but they've started to get more noticeable.  On the whole it's a good unit, but the controls seem less than user-friendly.

The Donner Eternal Bind was exactly the delay I needed.  I originally was going to go for a pure and basic delay pedal, but wound up going with this because it seemed to have more features that I could potentially use (preparing for the future and all).  This more than met my expectations.

THE BUILD:
It's a built with a stable and durable metal casing.  The knobs are a fairly good plastic featuring both smoothed and notched pots.  I've played this thing for several weeks now doing long multi-hour sessions and this has still pulled me through.

THE TONE:
First off, when switched off, it does not manipulate the signal at all.  But when turned on it really does shine.  There are multiple delay-type effects (3-types of basic delays, a pan effect, a ping-pong effect, a basic modulator, and reverse delay) and I've found each one to be quite effective and nice...there's even three types of basic delays (Tape, Digital, Analog), and each sounds unique offering different things.

OTHER FEATURES:
In addition to the delays, it also has the ability to lock a setting once you dial it in by flipping the toggle.  Even if you unplug it, it still remembers the setting.  It also has a 40 second looper (it calls it "hold") where you can stack parts on.  There's also a tap delay feature: if you have it on any effect model except for "hold", just hold down the switch for 2 seconds then tap the delay speed...you can even hold it for 2 seconds more to go back to on/off mode while still keeping that tapped speed.

ALL IN ALL:
I love this pedal.  It gets me U2'esque delays to creating very creamy distorted leads by making a faux reverb with fast delay and minimal repeats, to even liquid-like ambient leads when using slower and longer delays.  It has many possibilities.
summary: A Multi-Effect That Pays For Itself Many Times Over

I've gone through many recording interfaces in my time. Certain models stop being supported and you end up with a graveyard of USB interfaces over the years. I'm really glad i got this one. For under 100 bucks, i can record 4 channels at once, works perfect on both my Mac Mini and Windows 10 machines alike. Craftsmanship is good. Knobs feel good. I would have accepted it if there was some cheapness, considering the price, but this is a totally legit unit. Unless i find out a month from now that it magically dies on it's own, I see no reason to spend more money on any other interface unless you need more than 4 channels.

This unit has dedicated outs per channel too! So besides the main outs, you can get a separate out per channel.  That's uncommon in "cheaper" class units, so i was surprised by that. It's great to send mics and lines to this first, and use the outs on the back of the unit to send the signals through monitoring, additional processing, etc. In the past I would use a Patch bay to achieve the same thing, so I was able to minimize my set up by adding this unit to my studio.

reviewText: Even without the rivets this cymbal would have a glassy sound that characterizes most A Custom rides. With the rivets it's shimmering and it responds beautifully to a flick of a brush for accents, or a stick for a long sustain crash. I love it for riding when playing blues and jazz. That is not to say it would not work with other genres, but it would be more of an addition to your sound palette than as a main ride. In blues or jazz it can be either your main or possibly your left side ride. Another big plus is this crashes as well as it rides. Of course the sustain from a crash will linger seemingly forever, so that aspect takes getting use to. Do understand that this cymbal does not project well. It's relatively quiet compared to a 20" Zildjian A series Medium Ride. If you are playing heavily amplified music you will find this better suited as an effects cymbal than as a ride or crash/ride. Because I primarily play jazz this pairs beautifully as my left side ride with an Zildjian A Series 21-Inch Armand Ride Cymbal as my primary.

Wow.  I am amazed!  I was a little skeptical about the open gear thing, but these things have won me over.  After the initial string up and re tuning 3 or 4 times in the first half hour or so as the strings broke in, the guitar I put these on has not gone out of tune in over a month now.  I did not know such a thing was possible without a locking nut!  I have never had tuners that held tune this well, and I have had a lot of tuners over the years, including locking grovers and locking gotohs, and I don't mean their cheap lines.  I have never had tuning this stable without a locking nut and a micro tuning bridge of some kind.  I will probably never buy another kind of tuners again.  These are really that good.  Buy a set, you won't be sorry.

Also, huge kudos to SportHiTech, who was the Amazon vendor I got them from.  They are world class service.  I emailed them immediately after the order was placed and asked if I could have a custom set of post spacing and different buttons, and they hooked me right up - no extra charge.  I don't think I'll ever use different tuners again, and I don't think I will ever buy them from a different vendor either.
summary: Amazing!  I will probably never buy another kind of tuners again!

Even the name of some functions and displays have changed - and there is no reference manual for the current firmware (v2.0).  (There are some manual updates but they are still well behind the current software.)

I was unable to get several functions to work by just poking around the menu.  Tech support did reply (not very fast) but with very terse and incomplete (and for me - useless) comments (they did admit that one function had been given a new name - without clarifying further).

So beware - unless you are so familiar with recorders that you can read between the (tiny) lines.

I returned mine and got another brand that has a real reference manual available - and I am happy with it.

The Catalinbread Dirty Little Secret III aims to imitate the preamp circuit tones of both a Marshall Super Lead and the Super Bass. These are both classic amps with hallmark tones, but I think in terms of amp cloning the DLSIII fails. It doesn't sound like a Marshall. It does have its own sound though, and the best way to describe it is Dark and Fat. Whether you pick the SL or SB circuit, the DLSIII is a chunky and grimy overdrive. This is not the go-to for singing highs and stinging leads. This is for riffage galore. This is your pedal for sludge, grunge, doom: this is for Sabbath, Motorhead, Cathedral, SunnO))), and High on Fire fans.

While I owned it, I didn't think it was for me ultimately, but I definitely appreciated its quality and character for what it was, and for what it could do. If I were more into those subgenres, I'd happily run it into a 4x12 and a 100W head, tune my guitar low, and bang away in sonic subregions.
summary: Better Like It Chunky, Because that's this Pedal's Dirty Lil' Secret

I play keys, but my co-writer plays only guitar. I am using Sonar 8.5 and a Roland Juno-G as a remote instrument through a MOTU Ultralite and a return through a M-Audio 4x4 MIDI hub. The lag we experienced while testing was very small, about maybe 3-5 milliseconds. Considering the path from the YRG through the MOTU, through the computer, back through the MIDI hub to the instrument, we found it to be entirely acceptable. One method we plan on using to offset the difference in performance is to use an on board sound monitored locally through an amp, while recording silently in the DAW. After recording, maybe three small nudges left and the track should have no problems lining up. In hindsight, we didn't even try to go direct MIDI right to the instrument "in", cutting out three stops along the way. In that setup we would just record from the MIDI "through" of the instrument. I was being lazy and the setup worked fine as is. At first he was a little disappointed in the response on the strings, then we increased the sensitivity in the control panel and that did the trick. But what is great was when we threw down a quick scratch track with keys and guitar and within a few minutes the guitar player was laying down an incredibly expressive synth sax line, that would have been impossible for me to duplicate using keys. This is exactly what I got it for and I wasn't disappointed. Even with the slight lag, after just a few minutes he was hitting the next note just slightly early enough to sound great. It's not sporadic, the lag is entirely predictable and consistent. So I agree with the learning curve statement given in an earlier review. Considering the cost of any available alternative for MIDI guitar conversion, I personally believe this to be a incredible value. I have only owned it for about two weeks, so I will note any future problems in the comments section. One thing to note is that if using USB power, you might want to look into getting a fairly long USB cord. I don't own any of these so I have no idea about their quality. 10 foot cords: Belkin F3U138-10 Pro Series 10-Foot USB 2.0 5-Pin Mini-B Cable USB 2.0 A to 5-Pin Mini B Cable - 10 Feet 15 foot cord (was hard to find): RiteAV - USB 2.0 A to Mini-B 5-pin Cable 15 ft. I'm using a long MIDI cord (20') and the weight of the cord was allowing the MIDI connection to fall out. Since I had a vecro wrap already on that cord, tying the velcro around the guitar strap leaving about a 6" loop in the MIDI cord solved that problem and removed any tension on the MIDI connection. Similar to these: Hook & Loop Fastening Cable Ties 6inch, 60pcs/Pack - 6 Colors The color coding helps me to figure out the outs and ins at the MIDI hub, without tracing wires. Of course is good when you also have " instrument cords lying all over the place and you don't know which goes where. The same color on each end and no tracing required.
summary: For me, it works as described

reviewText:
I bought the UB802 originally just to have a small mixer for bringing in a few more things when recording.  At the price, I didn't expect much.

What a pleasant surprise!  It's rugged, clean, set up well (once you get used to such a small board) and over a year after I bought it, I can say that in all the projects I've used it, it has never let me down yet.

If you're looking for a small board or are just starting out and looking for something affordable to learn on, but you don't want something you'll just be replacing in 6 months or a couple years..I'd rank the UB802 as an excellent choice.  Ask anybody who works with sound and they can tell you, there's no such thing as an "extra" little mixer.  If it holds up good and sounds good, you'll always find places for it in your studio or gig.

This is a good one.  Kudos to Behringer.

I love this drum machine BUT I am disappointed with the product description. After manufacturing this machine for 20+ years you'd think Alesis would be kind enough to supply ALL of the information to make our purchase go smoothly. Nowhere does it state in the description that the footswitch jacks require MOMENTARY switches. These switches are not uncommon but they are not commonly made in a two button configuration to reduce cord clutter. After fumbling around with a Johnson latching switch I realized my mistake.
A good choice of pedal is the Boss FS6 which is switchable from latching to momentary. Along with a 1/4 TRS and 1/4 TRS to mono splitter I'm finally in business AND a little neater.
I suspect the SR18 needs the same switch........ Why isn't Alesis offering the machine WITH a usable footswitch?

EDIT for the following comment.
-------------------------------
There is NO 3/4 time preset and contrary to what google searches say, it is not easy to program your own waltz rhythm. The manual is useless and I have not found even one accurate, step by step explanation of how to accomplish it. After several frustrating attempts I ordered the SR18 which does include waltz rhythms but has its own set of problems. (Some day I'll review my experience with it). I returned the sr18 within days.

Alesis has made available a system update file for the sr16 that includes 3/4 time but it requires a USB to midi interface which is another $40 or so. The upgrade works well but be aware the 'in' cable has to go to the SR16's out port and the out cable has to go to the in port.
Confusing but it works. I used the "SyEx Librarian.app" on my Mac to push the upgrade to the Alesis and it rebooted with the updates immediately.

IMHO... Daddario has the best, most consistant strings in the business. The wound strings are wound with just the right amount of tension as to not feel to stiff to most players. The core string of each wound stings is hexagonal shapped so the outter winding actually "locks" onto the core making them stay sonically truer longer (other brands can end up with winding / core separaration, which makes the string sound dead). Furthermore, Daddario uses the right diameter cores and windings to achieve a tensionally-correct string (other brands can have, for instance, a stiff A string compared to either the E and/or D string or strings that feel slinkier at the expence of breakage). Lastly, Daddario's doesn't just pack the strings in an air-tight package. Nope! Their air-tight plastic bag outgasses a special corrosion inhibiting chemical that keeps the strings as fresh as the day they were made. This is why I love these strings and always recommend them to other players.

I got my first Shubb capo when playing a gig. A previous touring band had left it behind and was not coming back. Score.

If you plan to perform and care about staying in tune, buy this capo.

It adjusts so you can get the right tension wherever placed on whatever neck. On my acoustic I loosen it a few turns capoing at 8, tighten up a bit capoing at one. Easy and fast, can do it between songs no problem.

It applies even, straight down tension all at once, not a "pinch" like the Keyser style does. Yes, you should still check your tuning, your guitar setup/intonation would have to be flawless to not need to, but you'll have about 1% of the tuning issues with a Shubb that you would have with a Keyser.

Okay - I get it. The Keyser clips onto your headstock so easy. If you want to pass a guitar around a campfire and make noise, use your Keyser. If you want to play guitar, buy one of these or something of a similar design.  Yes, you're going to lose it. And then you're going to buy another one. And it will be worth it. And maybe somebody else will find your other one and they will sound better. Everybody wins.

These reeds can be a lifesaver when doing outdoor shows on hot &/or humid days, as there is nothing worse than picking up your tenor to blow, only to find nothing comes out, cause your reed has wilted... I've used them on some gigs where nuance & subtlety are not as important, for while I think they are pretty nice sounding, they are not as warm sounding as regular cane reeds. For the little bit extra in price, they are definitely worth it, as more of them work, and they last much longer than normal reeds.

The other side is lightly bedded with impact-resist foam.  For me (Fishman ToneDEQ DI, Boss RC-30 loop) the size is more than, fine, and could accomodarte more.  Plan on needing to have your pedals velcro taped independently, and using a fill-in bracer if desired (I chose to use a couple of the airbags and packing roll form amazon pagkaces in it).  It DOES lock, but obviously, for eye-view use (you can see someone unlocking it, but it can be broken open fairly easily, if not watching).  It's decent sturdy, but not 'guaranteed' air-ready, just imo.  4 stars, though - a great product, for the price, and versatile, upon your adjustment.

reviewText: This is the standard power supply for chain powering of pedals. It has inherent shortcomings that can lead to a hum in some pedalboard setups. I haven't had that problem yet. For the price, this power supply is as good as any. The power "bricks" work well too and eliminate some of the problems of the One Spot while creating problems of their own, including bulk, weight, expense and some electrical issues. For a single line power supply similar to the One Spot, my favorite is the Diago, which is a lot more expensive and worth the price for its strong, clean power. I tend to use the One Spot for 1 to 4 pedals and the Diago for any number of 9v pedals up to the maximum my board will hold. The bricks are great when I need different voltages for pedals on my board.
summary: Good power supply for a few 9v pedals.

reviewText: I decided to get this because I have 14 guitars and buying strings can get expensive. Plus these are the strings I prefer anyways. Had high hopes for it but even looking at the picture I thought "I wonder how they get the strings to not bind up inside?". The answer? They didn't. First string I went to grab was the low E. I followed the instructions and held the rest of the strings in place while pulling and it got stuck. Pulled as hard as I could without risking damage to the string and it would only come out about 6 inches...and then it wouldn't go back in. I tried another string, same thing. I now had 2 low E strings sticking out 6 inches from the box. I had no choice but to open the box up all the way, take apart the plastic spools inside, unwind ALL of the low E strings, and then try to wrap them back up again. The result? I now have 25 brand new low E strings with finger prints all over them. Thought my problems were over once I finished with the 3 wound strings. Nope. Sure enough went to grab a G and it got stuck. Took some serious coaxing to get it out. I would rather pay the extra money for 25 individual sets of these strings than ever get this bulk box again. They didn't even wrap each bundle of strings in protective sleeves either so by the time I use the last few sets they will probably be corroded and useless. Especially the low E's thanks to my prints. Basically what I'm saying is unless you are a guitar repair tech and plan on changing 25 sets of strings in one week do NOT buy this. Waste of money.

If you need to buy four or five microphones, don't spend 400 or 500 on SM58s. These are just as good, when used on a mic stand. Literally just as good. Not just good for the money. We use them all the time for all vocals at festivals and no one notices the difference. The only reason I still buy SM58s is because it's the same and model people expect to see, but functionally there's no quality difference, except for a little handling noise when hand held, only really noticeable when pee are speaking and there's no music.

A lot of  cheap mics seem to sound good for the money, but when you kick them up they feed back a bunch... Not the case with these. They sound good completely flat, similar in tone and gain to the 58. They're not THE SAME, though. They will feed back at different frequencies than 58s do, so of you're having to get loud and notch out feedback frequencies in monitors you may want to stick with all the same make and model on stage.
summary: From an audio engineer - as good as an SM58.

reviewText: I didn't get this on Amazon but got mine used for a substantial savings over new. I've been a fender guy for s long time and have several vintage fender amps. I was looking for a Marshall and this got good reviews. This thing sounds fantastic paired with my Les Paul. I really like the classic gain channel which goes from really nice cleans that are very different from fender cleans to a great classic rock crunch. The higher gain channel at first had more gain than I really wanted. I swapped out the cheapy stock Marshall preamp tubes with some vintage Tung Sols and that made a big difference - now the higher gain channel picks up where the classic channel leaves off and is much more usable. I love this amp and would highly recommend it. Many have complained that it doesn't have an effects loop but that doesn't bother me much - my pedal board sounds fine right into the front end.

Let me quickly talk about the negatives and move on to the good stuff. The bad news is that, the included case is really cheap and low-quality, the online guitar lessons seem to be under construction at the moment, but will probably be low quality once they are online, and no pick is included - so you might want to 'add on' this 10 pack on Amazon: Planet Waves Assorted Pearl Celluloid Guitar Picks, 10 pack, Medium Now, the good news. Right out of the box, the guitar sounds well-tuned and delivers a rich classic guitar sound that even the pickiest players will find suitable. It is a lightweight guitar, but still very solid and well-crafted. I received the 'transparent blue burst' color which may be a little neon to some, although I found it beautiful. There are some helpful pamphlets which will help you learn the basic chords and provides instructions for keeping the guitar in-tune. OVERALL: While some of the accessories are a little cheap, the guitar itself is a beautiful instrument that is crafted with care and a bargain at only $100. It would make a great gift for someone interesting in learning to play or a treat for yourself. Just don't forget to buy a guitar pick! I give it a solid recommendation.

reviewText: Folks that like the original Ibanez Tube King will love this pedal.  Sturdier construction than most of Behrenger's other pedals-  The housing is metal and the knobs seem a bit more solid.  Folks talk about how bad the stock tube is, but that has not been my experience.  I may experement with a low gain JJ in the future, but the stock tube is staying put for now.  Maybe I got lucky and they 'hand selected' the right one?  This unit sounds really incredible when it's running into the front end of my EL84 powered tube amp.  The sound is really organic and gritty, with great harmonics and smooth sustain. Sounds decent but not nearly as good going into a solid state amp (no suprise there).  Still, an improvement from the sterile solid state tone.  Be forewarned - this pedal is gigantic in dimension.  Who cares, so long as it sounds this good??  I'd wanted a vintage Chandler/Butler Tube Driver forever, but now I honestly don't need one.  This pedal gets me there on the cheap!
I love this thing!  Fits perfectly in my home made rack mount right below my behringer noise gate.  Saves me all kinds of time.
summary: Good buy!  Saves me all kinds of time.

reviewText:
Wow what a powerful little light.  I got this for a Halloween project. Super bright can be seen down the street on the stop sign, at least 100 yards.  Small and compact.

I'm not a fan of the separate lights for each color.  When the colors are mixed it makes a halo effect but for single colors or using it for a party, dance etc. it is fine.
They work! The only downside is the metal connectors need to be cleaned pretty frequently for aesthetic purposes.

reviewText: Good quality, but unnecessarily expensive. I didn't know that standard cheapo $5 covers would not fit Seymour Duncan pickups. You wouldn't  want to do a walk on to their gig with your belt clipped 6" amp. The marking on the controls are only raised plastic letters and are impossible to read. This smacks of it's chinese manufacture. If you could fine one of better quality sound grab it and let me know.

This little gem is made in Germany with the same kind of quality construction you see on their larger harps. I don't recommend it for beginners but it is a blast to hang on your neck with this chain Besteel Womens Mens Stainless Steel Rolo Cable Wheat Chain Link Necklace 28inch and have handy whenever you have a few moments and want to belt out a tune. Keep in mind that it is a four hole instrument so you are restricted to one octave. For some songs you have to get a bit creative to keep things in the small range. In our house it also doubles up as a great whistle for calling our cat. She comes running whenever I play it. I like to think she admires my skill. I waited until I was getting reasonably proficient on the harp before I bought it. It makes a great graduation gift. Note that I got the idea from an instructor of a Udemy course I am taking -- Ben Hewlett whom I greatly recommend.
summary: A fun little instrument.  Also makes a great gift.

Is it rugged, and going to stand up to heavy use? No.  Would I trust a really good uke to it? No.  But if you need a good, cheap bag, you can't go wrong here.

reviewText:
The Zoom iQ5 seems like a good idea but has many design and functional problems:
- Delicate, fragile construction. Probably breaks when dropped or bumped into.
- Stereo separation is poor. Sounds like mono.
- Using the Handy Recorder app, you can only save files as .WAV or .M4A (highest resolution is only 160kps).
- Everything is dependent upon the tiny, Apple-proprietary Lightning jack. I can foresee this getting broken very easily.
- It needs to be plugged snuggly to iPod Touch or iPhone. So you have to take off your case leaving it vulnerable.

[DW]
Does the job. I have bought these before.

The Boss RC-3 Loop Pedal is great for playing guitar in a band, or with friends, but also a big help practicing. It comes with 10 pre-set rhythm tracks but the real fun is laying down your own chord sequences with your guitar and then being able to play lead guitar over that rhythm loop with just a quick stomp on the pedal. It makes practicing etc. a lot of fun and meaningful. I haven't figured out all the possibilities yet - and probably never will - but it is a cool pedal to have. Like all Boss pedals, it's as sturdy as a little truck.

This is the first thing my sound hits as it enters my pedal board, and I love it. It's a clean boost pedal that really gives a nice EQ and fattens up my tone a bit. It's surprising what kind of difference it makes to my tone, and I love it for that. It stays on 100% of the time I'm playing now.

This capo is fundamentally flawed, and shouldn't even claim to be adjustable. It's WAY too tight, even on it's lightest setting. Do yourself -- and your frets -- a favor and buy the Shubb. If you compare the two, as I now have, you'll realize what a joke this Planet Waves capo really is.

The whole point of an adjustable capo is that you don't want any more tension than necessary. You don't want it mashing your strings against the fret.

I can't even imagine a scenario where one would actually tighten it more. It's ridiculous that this is even being sold. The design is simply wrong, and it's misleading to call this an adjustable capo.
summary: Fundamentally flawed design, and a waste of money.

reviewText: Great Product. Very High Quality. The customer service at Fishman is outstanding. Before purchasing the item, I contacted Fishman Customer service to ask them about whether I needed the narrow or the regular size pickup. They were extremely responsive and helpful. Since I was going to install this myself, I asked a number of questions online on Amazon, and I was touched by the number of responses I got with great advice by Music Store Owners and professional technicians who all selflessly provided the information I needed and encouraged me to install it myself. The product itself is very high quality and the packaging is almost as neat as how an iPhone would be packaged. The only thing lacking in the package is detailed instructions which can be downloaded online on Fishman's website.  However, even those instructions assume that you are a "handy"person and know how to work with tools and precision. The sound quality is awesome.

reviewText:
I'm approaching this review strictly from an Ukulele-perspective: I bought a pack of each of the Wedgie rubber picks - Hard, Medium and Soft - to try on the ukulele. I'll copy/paste this review to all three of the products. I have no finger nails (bad habit of mine), so I always have a hard time getting any volume out of my ukes. I mostly play with my thumbs/ on a more quiet approach. But I thought, to get more volume, let's try these out.
I've also tried the felt ukulele picks and didn't really like those all that much after awhile. The texture was too weird for me. I've tried plastic guitar picks too, and those are OK, but a little too harsh on ukulele strings.
I think these are great for the best tone on a ukulele. I think the Hards are too hard though for most ukulele's. The Hard's may work for baritones or electric's/solid bodies. The Hard's are about twice as thick as the Medium and Soft. The Medium and Soft are essentially the same thickness; the only difference is the tension in them. I find that the Medium is the best though because of that extra little resistance. The Soft sometimes can drag on the strings/snag on the strings a little bit.
Thus I think Medium are the best for the ukulele (5-star), Soft next best (4-star), and Hard least-best (3.5 but rounding up since I like the product overall).
summary: I've also tried the felt ukulele picks and didn't really like those all that much after awhile

Ok.  If you are looking at these harmonicas you know one thing, they are not top of the line high quality harmonics.  With that out of the way, I am extremely satisfied with these.  I'm not a serious harmonica player.  I have a Golden Melody that I like to mess around with.  I got these because the band I play in has 2 songs that need a hardmonica.  One for an intro the other for a solo.  Rather than spend $60 on 2 golden melodies, I got these 7 for $24.  They are cheap, yes.  I had one bad note on one of the harmonicas, but I think that it will work itself out with playing (had a similar issues with my golden melody and it is fine now).

I agree with other comments here that there is a plastic smell / taste, but its plastic, you'll have that and it will go away in time.  Just leave the case open for a while (like several days).

I am perfectly happy with what I got for the money.  Thus the 5 stars even with the one bad note.  If I were to rate these against my golden melody they would not stack up, but that's not what I paid for.

UPDATE:
I have been playing these much more lately with a bluegrass gosple band.  I'm still really happy with them.  Plastic taste and smell are long gone.  But, I did pull out my golden melody the other day after note playing it in a long while and can really tell the difference.  I have the GM in the key of G.  Think I am going to buy one in C to replace my most commonly used ones in this case, but I'm still really happy with the set.  A great starter or supplement set for those less commonly used keys.

While I've had good luck with these packets at times, they do not hold up in winter at all.

I have been running two kits (a total of six packets) in a single acoustic case, the hard case for my J-45, in an effort to keep it adequately humidified during this winter. Unfortunately, what I have found is that once the temperature drops below freezing and the humidity along with it, not even double the recommended number of packets will keep humidity in the case above about 35%. Further, the packets go bad in just 2 or 3 weeks of harsh winter temps.

I should stress that I have not had any problems with my guitar, no cracks or anything of that nature, but this system just can't put out enough humidity to keep the guitar safe in a climate with cold winters.

I have moved to the Oasis system which is refillable and much less expensive (when you consider the cost of replacing all these packets every few weeks across all your guitars).
They strings are vibrant and extend the sustain of my Les Paul, which already has great sustain.  I purchased several more sets to replace the strings on my other guitars.

The Guitar Wheel is quite the interesting tool for any musician, whether it is a guitar player, piano player or you want measure chord formation.

The product itself are 3 shiny plastic wheels pressed against each other with a pin, the center one being the one that has the numbers and letters imprinted, a process that required extreme calculation and excellent design just by looking at it, worth alone the effort of the authors. You move the plastic tab on the right side and make it fit to the main note you are looking for.

Its really that good, and will be very useful.

The reason this item deserves 4 stars its because it feels cheap, specially with the guitar drawing on the center.

FYI for those of you looking on where items are manufactured. MADE IN CHINA.

2. Lots of volume from the headphones. Two headphone outs, which is perfect for me.
3. 3 modes of operation-mixer, interface, and preamp. I find this very handy rather than being the impediment that the other reviewer found them to be.
4. Intuitive software package with a lot of flexibility for routing and other tasks.
5. Word clock BNC connections. My last interface lacked these. I clock to the 4-710D.
6. USB3 support with Windows 10.
7. Latency seems to be fine. I'm running a sample rate of 64 with no issues so far.
8. A very solid build. Everything works smoothly and feels tight.
9. XLR inputs up front. For my setup, this is great and saves some wiring and patchbay real estate.
10. 10 line outs, two are used for monitors. 2 additional line ins out back for my Integra 7.
11. MIDI DIN in and out.
12. ADAT support. I use a UA 4-710D as the front end and need an interface with ADAT. SPDIF in and out as well.
13. Rack and desktop ears included.
14. iOS support for working with my iPad.

Cons (room for improvement)
1. Phantom power for channels 1-4 and 5-8 rather than per channel.
2. The gain knobs are very small due to the XLR inputs being in the front. However, this is more than offset for me as stated above.
3. Wall wart instead of an internal transformer.
4. Metering-there is one lamp for each channel that changes color as clipping is approached. Not a huge deal, but a band rather than a single lamp would be better.

I feel that cons 1, 2, and 4 are due to the fact that real estate on the front of the interface is limited due to the XLR inputs being up front.

Originally I thought that there was no clock lock indicator except in the software, but this isn't really the case. A mode indicator will blink if the clock isn't locked.
summary: Lots of useful features, well-made, and sounds good

This is a pretty interesting set of LED light sticks that I think probably have both consumer and professional uses. I'm a professional photographer and I often run into situations where I want something a little offbeat on a set or in a location shot. LED light sticks like this aren't something I get to use everyday, but they do add a quirky touch to location portraits and band portraits and I've used a number of MARQ products in the past just for this reason. I also work at an FM radio station part time and I'm sure we'll find a use for these at live events--be great to draw people to a booth at trade shows, that's for sure.

This particular set of lights (like most of the other MARQ products that I have) suffers from one thing: a lack of a really good manual. This set is nice in that they have 30 preset programs (so you don't need a DMX controller necessarily--though you would certainly get more out of them if you owned one and knew how to use it), but it still takes time to get them to repeat certain patterns and to predictably call them up. I sat on my living room floor for several nights entertaining the cats (and I think my neighbors) playing with various configurations and various programmed effects. (Seriously, I have to wonder why none of my neighbors came knocking to see what was going on.) I got elated when I stumbled onto a really cool effect and then somewhat frustrated trying to go back to it again. But hey, I've been a photographer a long, long time and that's how you learn to use all lighting (though I will say that photographic lighting comes with vastly better manuals).

Each of the tubes has 32 LED lights in them and they are one meter (about a yard) long and they lighting is very intense--that's one thing I love about all MARQ products, by the way, in terms of light output and color purity, they rock. The colors are super saturated and the biggest issue I've had in trying to photograph them is finding a good exposure to capture the nicely saturated colors accurately.

I really like the fan stand that they come with, but it's also nice that you can set up each stick on its own. I'm going to experiment soon with doing some time exposures with a model moving the sticks around--perhaps one in each hand. I've read in a few other reviews that they aren't that well protected in the case, but I think if you're careful with them, the case is fine and its a very nice travel case. I eventually cut out a pice of black foam core material from the dollar store to lay on top of the tubes but that's just because I have a tendency to toss tuff into my prop/lighting room quickly at the end of a long day--but again, I think if you treat the contents with respect (it is light gear, after all) you'll be fine.

So my favorite things about these lights? The colors are bright and saturated and if you play with the programs, you'll find some super cool effects. If you have kids in their teens, forget it, you're going to find these going in their bedrooms all night long. I also like that you can set them up on individual stands (be great in a window display at the holidays--though they're kind of pricey for that) or you can fan them together. I think a DJ that does their own lighten and knows how to run a DMX box will have a blast with these.
summary: Nice saturated and bright LED colors and lots of cool effects

I really like this board, it's very small and useful, and the 2 (or 3) 9volt battery power option is excellent. I do outdoor wedings so occasionally need to mix a few mics in without easy access to power, this thing does a great job. I also use it for DJ gigs and a little live music- I wish it had reverb built in, but it doesn't. I know of no mixer that has onboard effects AND is battery powered... the holy grail? Surely it must be out there... If you're never going to need battery power, you'll probably want something with some onboard effects, there are many out there, but for power source versatility and excellent dry sound for little gigs this board kills it. Oh, I did have a balance pot get ornery, and you have to take off every single knob and jack nut to get at it, but I sprayed a little electronic cleaner in it and it's worked great since. The pots are good enough quality for a basic piece by the way, all Bourns. Next time a component acts up, it's to the scrapheap or donated to a school, these are too cheap to keep wasting time on, I'll just get a new one, I've already gotten 3 years out of it.

3. Visit your computer manufacturer's page and check for updates to the following
~USB controllers
~Chipset/motherboard
~BIOS

4. If all else fails then you will want to either do a system restore as far back as possible or reinstall your OS. We have seen a number of install failures on HP computers and the only 100% fix is this.

Did you see that..."reinstall your OS"  You got to be kidding!

I reviewed their forums regarding the error message I received and saw that I was not the only one who has had this problem.  As far as I could tell, no one was able to find a satisfactory solution.  This problem has been around for months, if not years and still hasn't been resolved by driver/software updates.

I think this company caters to Apple compatible products primarily, and secondarily to PC compatible products.  So, if you have a PC, you might do better to find something else manufactured by a company who makes products with PC compatibility at the forefront of their attentions.

reviewText:
This little gadget here is a dream come true. All it does is amplify the signal that comes from your guitar and transform it from analog to digital, then you can choose the output method, through your pc speakers, the headphone (or monitor) jack in the Guitar Link, or the computer headphone jack. The plastic doesn't look "chinese", if you know what I mean. It feels resistant and strong enough to take on a few drops.

You HAVE to have it plugged in during the installation or else it won't work. Also, it only installs on one USB port at a time, so I recommend you choose one port just for it (not that the port is goning to stop working or anything).

The installation instructions are really like this:
-Insert the CD with the guitar combos. Install all 3 if you want, although you are good to go with the AC Box Combo alone (other 2 are 30 min trials)
-Plug the Guitar Link and start the driver setup, it is in a folder called "drivers", but I don't remember which of the two CDs has it.
-Restart your computer and start the AC Box Combo.
-You are all set to start playing.
-If you want all the other software you might as well continue installing it.

The software included is mostly trash. It comes with 3 Combos, one full version, the other 2 are 30 minute trials. You can use this if you are an amateur and you will be more than happy. The Audacity has a learning curve as steep as a skycraper, and the "lite" version of Energy (called EnergyX2 or something like that) is a liiiittle limited. If you plan to make a studio of your office or room I recommend you buy something more "professional", I personally use Fruity Loops and Waves GTR, but a friend has a couple IK that work awesome and most come with a pedal.

The 64bit asio4all driver is included but is named like setup36.exe, who knows why not 64 or 86, so don't worry, it supports vista/7, 32/64 bit. I haven't tried it on MacOSX or XP.

Bottomline: Definitely is a good investment, weather you are a pro or a beginner. Good quality and good design. Works with everything I have plugged in the jack. (The price in Amazon is about 6 bucks less than every other place I looked).
What can you say.  It works but is not a perfect fix.
summary: It works but is not a perfect fix.

reviewText: I was reluctant to purchase a Mexican made Martin, but I knew Amazon had a generous return policy so I took the leap.  A sub-grand acoustic electric Martin is hard to find especially if you want to avoid HPL siding.  I have a HPL sided Martin DX1 already with the maple top.  I love playing it because of it's light action and bright clear sound.  My son who is all about Electric Les Paul's liked the sound of the DX1 so much he got a baby Martin with all HPL body for $333.  This DRS1 has all Sapele sides and has a heavy bass tone to it which I like.  I'll warn you the pick-up design with a 9 volt boost gives a lot more umph, than passive pick-ups.  The easy access battery compartment is great too, right next to the 1/4" jack.  I like the brightness of the Martin sound, but I have grown to like this bassier tone equally.  It counters my brighter sounding DX1 and I highly recommend it.  This was $759, but I later saw a Maple topped, all wood Martin acoustic/electric for $829.  It had the cut out for higher fret use to it as well.  If I had it to do all over again I would have given the higher priced one a chance first.  This is my traveling guitar because of all wood and when amped out the bass really comes through.  I used it once at a nursing home right after getting it and it was flawless.  Can't say the same for my voice, but I highly recommend this as a worthy addition to any Martin collection.
