I've been using this older model, there is a newer model now by Roland, which I've not tried. You want to learn to play guitar? REALLY? You will need PRACTICE, PRACTICE, PRACTICE! This device is the greatest practice device ever! Why? To practice, you need a METRONOME / DRUM MACHINE, a TUNER, BACKING TRACKS. To like how you sound, you will need EFFECTS, AMP MODELS, to color your sound. If you hate how you sound, you will not continue playing. Micro BR has all this and more. There is NO EXCUSE to not practice, when you use this device. You can use headphones, when you can't play with an amp. You can run this between your guitar and amp, when you need to. Any time you have 5 minutes to run some scales, etc. Micro BR is there for you. Quick, easy no hassle. Just plug in, pick an amp model or effect and noodle away. You can record your practice sessions, to track your progress. The interface is confusing, manual not well-written. However, when you learn to use it's myriad functions, you will LOVE this thing. I had stopped playing for five years. This device and buying a Gibson SG got me to WANT to play again. This in itself tells you everything you need to know.

UPDATE 9/1/14:
Two of the issues discussed below were fixed by Boss. The latency when switching from phrase to phrase was eliminated by a firmware update, and the labor part of the warrantee was upped from 90 days to a healthier 2 years.

With those improvements in mind I have changed my rating from three stars to four stars, although I am still not wildly excited about the RC-3. I am currently using it with a Zoom G3X, which can compensate for some of the RC-3's shortcomings. The G3X allows you to dial in a tempo, and it has 40 high quality drum beats (still not enough AFAIC). I've ended up using the RC-3 simply to record and loop what comes off the G3X and have dispensed altogether with the RC-3's inadequate rhythm features. The G3X also has a simple looper that is very convenient and useful when you want to try something out quickly without messing with the RC-3.

-------------

Original Review:

3-1/2 stars, really. It's almost a great product, but considering the relatively high price it's disappointing that Boss cut corners and didn't get some of the details right.

The good stuff about the RC-3 is obvious and easy to find online--it loops, has lots of memory and I/O, is easy to use, and is excellent for practicing and song writing--so I'm focusing on the less obvious bad stuff:

- Various online sources, including, until recently, the Boss and Roland websites, claim you can specify tempo incrementally. Unfortunately this is not true. There is no tempo display and it's tap tempo only, which is a pain in the neck and really ticked me off, because it was one of the few things I was careful to check on the Boss site. At the very least one should be able to fine tune the tempo in 1 BPM increments with the increase/decrease buttons, even if the tempo isn't also displayed, but you can't even do that. And no, you can't use the pedal to tap in the tempo--you have to get down on the floor and use the dinky little button.

- The drum beat and tempo reset to their defaults if you change the phrase number, even if you move to a blank phrase. Sorry, but that is plain dumb--it means you can't record several versions of the same thing, or different parts of a song, without re-setting the beat and tempo. BUT, as noted above, you can't set the tempo numerically, so it's impossible to get the same tempo.

- Built-in time signatures are 3/4 and 4/4 only. No 7/8, 5/4, etc. Boss's marketing department was inspired on how to play this--the web site says, "You can also specify the time signature." Uh, thanks, but the choices, which Boss conveniently neglects to mention, are almost as limited as the color of a Ford Model T. ("Any customer can have a car painted any color that he wants so long as it is black.") I should add that one of the 4/4 beats is a 12/8 shuffle, and that one of the 3/4 beats is a 6/8 shuffle and another is 9/8, but that doesn't excuse Boss's mendacity. It's clear they are trying to hide their product's shortcomings.

- The 10 built-in drum beats are very basic and are not adequate. There's a reason you can't listen to them on the Boss site, but as a public service I have made recordings available [links deleted by amazon. Try searching soundcloud for Boss RC-3 Drums]. There are actually 20 beats, since there are versions for 3/4 and 4/4, but with all the storage space on this thing, surely Boss could have included more. Even the previous model, the RC-2, had 30 (?) beats.

(Yes, you can go to the trouble of recording and importing your own rhythms to get any time signature and pattern, but you lose the pedal's convenience advantage. Besides, recorded rhythms are part of a loop--they can't be re-used without re-importing, the number of measures can't be changed, and the volume can't be adjusted independently of the guitar playback. Maybe there's a way to hook a drum machine up to the second input, but I can't think of how you would sync/trigger it.)

- The 5 year warranty is parts only. Labor is only 90 days. Labor rates are $40/hour. Return shipping is on you, and if you choose not to get the repair after receiving an estimate, then you are charged $25 anyway. It seems that warranty information is hidden on purpose. I could not locate it on the Boss site and even the documentation that comes with the pedal does not state the warranty period or detailed terms. It's a wonder of obfuscation: "... this product will be free from defect in materials and/or workmanship from the date of purchase until the period of time indicated for this product." Uh huh. And what "period of time" would that be and where would it be "indicated"? Well, I eventually found the actual warranty terms on rolandus.com: [URL deleted by Amazon. Try googling rolandus warranty]

- Power supply is not included by Boss, although some retailers include one.

- When you switch between phrases, there is a short lag, so you can't string together phrases to make a song in real time. See this youtube video: TlKDHsauvos

- Buttons are mushy, rubbery stuff like a tv remote. Probably saved on costs, but the durability is questionable.

One other note: I'm using the RC-3 in a Line 6 Flextone I guitar amp effects loop. That way I can overlay loops using different amp effects and amp models. Unlike the Jamman Solo, this is not a mode that is mentioned in the instructions. I think the RC-3 is designed to go before the amp. Amp effects loops are usually line level, while stomp boxes are usually instrument level, so whether it works probably depends on the effect loop's impedance (line level can mean different things and likely varies by amp) and whether the RC-3 can handle the signal coming out of the preamp. Well, nothing's fried yet.

UPDATE 2/21/12:
A minor issue: When a recorded loop is transferred to a computer, a drum/tempo track is not included. You get a Stereo WAV (41.1 KHz, 16 bit) of the guitar. So, if you want to use the loop in, say, Garage Band, or import it back into the RC-3, you will have to add drums. Getting drums to sync up on the RC-3 is difficult unless the loop was recorded at the default tempo (120 bpm) or is relatively short. If not, eventually the drums go out of sync, because, as noted above, there is no way to dial in a tempo.

UPDATE 7/27/12:
- Supposedly cannot be used with headphones. There is a dire warning in the instructions that the headphones could be damaged, but Boss does not elucidate how. I tried it anyway. It works, but you need a mono to stereo adapter to hear the output in both ears (or something more complicated if you are using both of the RC-3 inputs), and the output is weak. You have to turn the volume up all the way up to get a barely reasonable volume, so I don't see how the headphones would be damaged.

- Do not try using this with a power supply daisy-chained to other pedals or a headphone amp. It generates all kinds of horrible electronic noise, including a high pitched oscillation and in-tempo thunks.
summary: Almost Great. Too many small flaws [UPDATED 9/1/14]

Wow!  this is the best Fender amp ever made.....really the benchmark for all others
The clean sound through the twin Jensen 12's is 3 dimensional and unbelievable...
The dynamic sensitivity is excellent and really sets you free to express your music in a very pure way.
Not as loud as people complain about....I play in my studio at 3-4 and it seems just right.....use the right input for lower db
At church and gigs a 6-8 will be just right for nice warm tube bliss.
The reverb and tremolo are incomparable to any digital offering.
Use a simple distortion pedal like a Boss super OD or Klone or big Muff and it is creamy and smooth tonal happiness.
Compared to the Deluxe reverb you get a bright switch so you can choose between snappy highs or subtle tone.
The deluxe doesn't have a mid tone knob and the twin has treble, mid, and bass...so the twin can be dialed in to a huge palette of tones.
The twin speakers give the twin reverb much greater sonic dimension.
This is a "must have" combo for the passionate and tone seeking musician...I lifetime keeper that will keep you
smiling every time you plug in!
summary: Wow...the absolute must have amp for every guitarist!

reviewText: A good solid piece of equipment with great tone and control! It came extremely well packed. For the price, this is one great little dynamo!

I get what people are saying about it not sounding the best once it has been recorded and you're listening to it away from the amp, but so far--as someone who plays primarily clean Smiths-type stuff--it's sounded great when taken off of the pedal and put into my DAW.

The reason I gave it four stars is the app is pretty much useless. If you actually get it to connect, it will just crash once you're done recording something, and if it doesn't crash after you've finished recording, it will when you try to email it. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND getting the usb for this pedal. It makes it so much easier just to take the music file off of your pedal and drag it into your editor or iTunes or whatever.

If you're learning how to write songs this is great, if you're comfortable with writing songs, this just makes it incredibly easy to recording a decent sounding song.

reviewText:
I read the reviews about low gain and then ordered my Blue Yeti Pro thinking I could fix the low gain by using my Macbook Pro midi settings.  I was seriously wrong!  I'm not using midi so the suggested fix simply had no effect.  I already had a Blue Icicle XLR to USB converter, so I used it with the XLR output on the Yeti Pro.  Wow!  It was at least 5x louder than the Pro's native USB output (based on waveforms in Audacity).  I also discovered that the mic sounds terrific at a distance of about 2.5 feet -- perfect for webinars.  Yet, I had to give up important features when using the Icicle (stereo, headphone monitoring, mute, etc.), so that wasn't a permanent fix.  I called Blue Microphone and discovered that the Yeti Pro is intentionally designed not to have anywhere near the gain of the standard Yeti.  They tell me that's because they expect the Pro to be used in applications with high sound pressure (drums, guitar).  That's great, but I want to use the mic for webinars, web classes and voiceover.

The good news is that Blue Microphone offered to perform a "gain update" to lift the gain of the Yeti Pro to the same level as the Yeti.  However, I have to send my microphone back to the company and wait 1-2 weeks for the modification.  Bummer, but it's worth it.  So why 4 stars, given all the hassle?  I started with 5 stars for sound quality and features and then subtracted 2 star for the gain update hassle, but added 1 star back because Blue Microphone owned the problem and offered a fix -- 4 stars total.

Just a note for Blue -- since you can set the gain either high or low, it would be wonderful to have a "hi/lo gain" switch on the next iteration of this microphone.

BTW, I can't use the Yeti Pro on the same desk as my Macbook Pro without the optional shock mount.  The provided stand picks up vibrations from my fan and keyboard and that results in a seriously loud background hum and clicking.

Update: I received my Blue Yeti Pro back from Blue this week.  They made the mod to make the mic as sensitive as the silver Yeti and it sounds great with voice.  Now it works as a webinar and video recording mic.  I tried it with singing and concertina today and, yes, it overloads very easily.  But I expected that.  I also tried using the headphone output to play iTunes songs via the usb connection, but it sounded terrible -- very thin and echoey.  So, I learned that the headphone jack is OK for monitoring the mic, but not for monitoring my computer.

Update: May 15, 2013.  I lowered my rating from 4 stars to 1 star today.  I just received a replacement mic from the factory today.  It works fine through the xlr connector, but the USB is totally dead.  I tried two MacBook Pros and both recognized the mic and provided a USB driver, but neither computer could get any sound out of the mic.  And that's after a gain modification to increase the mic's sensitivity.  To recap; first no gain - to the factory for gain mod -- then no USB sound -- back to the factory for a replacement mic and gain mod -- now new mic has no USB sound.  I'm at my wit's end.  I'll call Blue Microphone again tomorrow.  They haven't ignored me in the past and I'll still raise my rating if I can just get a good mic.

Update: May 20, 2013.  Total fail.  After talking with the Blue folks, we got to the point where they just didn't know what was wrong with the mic.  The symptoms were no sound on two of my MacBook Pro's and great sound on another MBP and a Mac Mini.  All had the latest OS.  I could send it back to Blue a third time, but they didn't think another replacement mic would work any better.  The Blue people were responsive and concerned, but just didn't have a fix.  So I returned it to the vendor for a refund and bought an Apogee One.  To summarize:

1) The Yeti Pro has about 10 db less gain than the Yeti, making it useless for webinars, Skype and podcasting.
2) The Yeti Pro does not work with all Macs.  It didn't work on two of my Macs and others on the web report the same problem.
3) Blue Mic has a free factory mod to fix problem 1, but has no resolution to problem 2.
summary: Sorry Blue, This Dog Won't Hunt

reviewText: I purchased this because of the through connector. I am connecting the left 1/4 inch out of a Casio Privia to the 1/4 inch input of this, running the 1/4 inch through to a Fender Rumble 25 v3 Bass Combo Amplifier to use as a monitor, and the output to a PA channel. The bass amp is an excellent keyboard amp in its own right, but it's an even better monitor. I had been using a Mackie SRM150 as a monitor along with a mic. The problem was both the keyboard and the mic mix went to single PA channel. With this DI box I can use the bass amp as the keyboard monitor and the SRM150 as a two-channel mic monitor. One other feature that I love this box's versatility. In my home studio I am connecting my keyboard directly to a PowerWerks PW50 RMS Personal PA System. Without running it through this box I get hum. Inserting this box into the signal path completely eliminates it. At the time of this review this box was going for about twenty bucks. That is a tiny price to pay for both the convenience and versatility.

reviewText: Great strings

Let me start by saying I love this thing and would have rated it as 5 stars but for the fact that installation was difficult. I installed on a Fender Strat. The main installation problem is that the combined thickness of the nut part and the fret part was much thicker than my existing nut. The secondary installation problem is that once you get the nut part sanded down correctly, you need to somehow "hammer" the fret part down into the crack you have between the nut part and the fret board. You need to force the fret part down without bending or mangling the fret part. Because the nut part is behind and above the fret part it is hard to force into the crack without mangling something. You have to be careful not to over sand the nut part - the final fit needs to be snug. So, lots of sanding and trying. BE PATIENT!

Once installed, it is PERFECT. When you play, the open strings are "fretted" the same as the fingered strings. Tuning is easier, in my opinion. It is a wonderful modification.
summary: Great up grade but includes tedious work

Although the cable functions, I am not happy with the quality. My main gripe is that the rubber piece where the cable meets the connector fell out of the connector with almost no pressure whatsoever applied to it. The purpose of this piece is to keep cable bending force from getting inside the connector and damaging the connections between the wires in the cable and the connector pins (usually solder connections). With the rubber piece not serving this purpose, the cable is likely to fail much sooner than it should. I tried to force the rubber piece into the connector but was unable to. Maybe if I disassemble the connector... but hey, I shouldn't have to do that. Maybe this cable is OK for a studio where it is installed and never moved, but I would never take it out on a gig.

I used one of these early in my career and I always loved it.  I purchased one for use in my home studio and I was so pleased to see (and hear) this microphone still ROCKS!

A few things to note.

1. This microphone is truly flat (out of the box).  You can adjust its frequency response quite easily.

2. The microphone sounds a bit different depending on what wind screen you use (stock RK345 vs. the supplied A7WS).  I'm a fan of the extra pop protection of the A7WS.

3. Last but not least... the microphone needs a lot of gain (nearly 40 dB) so be careful what mixer you plug into.  Many "cheaper" mixers introduce noise when you really pump up the gain.  I find the mic works VERY well plugged into a pre-amp and/or processor.

Best Wishes,
Mike

I bought this case for my Crdoba C5-CE, because the factory-supplied gig bag started falling apart after one trip outside the house.

The fit around the perimeter of the guitar is excellent.  It's very snug and secure, and there is just enough room for the electronics to squeeze in.  The fit at the front is tight enough to leave string impressions in the lining on the lid of the case.  The fit at the back is just a touch loose with this guitar.  I don't think it's loose enough to matter, but I wouldn't want to use this case with a guitar that was any thinner bodied than this one.

The compartment under the neck rest is typical for a guitar case in that it isn't big enough to hold much more than a few packs of spare strings, a string winder, some picks and so on.  Since this is a classical guitar case, it would be awesome if it had a compartment somewhere big enough to store a foot rest, and that is the one big thing I will miss about the gig bag.

The case came packaged in a flimsy piece of black fabric by way of shipping materials.  I can't remember the name of the fabric, but it's the kind of stuff they staple under boxed springs.  It's kind of thin and gauzy, and tears easily.  I think that fabric was basically just there to protect the brass tone hardware, and provide a place to stick the shipping labels and so forth.  I'm amused that they shipped the case in what amounts to a wisp of nothing, and it survived all the abuse between here and China completely unscathed.  I think that says a lot about how this case is going to hold up, and I think I made a good investment.

I'd love it if it had more storage room.  It's a minor quibble, and I'd give it 4.5 stars if that were possible.
summary: Fits a Crdoba C5-CE very well

reviewText: EXCELLENT

Do you or a loved one spend more time on a guitar forum finding out what is coming out at NAMM? Do you or a loved one find themselves getting to know the UPS or FedEx guy better than your family? Do you end up with a room full acoustic guitars? Diagnosis - GAS (Guitar Acquisition Syndrome) - when you have more guitars than you know what to do with or you have more than the number of kids you have.

The cure for GAS is Tony Rice Monel Strings. If you own a Authentic Series Martin, Clarence White Model Martin, 1934 D SCGC or Tony Rice Model, CW Collings - you really really got to try this. I tried this on my D18GE and D28 Authentic 1941 Martins - WOW is all I said. Then I felt guilty owning more than 1 guitar. These strings increased my volume, sustain, clarity for each note. I didn't expect these results. If you are skeptical - just buy 1 set and give it a try. Spend a few weeks with them. I guarantee if you love bluegrass or flatpicking you'll buy these again. Even if you don't like bluegrass, these will improve your guitar.

Note: These are bluegrass strings - more like Medium gauge - if you have a OM or small body guitar - they may not be recommended by the manufacturer. Also if you only played with lights, extra lights, or electric guitar - you may need time for your fingers not to hurt. If you play mediums already, you should have any problems adjusting to these strings.

They are nickel based strings.
Good quality
I have been using 5B sticks for more than 10 years. Still my favorite.

My favorite thumb pick to date. Small enough to keep palm near strings for muting boom chick style. Gets. Great thump!! Fits great nice and tight. Doesn't get ought on strings. I don't use picks on other fingers though.

I gave it a 4* for the sake of my Dunlop strap lock which I had to wrestle with to fit. I had to use my dad's tool to decrease the thickness up front.( the one where you keep winding the back end of it and it presses it) other than that, all is well.
summary: I gave it 4* for the sake of my Dunlop ...

reviewText:
I frequently misplace guitar picks, eventually finding them laying somewhere (under a music book, on the floor, etc.).  I will sometimes slide the pick under the guitar strings, but I don't particularly like to store them that way.  This Pick Buddy is the perfect solution.  It attaches to any guitar surface without marring the finish, lifts off easily to place on another guitar and holds the pick securely.  One reviewer complained that it would not stick to a microphone stand, which is not surprising; a curved surface simply will not allow the Pick Buddy to stick.  A flat surface (of most any finish) will work fine.

All in all a nifty and very useful gadget.  I haven't misplaced a pick since I received this Vine item.  Recommended.
summary: Works like a charm and no more misplaced picks.

reviewText: This works perfectly and looks great on my Epiphone Goth Les Paul Studio electric guitar that I purchased it with. It looks great, is comfortable, and the price wasn't too shabby.
summary: Great comfortable strap for the price

reviewText: I bought this to make the bridge and tail piece match the pick guard and pickups on my Epiphone studio Les Paul.  It's much better quality than the original hardware, and looks great, but I had to fill and redrill the mounting holes from the old hardware.  I expect its made to fit only Gibson.  I didn't realize there were so many differences between the two makers of Les Pauls.  All in all, it's a good product if you have the skills to do the mods to the body of your Epiphone.
summary: Very nice but doesn't fit Epiphone.

reviewText:
I'm a beginner at the guitar and wanted something easy to use with effects. I purchased a Pandora mini and found it extremely easy to use but lacking in features. I saw this unit and figured I'd return the mini and keep this one instead.

I wound up keeping both because this unit is awesome and has all kinds of cool stuff like bass and drum groove accompaniment that you can play along with and allows you to record into it, slow the piece down and practice. At this point I'm nowhere near ready for that so I've been using the mini for practice and once I get a bit better look forward to using the advanced features of this PX5D.
summary: More complicated than the Pandora mini

reviewText: Love these headphones.  Comfortable .  Good depth with lows and crisp with the high end.  Multiple cords to accommodate travel or walking around the room.

I've got a set of these on a Fluke concert and used the excess to string an Ohana soprano pineapple. In both cases, they sounded more musical, ringing, and yet mellower than the strings they were replacing. Give them a few days to settle in and they seem to hold their tune really well. The volume and projection is great too. Oh, and the price? Buy two sets!

Seriously, I was happily surprised by the improvement in sound in both the ukes. I think you will be too, but it's all subjective, right?

Good luck and keep strumming!

Well what can I say about this speaker that has not been said...
I know this does not sound sane but I installed the Gold in my Fender Mustang 2 v2 practice amp. I also have the Fender Mustang 1, 3 and 5 v2 and just for kicks I previously installed  a Gold 10" in the Mustang 1. I was totally blown away so I "invested" in the 12" version for my Fender Mustang 2. I was again completely blown away at the huge difference in the complexity of the tone. I had changed the stock speaker many times previously and had settled on the Tonker  and loved it but it was a tad too aggressive/loud for practice if that describes it. The Gold is just perfect. I think it is the best modeling amp available period. I have auditioned a lot of well known speakers and they all seemed to be really good at something but not all things. The Gold is great at everything I can throw at it from super clean jazz to power metal. I was astonished when I could hear the spring reverb ringing clear on the Mustang as the notes carried and trailed. I would have sworn there was an actual spring tank set in the Mustang. It is very much like investing in a 4K TV. The detail is just freakishly amazing. I HIGHLY recommend the Gold if you want to hear the subtleties of your playing and equipment. The Gold is fairly linear (small upper mid bump in a good way) and has no harshness at all. Bass is all there and not flabby. It does sound great a bedroom volumes as well. My speaker/tone quest is finally over - Hallelujah!! It would have been so much cheaper if I would have started with the Gold. There is a reason this speaker cost so much... it's worth it! I have spent a ton on guitars, pickups amps etc to find the perfect tone and convenience at the best price and it turns out to be the Fender Mustang v2 series with Celestion Gold speakers. DONE! I have the Mustang 3 and 5 for gigs as well. I will be putting the Gold in them as well pronto.
summary: Like investing in a 4K TV! Freakishly Amazing!

reviewText: Great price
Good fit, nice bag

We've had tons of issues with the old pulpit mic at our church.  Replaced with this one and it has been working like a charm.  Need a soundboard with phantom power to operate, so as long as you can verify that before purchasing all will be good to go!
summary: Works great and great price for a nice pulpit mic!

reviewText: I have been using these heads during rehearsal with a big band.  Good sound, easy to tune with a DrumDial followed by ear.  I hand tightened the lugs, then added a full turn with a drum key and pressed on the center of the heads a couple of time to seat them.  A couple of days later I came back with the DrumDial and tuned, followed by tuning by ear.  So far so good with about 10 hours of rehearsal.

I took pro lessons for about 5 years (okay, so it was 35 years ago) but I hooked up this great kit to my IPOD and a nice pair of quality headphones and it sounds positively excellent.  You need to inspect the heads carefully as there are separate ones for the snare and the tom toms.  But the cymbals respond properly.  Even the ride cymbal responds with a bell sound if you make a precisely perpendicular strike on it. The high hat hisses nicely.  There is enough slack in the cables to hook up the control head all the way to the right so the tom-toms are groped together, which is what I did.  I am also using this set to attempt to get the same sounds out of my acoustic set, which is challenging, fun but really worth it.  I've used it almost every day since purchasing and it beats the heck out of exercising on the stationary bike.  Especially if you already know how to play.
summary: I think this kit is great.

reviewText: Well made and works great. The price is a great value. Very pleased.

I use this as my first-stage overdrive and have been impressed with it's performance so far.  Buzz is not a major issue with this pedal when used alone, but I would recommend a noise gate if stacking with another OD/Dist.

I purchased this mic to use for screencasts (recording what's happening on my PC's screen while I talk about it). I set it up to sit on my desktop, approximately 2' away from me and used Camtasia Studio 8 [Download] and a free program called CamStudio to test it out. Both programs worked well with the mic and did what I'd hoped it would do - eliminated my need for a clunky, wired mic headset. The build quality of the mic seems excellent, and the compact design is fantastic! I love that it comes with its own carrying case and that it can be on a desktop or clipped to a laptop's monitor. KINKS IN MY SYSTEM: MUFFLED AUDIO The included software: Cakewalk's Music Creator LE can be installed on one computer. You get 30 days to register it. I installed it and registered it immediately, but it would not allow me to put in my registration code, saying I wasn't the system administrator. I am, and my Windows 7 PC says I am, but alas, it wouldn't work. This software is optional, but I decided to install it prior to the microphone (per instructions) to try it out. Eventually I ended up uninstalling it. Soon after installing Cakewalk, I had a PC issue: muffled audio recording. No amount of system tweaking seemed to fix it. I was stumped. Then I decided to go to the Samson site and see if there were updated drivers for the mic. The generic ones installed were from 2010. No luck. I began reading online about 'muffled audio' on Windows 7 PCs. Somewhere I noticed a name I recognized: RealTek, which was a name associated with my speakers on my PC (RealTek digital audio). I went to the RealTek site and noted updated drivers for Windows 7 64-bit (2012), and decided to download and install them. I rebooted my PC and tested out the audio recording once more. Much to my delight, this solved the muffled audio problem! I did set the bitrate to the highest level for the best sound quality recording. Afterwards I tested out the mic using Camtasia and CamStudio, both worked beautifully with the Samson Go Mic! On my desk at a distance of about 2.5', this mic pics up my voice perfectly for dictation and screencasts. No hiss, hum, breath noises or distortion. Very clear and with the properly installed drivers for my audio - works perfectly with the USB 2.0 connection on my powered USB hub. CONCLUSION: BUY IT FOR GREAT RECORDINGS This mic is a truly great if it's recognized and properly configured by your system. Impressively clear recordings, unlike any I've been able to obtain using a Plantronics .Audio 655 USB Multimedia Headset or the mic on my Microsoft LifeCam Cinema 720p HD Webcam - Black. For the price, I don't think you can do better. It's compact, has great voice pick-up and audio recording clarity. Installation issues may occur, but updating audio drivers, using a powered USB hub connection and tweaking audio settings within the operating system should give you the quality you've been hoping for at a price that's right. UPDATE: 12/30/13 Been using this mic consistently for a couple months and I'm liking it. It's a condenser mic, and doesn't filter out ambient noise as well as I'd like, however for an under forty dollar purchase - I'm still very happy with it. Cakewalk never has registered correctly with my system so I uninstalled it. I guess if anything, that's been the downside to this purchase.
summary: Problems with Win 7 audio drivers, but once resolved, stellar performance

reviewText: Product works great. Brass sounds great.

Was highly recommended to me from my authorized Taylor repairman. Works well from what I can tell.

no complaint here, glad I purchased it.

Worth the money, such an enjoyable process bringing the raw wood to life... The neck plays well, it was easy to adjust the intonation, the volume/tone works well and the top stained well.  With great YouTube help made wiring and assembly easy and the guitar does come w a wiring diagram.  The guitar finish on the video looked so good I copied it!  Don't start with this one if your looking to build, the electronics and glued neck makes it a bit more tricky.  The headstock gives plenty of room to enjoy making an original design or buy a Gibson template online.  The black hardware makes this LP model so unique.  Like all DIY kits the parts are not top notch but buying these kits are for enjoying the build.  Heck no reason not to upgrade if it feels better than your name brand guitar.

My girlfriend used to play piano, but we don't have room for one in our apartment, so I bought her the Yamaha P115 88-key Digital Piano and FC4A Piano Sustain Foot Pedal. Set them both up in our bedroom and the result is amazing. The resistance on the keys is great, it feels like a real piano, and it's small enough to fit next to our bed in our fairly small bedroom with no issues. Audio quality out of the built-in speakers is pretty good, but of course we could always hook it up to a better sound output if we wanted. It was a little pricy, but it's worth it if you need a piano in a small space.

reviewText:
This little baby has been sitting on my desk for a few months now. Still works perfectly. Was easy to use. Came with a few plug-ins that I honestly don't use and Ableton Live Lite 8 that I do not use for recording audio but still a nice gem.
I'm using this with an Audio Techinca at4040 (microphone) and M-Audio CX5's (monitors) Works perfectly. No complaints about it whatsoever. Doesn't hurt that this thing looks amazing either.
Very nice uke just as shown in the picture. Excellent quality for the price. Nice warm tones, holds in tune well after a few tunings to stretch strings. Would recommend for beginner to more advanced.

I've used sabine, snark, and the original planet waves clip on tuners, and this is by far the best.  it's super tiny, has a really bright LED, and is very accurate.  one upgrade from the original PW tuner is that this does a fancy little LED dim so that you know it's turning off.  sounds stupid, but it's actually really helpful!  love this tuner, got a two pack and have them on my acoustics.
summary: Best headstock tuner i've used so far

reviewText: This tuner is just what you need for you banjo, guitar, or ukulele. You just leave it clipped on, hit the big silver button, and easily tune your instrument with the fast responding display, then click the big button to turn it back off. You can't beat the price and performance.
Very nice tone!

Man, I love this thing.  Gold hardware.  White binding.  Clear red finish.  This is a beautiful bass, and it is a perfect complement to my B.B. King Lucille copy.  (I took this out on a gig right after receiving it, and got a lot of nice comments on how pretty this bass is.)

The humbuckers have a twang that can be made to sound close to a Rickenbacher.  I love the short scale neck (works great with my stumpy fingers) .  The bridge is the most weighty bridge I have ever seen on a bass.  The short scale and the configuration of the bridge work great for palm muting and thumping the heck out of it.

The bass comes with round wounds that can be pretty rough on your left hand if you haven't been playing for a while.  I plan to change these out for roto-sounds, which are quite a bit smoother for one's fingertips.

Great value.

Update 7 months later.  I still love the bass.  After a 3 hour gig where I had been playing pretty hard, my finger tips were pretty sore.  So I checked the strings with a micrometer.  The low E string seems to be a .105 and the G strings measured at .048.  So I will be changing these out to a lighter gauge string, and we will see how that works out.  I'll update after the next gig.
I rate this a three because of my amp and set-up, not because of any failing of the chorus foot pedal. It was packaged well and was a fair price.
Hands-down the best Delay pedal I've ever owned I would recommend this to anyone. However battery life is limited and should be used with the DC power supply good luck. Rock on mama!

The common features are easy to use, but if you want to dig in and start really taking advantage of the amp, you will need to invest some time into it. Since I'm not scared of playing around in menus and reading the manual, this amp fits me well.)

UPDATED; Nov 11, 2017; This amp still works great and sounds great. I've been using it with a Zoom MS100BT going into the Spider Jam's Aux input lately. Nice Amp and glad I bought it years ago.

reviewText: I have been playing for 35 years, about 9 of them professionaly. I have also worked as a set-up man, and, made guitars both acousctics and hard body that people seem to really like. well made. very stiff foam in the seat. Have to use a thin pillow with it.

First of all, I was a little skeptical of buying a light in this price range due to the fact that many of the other lights in my stock are several hundred dollars, but I was looking for a decent light that had a wider beam angle and still contained the brightness I needed. For those that may be reading this wondering if it's worth a try, I would say YES. I have been impressed with the light so far. It is different than your typical Chauvet SlimPar(which I also use). This light has a wider beam angle and works well as a wash light rather than a "beamy" uplight in my opinion which is what I wanted. I compared it to my SlimPar 64s and these are the pros and cons of what I found:

PROS:
-While it's not a metal body, the hard plastic finish looks like it could take a beating( I wouldn't mistreat it, but just saying)
-The beam angle on the light is slightly wider than that of a normal SlimPar which I liked because I didn't plan on up-lighting with these anyway
-The All-In-One LEDs are far superior for your variety of colors rather than the individual LEDs where you would have color blending down near the light and the true color as you go up.
-I have to say that the brightness of the LEDs hold there own against any other LED Par fixtures and the dispersion is great as well(No hotspots)
-It's DMX capable with a variety of colors including a white which is beneficial
-It's got a built in fan for cooling that runs constantly(some would say a noise issue, but not for me as I will have music and sound while I'm using them anyway)
-They are a price friendly light and a bang for the buck!!!! If they have the life-span of the normal 50k-100k hrs, these are definitely worth the buy!

CONS:
-While the light is impressive, I wasn't impressed with the braces that hold the light. They're pretty flimsy compared to the thicker braces on my other fixtures. They work okay on the floor and while it's not a complete deal breaker for me, it would have been nice to have a sturdier bracket to use when hanging the fixture above.
-While this light does have the capability to daisy-chain to another fixture, there is no normal plug outlet like on the SlimPar. In order to daisy chain, you have to purchase a separate NEMA to IEC cord to plug in another light. I don't know why they don't supply one with the light, but that would have been handy especially if purchasing multiple lights.

All in all, the light is fantastic for the amount you pay for it and the brightness you get out of it. I purchased (2) fixtures as a test run before buying more, but I will say that I will be purchasing more as a cost saving measure! I would recommend them for sure.
summary: This is Definitely a BANG for your BUCK.....

reviewText:
I ordered the RODE Podcaster and needed a shockmount that would work with it on the first try. I could have found a cheaper third party solution, but to be honest I wanted my Mic to have the products that were designed for it. That's why I went with the PSM1. It's got a perfect fit for the Podcaster and Procaster mic's. No real complaints from it thus far.

The shockmount is made from metal and seems very well constructed. The area that connects to the boom arm is plastic and it could strip if not careful, but so far it's been the right choice for the Podcaster.

I love this.  Using it with a Kala U-Bass which I ALSO really recommend.  I should clarify that I am using it with the Bose Tone Match mixer and the Bose L1 Tower PA.  I'm also using it with a little JBL Charge2 (since they went on sale so drastically--what a great speaker).  It looks good.  Folds up nicely.  Surprised by the built in drum sounds so I can practice my Bass lines with ease.  Convenient.  Gonna buy another one for my regular ISA uke.
summary: REally really well made and great sounding.

reviewText: These are awesome! I do wish they were a bit cheaper so I can do my whole studio with them, but alternating between these and a thinner cheaper model makes it look great and you still get the same sound damping quality you need.

I actually purchased the 1/16 size violin. My daughter is 3 and loves it. I did some research and it's unanimous that you should not buy a violin that is too large. Be sure to size accordingly and don't buy a violin figuring your child will grow into it. Get the right size for them now and they can play it for some time. Too small is okay, too big is not.

This violin is so cute, it was difficult to not dip it in chocolate and eat it. Pretty sure it will be a wall hanging after she outgrows it.

For such a tiny instrument, it is a completely functional violin. My fingers are way too large to play much of anything on it, and my daughter is still learning how to do more than practice the open strings, but she can successfully play all the open strings individually (and we haven't had it a week yet).

FYI, If you get one of the How to Play Violin books (Suzuki, Essential Elements, etc...), they all have accompanying YouTube videos for all their lessons. A three year old is happy to watch those and mimic rather than listen to her dad tell her what to do.

Also, Kennedy Violins is a great shop. Very easy to communicate with. Great place to turn to start learning violin.
summary: Great things come in small packages

reviewText: very good quality,looks good and fits my silverface twin perfectly. Tried it on my pro reverb,fits well but slightly loose, well enough for me to buy another and keep it clean/protect from paint splash etc. Also priced reasonably.

These are great straps for $20, I own two of them. It's not a super nice and expensive leather strap, but it's perfectly functional and I feel that the designs look really cool. Also, the ends are solid and fit snugly on the guitar, it's actually pretty difficult to get them on at first. Because of the tight fit, I have no concerns about this thing falling off when I'm busy rocking out!

reviewText: Very, very good speakers for me, it has surely served my purpose as a bass speaker. I run 2 tens, 2 twelves and this 15 inch. Man it sounds good

adequate. inarticulate. uneven string amplification. the chord balance is dissimilar in alternate positions and fingering. also, not for use with inexpensive practice amps. better to use a mic setup for acoustic rather than this pickup.

That's what I bought it for, and it does it swimmingly. Thumbs up.

I make profiles of heads and cabs self-taught, sometimes, heads only. this unit gets that line signal nice and juicy to insure a great profile every time.

I can't comment on any other functions, as I only use it as I stated above, but again, works fantastic four my use. Very transparent, no sound coloration. Does not require the battery out any external power for my needs.

Big question- is this better than the Yeti USB version (pick your color) I honestly have to say YES.  I spent a few weeks (months?) using the Yeti USB for Let's Play videos on my youtube channel and honestly I noticed a huge difference in sound quality with the Yeti Pro.  I have set up the Yeti Pro using a USB mixer to better control sound and with the Pro to USB.  The warmth of my voice is great with the Pro.  They are both excellent options for plays, podcasts and instrument recordings.  The Pro is just a bit better.  I tried this with my acoustic guitar and some harmonica as well and the sound difference is amazing.  Straight into the PC or Mac using Audacity or more professional paid applications is the way to go if you want complete control of your sound.  Using something like GameCaster or BroadCaster is a cinch.  I can't praise BLUE enough for their excellent products.

reviewText: This is a GREAT !  little tuner!,.. It works every time...! I would make a hard shell case for it if I improved it in one way because it can be accidently turned on if it touches something when it's in the soft bag case and you won't see it. But overall it is an excellent tuner, and price....Thank you!

reviewText: I was using D'Addario Flattops on my acoustic and switched to EXPs over a year ago, because the Flattops wear out really fast. The EXP has great tone and lasts 3 or 4 times as long as a set of Flattops. The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is I put a set of D'Addario 80/20 Phosphor Bronze strings of the same gauge on my Guild and was really surprised at how bright they sound compared to the coated strings.

This is a pretty nice cable.  It's very cheap for the quality of signal it passes.  The lining looks nice, but frays easily - more easily than other wrapped cables I've had. Because of the long, rigid plastic/rubber end of the cable, this is more suitable for an instrument with a front jack plate.  It won't be usable for bottom-mount if you want to be able to sit down and play.

Overall, I'm very happy with this purchase.
Amazing, got to love novation for the amazing products.
I always recommend DAddario strings when asked.
Great deal, great strings!
summary: This is the best deal I've found on these. Great string!

reviewText:
This software is great for the producer or songwriter that is starting out and wants a basic, easy to use DAW.  It lets the user get a basic idea of how Live works, and get a sampling of some of the effects and instruments that Ableton offers.  That said, this software is called intro for a reason.

Unlike the full version of Live 8, Intro has limits on tracks (although it's pretty high), number of effects you can apply (12) etc.  Probably the biggest difference between this and the full version is that many of the brand new instruments/effects aren't included, like the vocoder, looper, "pro" warp mode, and others.

After demoing this alongside the full version of Live 8, I'm going to buy the full version instead.

I absolutely love this product for portable recording. I have a Dell notebook computer and have used this to record solo piano and my music lessons. The microphone pre-amps are pretty decent. I have used the mic preamps directly and have compared them with the same mics used through Grace One preamps. Surprisingly decent in comparison. The recordings of piano compared to a setup with a MOTU 828 MKII and Grace One's was really pretty good. I absolutely loved the large controls for gain on the top of the unit. Very easy to manipulate and more solid than other competitive product cheap knobs. The fact that this unit is USB 2 means that the recording quality can be far superior than USB 1.1 units that are going to limit whether you can do high quality recordings on multiple channels. The midi interface works great also in Acid and Sonar. The unit definitely will cause your laptop battery to drain faster if you are using mic inputs with phantom power but that is fine by me for the great functionality. Line in works fine but if I had any minor complaint it would be that it would be nice to have an effects insert interface. Obviously, this should not be a problem for line-in devices but is more of an issue for mic recording where you might want some outboard vocal processing. The headphone interface is good and I like the ability to use a mix between the computer and the external source into the headphones.
summary: A great product for the money

I'm using this on a bass rig - I play stereo and have two amps, one driving 4x10 and the other driving 2x15. I wanted to be able to use the hardware for when I'm not using the Rickenbacker, so I got this. I don't need the stereo, but use Channel A for both amps, sending <~170hz to the 15's, and everything else to the 10's. I was hesitant because I'd heard bi-amping wasn't all that it was cracked up to be, but this actually sounds excellent. Pulling that low end into the 15's, now acting as sub-woofers really takes the load off the main amp. Definitely need to play around with the crossover point and the Sonic Maximizer settings, but this definitely makes a huge difference with the amount of headroom available.
summary: but this actually sounds excellent. Pulling that low end into the 15's

First of all, I have a more expensive Saxony chromatic by Seydel. I like the sound of the Suzuki better both have great comfort of the mouth area. However, that being said the Suziki requires more cleaning at and you need to be careful to keep it warm so the wind savers do not stick. After a while and the slider on the Suzuki gets a bit stuck on first push when you pick it up (Ok after the first push) after not using it for a day. My Saxony has had 3 notes fail I guess from fatigue and the spring broke from fatigue so I have had reliability issues but I do practice a lot with it still it is less than 2 years old. On the plus side Seydel service is really excellent. I am not an expert but I would say that the stainless steel reads do not hold up compared to the brass in terms of fatigue. They have a different sound and the Saxony is louder. I practice on the Saxony and perform on the Suzuki. So I am not a stainless steel fan. Just got an Ozone cleaner by Ioncare, hope that helps. If I had to do it over, I probably would not have got the 4 octaves, but sometimes you run out of notes so it is good but may be hard to keep track if you are not playing by ear, that is finding where you are while playing. If you do get the Saxony, don't get the high pitch one (forget what that is called). It is too high and I was able to return it. I also own a Super Chromatic 64 which is another terrific instrument on the economic side. This is very bendable and love the sound and I would rate that highly. I also own a Honer CX12. Although this is not a favorate it has a good sound, is easy to clean and does terrific when it is cold as it has a plastic body.

NOTE: This review is not a review of the product itself, but the software and set-up process required to use the product. I received this device on a Saturday morning and spent more than 5 hours trying to go through all of the steps of downloading the accompanying software and setting up the device on my computer (s). Customer service is not available on the weekends. The software installation and setup process was a nightmare. The Focusrite website actually has very helpful videos walking you through the installation process, but unfortunately I ran into a variety of issues trying to install the software on two different computers (one PC and one Mac). Focusrite also has a variety of help-related videos on Youtube which also are very helpful, but I still ran into a variety of issues on both computers. After registering for every separate website from which I needed to download software, several downloads failed to load, on both computers, and my computers kept freezing through the process. Even if everything would have worked properly, the setup would have been extensive. I ended up returning the product mainly out of frustration over the amount of work it took to unsuccessfully set up the device. From what I have read and seen online, the device seems to be of very high quality but unfortunately, for me at least, I ran out of patience trying to make it work.
summary: Review of Software, Not the Device

reviewText: I first became aware of the EBow way back in the 80's when the song "Big Country" by the band Big Country came out. They used it to simulate bagpipes and I always loved that sound. I finally purchased an EBow about a year  ago. I'm a songwriter and record my own demos at home. I also perform live in a cover band. I don't use the EBow very often but when I do, it really adds to the performance. I recorded an EBow track for an original song in a passage where there was only acoustic guitar and it added another dimension to the overall sound and made my recording sound more professional. For live playing it can be a little tricky because sometimes it takes a few seconds to get the strings to start vibrating. With practice, I think this could improve. I play the solo on STP's "Sour Girl" and it sounds very much like the original recording. People in the audience tend to take notice during that solo and I get questions about how it works. I have not had good luck with arpeggios but again, practice could improve this. The octave switch is great for a controlled feedback sound. Battery life is exceptional. I have only had to replace the battery once. Overall, I think this is a great product. I wish it had been a bit less expensive but if I lost it, I'd buy another one.
summary: Adds another dimension to recording and live performance

reviewText: I have always found Ricos to be acceptable beginner reeds for students in their first year or two playing. Size 3 reeds are appropriate for students who have begun to cross the break. The provided plastic cases do a good job protecting the reed, as long as they are not pushed in too far. I usually move students to Rico Royal or Vandoran after their first full year or two. Amazon does have excellent prices on reeds - definitely recommend buying here - especially with Prime shipping!

reviewText: I bought this strap in the Amazon Warehouse for less than $15. It said "used" but arrived new and repackaged (which is typically my experience with Amazon Warehouse deals). What a deal! I wanted a wider strap for my Epiphone '58 Korina Flying V because it is a little neck heavy. I also bought a Levy's Leathers MSS2-4-BLK 4 Garment Leather Signature Series Guitar Strap,Black strap at the same time (also very cheap) to see which worked best for the V. This M4GF was the right strap for my Flying V. The suede underside keeps the guitar from neck dipping, and it no longer feels neck heavy when standing OR sitting. This strap is also very beautiful. The leather is very soft, and the strap is very flexible and fluid. For the Flying V, I like this strap hands down better than the more expensive MSS2-4. The MSS2-4 is also a very nice strap in its own right (see my review for that strap if you like); but, for the neck-heavy Flying V, this was perfect. The strap is actually 3.5" wide, and offers super stability. Since it has a suede underside, it is a bit hotter to wear than the MSS2-4 (which has a soft leather underside). If you play with your shirt off, you may want to consider how much you sweat and if a strap with a suede underside is right for you. For my purposes, this strap is just perfect. This will be my goto strap for all of my Flying V guitars without a doubt.

After tons of experimenting, I settled on the EXL116 for D standard and E flat standard. I've tried 10-52 but the top is a little too floppy for D and that makes notes sound out of tune if you don't press the string just right. Also tried 11-56 and while that gives a real solid and full rhythm tone, the attack is too rounded due to the pick taking longer to travel over a wider string. That reduces articulation. So while you get a fuller sound with the 56, you get more dynamics and attack with the 52, and the latter makes metal rhythms sound heavier. You can EQ fullness into a rhythm track, but you can't add in pick attack and greater dynamics.

Tension wise, at D standard 11-56 is ideal but 11-52 is doable. Sound wise, 11-52 has been best for my metal recordings and that's why I'm sticking with the EXL116 set from now on. I also replaced the G string with a 20 gauge wound for better sounding power chords. And compared to Ernie Balls, D'addarios start off less bright but maintain their brightness longer, thus a more even and predictable response over time.
summary: Great for D and Eb standard

It can be safely said that if you want to buy a student mandolin you could spend anywhere from $150 to $250.  Anything under $150  NEW will be a problem to learn on and that is fact.  It can also be said that if you want to buy a truly PROFESSIONAL mandolin you could spend as much as $3000 to $5000 and more.  However, if you want to buy AN ENTRY LEVEL PROFESSIONAL MANDOLIN don't go crazy....simply buy The Kentucky KM 505.  I have played guitar for over 46 years and mandolin for over 25 (on and off).  These days I am playing more mando than guitar.
I have recently been through more than a few mandos in my attempt to get back on track.  I went through an Eastman MD 304 and 305.  A Gretsch G9350 Park Avenue F4 oval hole and a The Loar LM 170.  I liked the Eastman and the LM 170 but the Eastman neck was too narrow but did have a nice radiused fretboard and the LM 170 had a wider, non-radiused fretboard which was okay but the V-taper of the rear of the neck WAS A KILLER ON THE WRIST.  The KM 505 has a nicely radiused ebony fretboard with the same 1 1/8th inch nut width of the LM 170 but with NONE of that horrible V-tapered neck.  The 505 has a more comfy rounded neck that is easy on the thumb and wrist.  The woods are all hand carved and beautifully grained (I have the lighter tea-burst finish version with the pickguard).  The binding is exquisite as is the pearl and abalone inlay on the headstock.  The tone is full and woody without any tininess (note the Eastman, The Gretsch and the LM 170 all had good tone as well).  But on consideration of all the attributes of a good mandolin the KM 505 stands out of the crowd.  This, for me, was a step up.  In fact, this mando should hold me until I can afford (if ever) an Ellis or a Weber...or maybe I will just stay with the Kentucky.  Buy one...you will not be sorry.  Please note:  I am not a bluegrass player.  I play in a band that covers Jug Band Music, old timey blues and folk.
summary: A REASONABLY, SANELY PRICE PROFESSIONAL MANDOLIN

reviewText: I purchased the Mustang V.2 after owning an original Mustang 1 for a couple of years and I love both of these amps. I have owned a few Fender tube amps in the past and I can honestly say the modeling is spot on (without the tube inconsistency) on the Mustang series. The Twin Reverb and Deluxe models are particularly accurate representations of the original amps. I run my Mustang V.2 through a Randall 4X12 cabinet that I re-wired for stereo operation and it sounds fantastic. The head runs 75 watts per channel in stereo so you get nice lush chorus effects with good separation if you run it on a stereo cabinet or dual cabinet configuration. The amp features a wide array of on-board effects which can be configured and saved as presets and accessed via the 4 button pedal which was included with my amp. You can also add another 2 button foot switch to run with the 4 button unit or run the two button switch with an expression pedal. So Fender gives you lots of options for configuring this amp to your needs. The included software is very functional and expands the amps capabilities even more. I use both the Ableton Live Lite Fender edition and Amplitube software and I get amazing near studio quality recording results running this amp directly into my laptop. The amplitube software is cool because it allows you to access the amp models by way of a graphic interface that is an exact reproduction of the original amp. I have used the amp in live gigs and it provides plenty of volume, while maintaining consistent sound quality at all times. I play a very wide range of music and this amp does all genres very well. Blues, Jazz and Metal are my main genres. The White Chapel preset is perfect for my 8 string guitar metal work. The Twin Reverb with a touch of chorus and my Stratocaster is a blues perfect tone and that only scratches the surface of what this amp can do. Take the time to learn what this amp's capabilities are, don't just settle for the presets. It is a truly great amp that does a multitude of things very well.
summary: Every great Fender amp ever made in one affordable, great sounding package.

reviewText: I purchased this speaker after listening to hours of reviews and samples from the Eminence site. Basically I wanted a guitar speaker that gave me a Celestion vintage 30 with tamed mids and a smoothness in the top end like American voiced speakers. Eminence hit the ball out of the park with this one! It gave me exactly what I was hearing in my head. I use it in a 2 x 12" sealed back cab with a Egnater Tweaker 15 or my Jet City 20 watt head modded for more clean headroom and a warmer tone.
summary: Value priced for such drastic tone improvement!

reviewText:
I got this guitar to use for travel, and practice, but I felt the quality of the sound was a little lacking.  I tried changing the strings, and it still sounded a little tinny.  Compared to my full sized dreadnought, the sound felt thin and at times as though it was heavy in the treble end, and lacking in bass qualities.  It also couldn't project nearly as well because of the smaller size.
I like to with fingerstyle and am going for a folk type sound, so I'm not hammering the strings with a pick.
I decided for the price, I would give the o-port a try, and I'm so glad I did.  I chose the small size in ivory to complement my pink sunburst guitar.  The sound hole measurement was the smallest option.
Installation was easy.  I loosened the strings (without a capo as the video suggests) and just spread them to the sides for installation vs. pulling the bridge pins.  It took some serious folding/squeezing and manipulation to get it in to the sound hole.  The ring is much larger than the hole, so that extra material has to go somewhere to get it in.  The piece is malleable plastic as described, but it has a rigidity to it as well.  I got it in just fine, but then had to use a thin tool (smooth end of nail clipper lever) to coax the part of the o-port that lacks a rim out of the guitar to fit along the inner edge of the top of the sound hole.  At first it kind of folded to the inside, and since there isn't a lip on that part, it stayed in until coaxed out.  I wasn't sure at first, but then I remembered it's job is to smooth out the interior of the guitar, and if there is a ripple of any kind it can't do that as well, so I worked it out.  It fits very snugly, I am glad I don't have any plans to remove it because I believe it would be a challenge.  It fits very snugly into the sound hole, and would be hard to find a edge to lift.
The final step was to tighten and tune the strings.  Total installation time was around 5 minutes.
Once installed, I immediately noticed a change in the sound.  So did my children, and they aren't musicians.  The guitar sounds richer and fuller as described.  The thin tinny quality I sometimes had seems to be replaced by tones and harmonics that are much more pleasing to hear.  The guitar is also louder.  I don't have to play as hard to get a louder sound.
Overall, I feel like my guitar just got an upgrade.  I don't plan to gig with this guitar, but I love how it sounds now.  For all of you who have a smaller sized instrument, consider an o-port if you want a passive, inexpensive way to improve and amplify your sound.
FWIW I'm currently using Martin Silk n' Steel strings.

Two weeks later, and a friend who had heard the Daisy Rock before the o-port heard it for the first time with the o-port.  They didn't know what changed, but noticed the guitar sounded much nicer.
summary: Noticible difference in my Daisy Rock Short Scale Dreadnought

reviewText:
I have owned my GT-R1 for about a year... As other's have mentioned, months after owning it, the input jack for a guitar (or bass) started developing problems. I was able to twist the cord in a way to make it work, but that soon ended, making the recorder impossible to record into through the input jack. Soon after that the volume control stopped working for recording... It would go down, but once down, would not go up... The record function through the built in mics still works, but now you are unable to hear what you recorded, because it only records at the lowest level possible, which is inaudible. Making my GT-R1 totally useless and garbage...

I love all the features, but it took a long while to feel comfortable with them.

Obviously the input jack is a design flaw, so I would not recommend buying this product unless Tascam designs an input jack that works and lasts more then a few plug-ins... It is made from cheap plastic.

I have not seen the volume control problem mentioned in other reviews, so it might just be mine, but this now makes my GT-R1 more cheap Chinese plastic garbage for the landfill...

I was struggling to advance my beginning-guitar skills with my Luna Safari Muse nylon 3/4 guitar, due to the narrow neck of the guitar and my broad fingers. I took a chance and ordered this Cordoba Cadete since the nut is wider but not quite 2", because my fingers are also short. I've only had it two days, but I'm really pleased with it. Not only does it look gorgeous, but it sounds amazing! Compared to the Luna, which has a nice sound, there is more depth to the sound - the bass is very good on this guitar. I'm finding it easy to play despite having small hands and short fingers (and am not too coordinated to boot!). The 3/4 body makes it very comfortable for me to hold, like the Luna. I can't get my arm around a full-sized acoustic bout without serious discomfort, but the Cadete is a perfect fit for me. Mine didn't come with a gig bag, but I had ordered a Gator case Gator GWE-ACOU-3/4 Hard shell Acoustic Case for my Luna, and the Cadete fits like it was made for it (it's a touch big for the Luna's body). Mine also didn't have strap buttons on it, but I had the seller install them. The seller - Calido Guitars - was great. They set up the guitar before shipping, and were very prompt at answering my questions both before and after ordering. And it arrived two days early! I highly recommend this guitar for anyone!

reviewText: I am truly a beginner when it comes to guitars.  I know the strings pretty well and the frets.  I know a few chords, but that's about it so far.  I just like how guitar's look. It does have the Trans Black finish, but it's not brushed on dark enough and it makes it look kind of green in the right light.  In the dark it looks well.  It has too many bare spots that weren't brushed like another reviewer said.  After waiting for the guitar and weighing the pros and cons, I decided to keep it.  The finish is kind of growing on me.  I thought it looked way too green at first, but now that I look at it, it looks fine.  Now about the sound of the guitar.  It sounds very very nice.  It has really clean sounds with the stock strings I think, unlike another reviewer.  I got some Slinky 9 strings though because I hear they are good.  I will use those for backup.  It does come with a cable to connect it, and 2 allen wrenches.  The cable is far too short I think so I bought another one.  I think it's only 10 feet long.  The guitar itself I think weighs less than my old Fender Acoustic.  That's saying something about this guitar.  I bought it mainly because of the finish and all the positive reviews it has on it's weight.  I remember an old beginner guitar and that thing weighed a ton.  I really like the weight on this thing.  So, after my short review, I would say if your looking for a great sounding electrical guitar that is pretty light with a good price tag, get this one.  If you want an all black finish I would continue your search.  I just found out they make an all black guitar like this one.

reviewText: I am not a general percussionist so I cannot speak to how well these work on timpani and other instruments that are normally played with mallets. I can vouch for how well these work with some drum kit applications. My primary use is for lower fundamental tom tom patterns. Compared to mallets specifically designed for drum kits like the Zildjian SDMDC Dennis Chambers Double Stick/Mallet Pair, hese have a much softer head that is absolutely perfect for music that requires a softer attack and/or more resonant notes. I actually use this and the Dennis Chambers model, depending on what I need to accomplish. However, when I need to be in the PPP to P levels these are perfect. These mallets will also work well with cymbal crescendos and diminuendos. If you are familiar with the song titled Harlem Nocturne, these mallets on a large ride cymbal will product the same effect. Another thing I like about these mallets is the balance I get regardless of whether I am holding them using French or American grip. The handle shape, weight and balance allow me to control my dynamics perfectly. The mallet heads need to be carefully handled when storing them in a stick bag because they tend to unravel a bit if you are careless with them. Overall these are a permanent addition to my stick bag and an important tool for my sound palette.
summary: Perfect for some drum kit applications

Movo WMIC80 UHF Wireless Lavalier Microphone... My system seems to have the same noise problem as other reviewers have stated. I decided to open each component up to see if any connections or wires were loose. I pushed all connectors to make sure they were tight. I Noticed one of the receiver antenna wires had been nicked by the screw on the side it was on, so I put electric tape around exposed wire. I also noticed the mounting screw was metal and exposed inside with no noticeable insulation(same on both x-miters also). As an added precaution I placed electric tape over this exposed part inside all 3 components. I put it back together, and it was crystal clear sounding on all channels on the first x-miter I tried. I tried the same on the other x-miter, but it remained noisy. I am able to used it at least, but only as a 1 x-miter system.
UPDATE: The one transmitter that I got to work is still working. I have been able to record my pastor a few times. added 1 star...

I'm giving one star here, not because of lack of quality, but because this company is so money hungry that instead of fitting US customers with the correct adapters, they send us the standard European mic stand sizes, which do not fit. I was headed for a recording session, excited to set this up, only to discover that I couldn't use it due to this.

Anyone from the US ordering this, you MUST order a 3/8-Inch Male to 5/8-Inch Female Mic Screw Adapter. You can get it here on Amazon, but make sure you get Ultimate Support 21600N Threaded Mic Stand Adapter. It costs a few dollars more, but all the other ones are fragile and will break from the weight of the RF-X.

UPDATE DECEMBER 9, 2013: I received the adapter, which got the Reflection Filter mounted on my US mic stand. What I didn't think of is the fact that I now also need a 3/8 female to 5/8 male screw adapter to fit my US microphone. In other words, make sure you also add that to your shopping list if you live in the US and have plans of ordering this filter.
summary: Does not fit US Microphone stands - had to order separately

I have read several other reviews on the Kala Solid Acacia Concert instrument and think it is time some things to rest so...
Before purchase I wondered about things such as the sound, the set up, and the quality of work done in the construction. Here are my insights in these areas but these are specific to mine.
1. The sound: My ukulele has a sweet sound that is neither overly warm NOR brassy. This quality can be varied with different strings (String Material such as Fluorocarbon, Nylon, etc. dependent) and as mentioned several times in other reviews, is "Spot On" for intonation.
2. The Set Up: I found that the Kala was set up at a great string height (I Researched the recommended string heights on line and was surprised to find Kala was at the mid point of the recommendations). One thing I have learned is that if the instrument is physically correct, you still need to "Fine Tune" the set up for your personal wants. The Kala allows this but straight from the box so to speak is outstanding.
3. Quality of work: Looking with a very critical eye I found nothing negative. The glue points had no over runs and all surfaces/edges were without flaws. The Tuning Machines were smooth and hold their position well. The inlay work is outstanding as well.

In a nut shell, my Kala would be a great deal at twice the price I paid, and I am totally happy with it.
summary: Well worth the money is an understatement...

reviewText: Looks great and does the job!
This was a gift for a friend who is a fan of the Beatles. He was very happy with his gift.

I am a vocalist in a cover band. Nothing serious. Still, we try to get our hands on the most decent equipment feasible. After reading some solid reviews for Samson's Q7, I was pretty excited to try it out; although, to be honest, my expectations were not that high. In my mind, based primarily on price point, the Q7 was in competition for air time with the Shure SM58-LC Cardioid Vocal Microphone without Cable. I have to admit, for all of the talk about how sturdy and durable the SM58 is as the go-to workhorse, the Q7 at least feels sturdier. I really appreciate the heft of the Q7. Something about the weight and contour is just more satisfying than that of the SM58. Of course, I have used SM58s that were well over ten years old, and I've just pulled the Q7 out of the box, so to speak; so the jury is still out on actual durability. As far as sound is concerned, the discernable difference I was anticipating between the SM58 and the Q7 never materialized. All in all, as a multi-purpose stable mic, I am happy to add the Q7 to the herd. Depending on how well the Q7 holds up, if faced with the decision to purchase a new workhorse mic in the future, I will probably choose the Q7 over the SM58 just to save a few dollars.

My daughter has some DIY synthesizer, drum machine, and delay effects boxes that use 1/4" connectors.  But she has a single amp.  This kit let her craft custom length cables to hook the components together in the way she wanted.

Crafting the custom cables isn't hard.  This kit comes with a tool to cut and prepare the cable.  From there, it's just a matter of attaching the jacks to the cable.  It didn't take long at all to do that.  The jacks are of decent quality.

We've had good luck with the Planet Waves line of products from everything from cables to guitar picks.  This kit is consistent with the quality we've come to expect.  It's a handy way to get short cables of the lengths you actually need.
summary: Good kit -- worked well to connect several DIY components to an amp

There is something special about this guitar. First off, it has a really nice weight to it. The satin finish on the body is what really sets it apart from the glossy versions, in my opinion. It gives the guitar such a better look. The neck feels great. And I mean great. Very smooth feeling when you're playing and running your hand down the length of it. The pickups are ok, I think they are meant to be changed anyway. They do sound great with the right amp though.

The inlays look dope, no complaints there. The head stock is nice too. The knobs are fine, the tone knob gives some variety for your sound, and the volume knob is simply that. No coil tap ability but that's fine. The strings go through the body, as can be seen in the pictures. It's a nice touch, and it does increase sustain. Obviously this is not something to rival the very expensive ones. But with the right upgrades, it has a really good chance to do so. I will definitely be keeping this one.

UPDATE: It has been about 9 months now that I have had this guitar. I still love it. Ended up changing the strings to 11s (Ernie Ball Power Slinky). For metal those strings just work better in my opinion. None of the guitar parts have come loose or apart. The inlays still look good as new. I was a little worried when I first got it that the headstock would break. This is because it is set at a slight angle compared to say a Strat-style guitar. I've traveled around with it in a hard case and softer gig bag, and so far no problems. However, I do treat my guitars as if they are my babies so that plays a big part. I still have no complaints about this guitar. The only thing I would change are the pickups but I get the sound I want by adjusting the amp settings, so it's not a big issue for me. Would still recommend this guitar for players of any level.

It seems cool, but it doesn't fit my Traveler Guitar Ultra-Light for which I bought it.  I suppose it is through no real fault of its own since the issue is that my guitar combines one of the end pins with the 1/4 inch output connector as one piece, so that the strap and a cable cannot be both connected at the same time, but if I had known this I probably would not have bought it.

So consider one star off not so much as a negative on the strap but more as a warning that when they say "fits virtually any guitar", it might not fit yours, for the above reason.  The  second star off is because to me, the connectors feel rather like cheap plastic.  If I get to use this on some other instrument for any length of time I'll find out if my impression of the plastic is confirmed or not.

Yes, I plan to keep it, hence the three stars.
summary: doesn't fit my Traveler Guitar Ultra-Light

I bought this as a "campfire guitar". An acoustic that I can carry on my bike, take to the park, take camping or to a party and not worry too much about having it damaged or stolen. I tried out several guitars at Guitar Center in the $100-$200 price range and this Yamaha won handily over other guitars in the price range I tried (such as Fender). When I bought the guitar at GC they gave me a new one still in the box. I took it home and found that the guitar creaked: the baffle was loose and applying slight pressure to the body made it creak. When I hooked up a strap and tried to play it I sounded as if I were standing on a creaky old wooden stair. I promptly took that guitar back to GC and asked them for the one on the shelf that I played. So: if you order this online take some time to really inspect it before committing to it, there may be some quality control issues from one to the next. That said I am otherwise quite pleased with the bang for the buck the guitar is giving me. I often take it to the park with me, and it has already suffered a cosmetic casualty that earned my son a good scolding but hasn't affected the playing. I put Ernie Ball Hybrid Slinky strings on it which are a custom 10, 13, 17,  30, 42, 52 and it's remarkably playable for "lead" as well as rhythm.
Great sound. Custom lights all the way! I feel this version sounds better with thin cut/lite wood guitars.
