This stand is probably one of the most popular among smaller bands, jammers and home studio owners because I run across them everywhere. And like everyone else I wound up with a few of my own. Here is what I have learned during the four or so years I have owned and used this model: - For the money they are a bargain and work extremely well in home studios and practice spaces (assuming the areas are not overly cramped.) - They hold up under light gigging and jamming, meaning they are not transported more than two or three days a week. - Good stability inside, even with heavier microphones like the Blue Microphones enCORE 100 Studio-Grade Dynamic Performance Microphone. Not so good outside if there is a fair breeze. I lost one to stepping inadvertently on one of feet, which immediately broke, and another has started binding when I try to extend or collapse the center pole. Those problems are not necessarily quality issues since in the case of the broken tripod it was my fault and not the gear's. As for the binding - I am sure that a good amount of grime has found its way into the tube after four years of use and transporting the stands. Had I taken better care of them those problems may have been prevented. For inexpensive stands these are hard to beat. However, I now use the Seismic Audio - Tripod Microphone Mic Boom Stand - PA/DJ/Band/Church/Wedding use, which I consider to be a superior stand for a small increase in price. Also, for outside use or when stage real estate is an issue I have found the old school style On Stage MC7201B Round Base Microphone Stand, Black to be a far better solution.

I really can't complain about this item. The build quality is fine. It is all plastic, the cord is not detachable. The jacks on the back side of it are gold plated, the headphone jack is not. As other reviewers have said, there is no software in the box, you get to go download it. I haven't used any of it, it's not what I bought it for. What I wanted to do was have a real mic and a real mixer and two separate sound cards to separate game audio and Skype audio. Yes, I know I can change this in the Windows sound manager, but I like having my analog mixer! As far as my uses go, this was perfect. I plugged it in, set it as my default communications device, plugged the main line out on my mixer into the input. It works perfectly, and people on Skype have noted that it sounds great. Out of curiosity, I unplugged my normal SoundBlaster X-Fi Pro card and plugged my headphones into output on this interface. It seems to have no troubles with my Sony MRD-V6 headphones, and it sounded every bit as good as my SoundBlaster. Now, it sounds DIFFERENT, but it's still good. The SoundBlaster's output seems to have more low end response where the Behringer interface focuses more on the high end. Now, the Sony MRD-V6 headphones are pretty low impedance, so high impedance headphones may make a difference here. But really, plug the line output into a stereo channel on your mixer and use your mixer's headphone amp. If you're looking for something you can plug your matching Behringer mixer into and record stuff or have a crazy setup for Skype, this thing is great. I could see this being used for some small recording, but it really doesn't seem like an overly professional device, having just unbalanced line inputs and outputs. For a professional recording, you might want an interface with XLR inputs. But, if you're in a small band and want to do some quick recordings, this can run from an aux send on your board. You may want to buy a couple Hosa Cable CPR201 Dual 1/4 Inch To RCA Cable - 3.25 Foot to plug this into your mixer.
summary: Does what it says it does

I mostly play guitar and only occasionally play bass, so I sometimes need a pick for fast moving passages on the bass. A regular guitar pick is too stuff and clicky for my playing, so I wondered if a softer (felt) pick would work better. I started to make my own felt pick but found that these pre-made ones were available. They work "okay" for my purpose, but not well enough to stick with them. The main problem for me is that only one side is felt-ish. The other side is stiff, much like a regular pick. So the pick provides the desired soft tone in one direction but not the other. I tried gluing two of them together (back to back) but the resulting unit was too thick for practical use.

I haven't given up on the concept of a soft pick for bass guitar. But a better design would be a very thin, flexible pick coated with felt on BOTH sides rather than only one.
summary: One side is soft, the other side is not

reviewText: To non players, and perhaps to some not-too-particular players, the idea of a "half step" in string gauge is possibly a notion of no use. For some of us who are in the .10 - .46 club and cringe at using 12's (SRV) or even 11's, the production of premium quality strings in a "half step" gauge is simply brilliant. Quite honestly, I've needed these for a long time. Top light, bottom heavy sets not quite right. 12's I can only deal with on my acoustic. For electric,  .11 - .49 is simply just too much work when bending, etc. (for my puss fingers anyway). Goldilocks tried the .10.5's and said "not too light, and not too heavy, they are just right". And the three bears danced till dawn!" Nice one D'Addario, cheers! GW

reviewText: It's rosin. You'd think it would be hard to screw up rosin, so five stars should be the norm to anything that didn't ship cracked or crumbly. Okay; I'm a beginner and I haven't enough experience to compare this to anything but what came in the box with the first violin. And compared to whatever no-name brand was in the box, this is a lot more sensitive. In fact, I'd almost decline to recommend this to a true beginner. I'm only just at the skill level where I can control the increased response this stuff is giving me. The tone to my ear is sweet, without too much high end, it speaks quick enough but isn't excessively grabby, and I get a great dynamic range off it. Although, like I alluded to earlier, with that increased range comes increased chances to a thin whisper or a gronk once you've wandered too far off from the speed/pressure zone. In short, this is exactly right for me now, it is helping me to learn (but I'm glad I didn't try to start on it).

I have recently joined a sixties era band and I needed a fuzz box to cover several of the tunes. A great pedal and a lot of bang for the buck.

reviewText: Better than erine ball strings

The Danelectro Honeytone Mini Amp - Beatnik Burgundy is an easy way to get great sound from your electric guitar. The color of this unit is a soft burgundy (almost brick red in color). Paired with the Zero Hum AC Adaptor, it's a highly portable amp setup. "Ultra-portable" by using a 9V battery instead of the AC adaptor. I do think they are best purchased together to enjoy all the benefits of this rig though. A headphone jack on the amp means you can enjoy the amp's impressive sound quality without bothering the neighbors or waking your spouse. Included with the amp is an Owner's Manual with simple start-up instructions. You'll need to have your own cord (the one that goes from the guitar to the amp isn't provided as part of the amp package...). The manual has several control settings for the following sound tweaks: -Clean & Spanky -Warm Jazz -Big Amp Overdrive -Killer Blues -Distorted Rhythm -Thick Solo -Woodstock Fuzz -Send the Cats Under the Bed -Twang -Mondo Sustain -Brit Solo Tune -Sparkle Clean -Early 80's Clean Solo -Late 60's Neck Solo -70's Brit -70's Solo I paid under $20 for this amp and couldn't be happier with the product. Don't hesitate to pick one up for yourself. UPDATE: 7/19/12 There is a space in the back of the unit for 1 9-volt battery Duracell 9-V Alkaline Batteries, 4-Count or you can use the included AC adapter to power the amp. UPDATE: 9/19/12 Per reviewer Paul Stewart: "As a point of clarity - the current version of this item does NOT ship with an adapter nor cable. Be prepared to purchase these in tandem." FYI... UPDATE: 11/17/13 Almost 4 years ago I bought this item, and it's still going strong! Great deal. UPDATE: 7/11/14 YUP! It's still kickin' along. Super buy on this mini-amp.
summary: Impressive Sound from an Inexpensive Source - UPDATE 7/11/14

reviewText:
Let me start off saying that you cannot go wrong buying any of the series of Mighty Bright music stand lamps.  The Orchestra lamp in particular is a fantastic product.  It provides plenty of smooth, even light and is sleek in design.  And the carrying case makes it very portable.  Fits best on flat metal, and has a tight clamp.  I have a portable stand which does not have a flat metal base...so I used a sturdy piece of foam board to clamp to...works great.  The unit uses three AA batteries. I started off using 3  batteries and they do work but light drops off within about four hours.  I prefer to use the 13 foot adapter cord.  I am an older person who has old eyes. Sometimes lower C and lower A look alike.  Mighty Bright Orchestra Light to the rescue!  The clip is also much larger than the image would let you believe; however, the base is curved to allow your music to easily lay on top.

Some comments have indicated that when plugging the AC adapter into the base apparently did not disconnect the batteries as expected. The unit I purchased does disconnect the batteries upon insertion of the power cord into the clip. To confirm this on your unit: (1) DISCONNECT the AC adapter from the wall and from the light, (2) load batteries into the clip, and turn on the light, finally (3) with the AC adapter STILL DISCONNECTED from the wall outlet, plug the cable into the base. The light should go out. If it doesn't, your unit is not isolating the batteries from the AC adapter, and may present a fire hazard if the batteries are installed when the AC adapter is plugged in.

The mic requires phantom power and once I compensated for that it worked. My previous mic did not require that. The headset is comfortable, flexible and stayed in position. The inline preamp is the least comfortable aspect as it does have some weight and you must attach it to your clothing by the included clip. It's too heavy to let the preamp hang. A woman may not have a belt or pants pocket to attach to. There is no included pouch or case with this mic, and you may want to acquire a carry case, & xlr cable as accessories. The sound quality and features met my expectations and so I'm satisfied with it.

Ive been very happy with the Planet Lock guitar straps.

My review is a little different than most.  I am an older guy who started playing the guitar way back in the mid-60's. Then, for forty-something years, I stopped playing because I was busy paying the bills.  Now that I have a lot of free time on my hands, I decided to start playing again.  I didn't want to "start small" and then spend more money on upgrades later.  So, I bought a 2017 Les Paul Standard (Blueberry Burst) and a Marshall DSL40C amp right out of the gate.  Not cheap, but it's a beautiful combo.  The point I wanted to make is this:  This amp is HEAVY and bulky.  Not just "kinda heavy".  It is heavy.  I'm in decent shape for my age.  Yet, I struggle to move this amp around my house.  If you plan to move this amp from room to room, from gig to gig, or to & from your buddy's garage, I hope you don't have a bad back.  Even the young guy that delivered it said, "Man this thing is heavy".  Also, it has way too much power for a bedroom or living room.  It's overkill for my situation.  Yeah, I know what you're thinking.  You're thinking that I should have known this before I bought it.  Well...like I said...I'm an old guy and I'm just now getting back into playing.  So, cut me some slack.  Performance-wise, it's a 5 star.  For portability, it's a 2.  Overall, I compromised and gave it a 4.
summary: It's heavy, but sounds great.  And oh, did I say it's heavy?

reviewText:
Disclosure, I own an iRig Pro, but I did not buy it through Amazon.

The iRig Pro works as advertised. It has an elegant design, but it is also quite rugged. The microphone & instrument pre-amp is quiet & clean.  The MIDI IN support is a great bonus. You get all the interface cables needed to hook up for MIDI IN (DIN to 1/8"), iPad (Lightning or 30-pin to DIN), iPhone (Lightning or 30-pin to DIN) and MacBook (USB2 to DIN). It uses a 9V battery (included) to provide phantom power for a condenser microphone. It plays nice with Garageband, MainStage 3 & Logic Pro X.  While it doesn't charge an iPad or iPhone, the iRig Pro appears to draw very little battery power when operating off their internal batteries. Overall, iRig Pro is an excellent tool for iPad & MacBook Pro/Air users to create music on the go.

Now for some cautions:

The iRig Pro does not have a built-in headphone amp, thus direct, no-latency monitoring is not possible. In use, overall latency is slightly present, but tolerable.

As others have pointed out, the provided I/O cables are flimsy and semi-proprietary. If you have a bad cable, you are pretty much chained to buying a replacement from IK Multimedia.

Yes, iRig Pro comes with "free software", but these are stripped-down versions of their established packages such as Amplitude and SampleTank. They are designed as "entry-level drugs" to get business for their expensive add-on packages of effects and instruments.  And no, Amplitude or SampleTank are not appropriate substitutes for good DAW software. The last time I checked, if you need a DAW, the Garageband app is just $5 (yes, I know it used to be free!) and it works fine with iRig Pro.

BTW, the computer devices I am using the iRig Pro with are iPhone 6, iPad (1st Gen.) and MacBook Air 13.3" (2013-vintage). The operating systems are iOS 8, iOS 5.1.1 and Yosemite.
summary: The iRig Pro is a great tool for music creation on-the-go

Nice quiet pickups. Super light. BONUS: it makes you seem like a larger person than you really are, since it's that much smaller than a standard sized bass. Delightful silver finish. NOTE: if you are actually a fairly small, diminutive, elfish sort of person, onlookers might see you with this bass and mistakenly assume you are farther away than you really are! This could be handy if, for example, you have the farts, and they are within nose-shot of you, but they'll never know it was you because they'll mistakenly assume you're too far away to be the culprit!

If there were a FRETLESS version of this, or a short-scale neck readily available from a third party to make it fretless, I'd be even more stoked. That's just me. But there isn't. Anyway, music always sounds better with bass notes, and this is your bass note producing MACHINE right here.

reviewText:
For years I heard how great these are, but never wanted to spend the extra money. Finally gave them a try, and I will never use anything else. I have a cheaper acoustic and it sounded dead and lifeless with regular strings. Put these Elixirs on and now it sounds like a much more expensive guitar. They're extremely comfortable and keep their sound twice as long as a regular string, so I feel that I'm saving money in the end. And either way, if you can spend a little more and make your guitar sound way better, why wouldn't you? They have seriously increased my enjoyment of playing.

One caveat, if you completely de-tune your strings and tune them back up, it can mess with the nanoweb coating. I did this a few times and the coating started coming off the strings. So just be aware of that.
summary: The only strings I will use

reviewText: While it is entirely possible to string a resonator guitar with regular acoustic guitar strings, there really is something to be said for using a set of strings specifically designed for a resonator guitar.  This particularly is true if you are going to play lap style slide guitar, because of what they will allow as far as pressure of the bar against the strings, and because of the tonal depth.  When I ordered the D'Addario EJ42 set I was surprised--pleasantly--at the price.  It turns out that these are very good strings:  they hold their tuning quite well and the set has a nice balance from string to string in tension and tone.  They can be used on a round-neck resonator for a combination of fretting and slide playing, but because some players might find them a bit heavy for fretting, they probably are most ideal for square-neck, lap-style playing.  Because the music stores in my area don't routinely carry resonator strings, and because the Amazon third-party vendor from whom I bought the strings offers free shipping, these D'Addarios will be my first choice the next time I need to change strings on my resonator guitar!

Just got this a week ago and I am generally delighted with it.  One caveat.  I read some of the other reviews and several people remarked that the shaft attached to the desktop would not remain extended if too much music or other weighty items were placed on it.  Based on that analysis, I ordered the recommended Manhasset ShaftLock Model 2400.  When it arrived, I attempted to install it, but it became very obvious that the design of the shaft lock is incompatible with the M51 music stand.  There is a tiny slotted screw on the shaft lock which is supposed to be tightened to the extent that the shaft lock will bind to the black tube below.  You can then turn the twist sleeve on the shaft lock left or right to raise/lower on the one hand or lock the chrome tube in place.  Sadly, since the shaft lock does not bind to the lower black tube, the whole concept fails.  It was annoying enough that the shaft lock had to be separately ordered and arrived several days later.  It was even more annoying to waste the time trying to get it work.  I called the Best Service Store phone number (the people who shipped the shaft lock), but they did not answer the phone or respond to a voice mail message.  I then called Amazon and they quickly sent me a shipping label to return the item and I will receive a credit after it arrives.

As I nearly always play sitting down, it is not too disappointing that I cannot raise the desktop with any significant amount of weight on it.  For that reason, I chose to give the unit 5 stars.  It is a really a pleasure to use, having used a smaller stand for years.  Someone who plays on their feet may well feel differently about the rating the product deserves...

When comparing the Sennheiser e 835 to the popular SM58, it's a better microphone in most situations. The pickup pattern is tighter and the frequency response is fuller. It probably has the ability to handle a higher sound pressure level also, but most won't care about that.

The pickup pattern is so tight that you will usually want to be within an inch of the windscreen, but this is why you won't get feedback as easily from it. Well, you know how you have to work the mic to adjust for louder and softer, now you'll just be working it at a closer distance, just remember to roll off the lows to reduce the proximity effect. But this is probably just it's biggest benefit of many, although it also makes it a bad choice for using one mic in front of three singers.

This microphone speaks of quality and durability in your hand, it's solid and heavy. The handling noise is excellent for those of you using this as a hand held microphone, it's quiet. It's frequency response drops down to 40Hz, making it an excellent choice for an instrument mic also. This will do a good job on close up work with guitar cabs to brass, providing excellent rejection of other sounds, The bottom of a snare or anyplace that you want a high rejection ratio, and can also fit this size of microphone.

So for those of you looking for it double as a recording microphone, because where you are recording has a high noise floor, it will work out well also. Being a studio owner, I suggest the quietest possible place to record and a low noise floor, but I know that it's not always possible. It will do a great job of rejecting other sound and focusing on what it's in front of.

You'll get a good clip and an average carry bag with it.

It's a good, high quality microphone at a fairly low price, and I can recommend it.

I have tried a few Sennheiser wireless systems and this is my favorite and for my purposes the most flexible for use on Flamenco Guitar. I primarily use this system with a DPA 4099g mic with a YPA micro dot Sennheiser adapter.  The sound is  incredible and of course tone is whats most important. Ease-of-use very easy plug in the batteries turn it on and its ready to go while some might complain that there is no AC power supply for me the ability have a receiver that uses batteries to use on location where there is no power such as a battery powered amp is a plus .  This system allows for completely uncluttered guitar performance I can clip on my microphone and transmitter and then put the receiver wherever the sound system XLR input is our use Bose L1s & Compact systems, QSC, Behringer, and others.  For me this system is a keeper.  I first tried the XSE2 system  there was too much total degradation and noise .  Then the ewD1  The sound quality was very good but there were too many dropouts .  The ew112-p G3 even with one antenna is a dual  diversity receiver uses one of the wires that goes to the output as an additional  antenna.  The HDX compander offers crystal clear sound. Both the transmitter and receiver are in a sturdy metal housing.
summary: Sennheiser EW 112p G3 Wonderful for Flamenco Guitar w DPA 4099g

reviewText: I use this with a wired headset while playing drums.  It works as I expected - when set to OFF, no noise comes out of the PA when I unplug the headset from it so I can take a break or whatever.

Hard to get excited about a power strip, but this is one fine no-nonsense item that delivers on noise reduction, makes all the rest I own feel like dog toys.  This thing is a metal-cased brick that will not brick your electronics.  Would complain the power lead is too long, but am sure that helps more folks than it hinders.

Bottom Line: These strings truly do have most of the smooth playing feel of a set of flat wound strings, though not completely as smooth. (The outer winding surfaces were made as normal round wounds, then the outer surface was ground down until the surface was flat-ish.) Yet the tone of these strings retain a noticeable amount of the brightness and overtones of round wound strings. The best of both worlds on a bass if you ask me.
Very Important!: These medium scale strings fit my Hofner Club bass perfectly.  The heavily wound portions of the strings run from below the archtop's floating, rosewood bridge and then, just past the nut of the bass, these strings quickly taper down to where they DO fit into the holes of the guitar tuning pegs Hofner uses on its basses. The E string's taper at the top is just enough that it fits snugly into the E tuner's post hole.  The other strings, of course, fit into their tuners with more ease. This bass is a joy to play, and the feel and tone of these strings have increased my enjoyment of playing it.
I was given a Hofner Ignition Series Club Bass for Christmas, though I got it early.  The Club bass is made in the same manner of hollow body construction as its more famous Hofner Violin or "Beatle" bass brother, only the Club bass uses the same Les Paul-ish shaped, single cutaway body as the Hofner Club guitar. The natural tone of these hollow body basses has a distinct thuddy, woody character resulting in a tone more akin to the tone of a large acoustic double bass than does any Precision or Jazz bass.  These Hofner basses are 30 1/4 inch scale (15 1/8 inch from nut to center of twelfth fret) basses for which there are notoriously few choices of string sets because of the extra string length needed from the bridge to the trapeze tailpiece.  I have wanted a Hofner Club bass for over twelve years (when I first laid eyes on one of these sunburst beauties being played by Kurt Smith of Tears for Fears) and I finally got one; even if it is the $350.00 Chinese version rather than the $2300.00 German original. (The bass's manufacture, finish, and workmanship are simply amazingly close to perfection! I'm truly impressed with the workmanship.) However, I really liked the sound of this Club bass with the included round wound strings. Sadly, the winding end of the factory strings were coming unwound somehow and the A string broke at the tuner, necessitating this string purchase. On my other bass I have long used a set of D'Addario ENR71 "Half Round" bass strings and love them.  If the Hofner Violin and Club bass users on the bass forums are to be believed, the vast majority of new Hofner bass owners immediately on delivery remove the round wound strings installed in the factory and replace them with LaBella or other brands of flat wound strings.  I guess the idea is to get as close to Paul McCartney's unique thumpy bass sound as possible. I'm different, and am loving the thumpy AND bright overtones, and feel of these D'Addario ENR71M medium scale strings on my new short scale Hofner Club Bass.
summary: I LOVE the tone (and feel) of these (ENR71M) half round, medium scale strings on my Hofner Club bass.

reviewText:
I wish they still sold hardshell cases for autoharps, but I haven't seen one in years.  Gig bags just aren't any substitute for a well-padded, solid plywood case.

As gig bags go, though, this one is pretty good.  It's basically a canvas gig bag built over a Styrofoam shell.  Not quite as good protection as a hardshell case, but better protection than a bag alone.  The case is considerably over-sized, being a good 8 inches longer than the autoharp itself; that extra length is taken up by a sizable internal compartment for picks, straps, etc.  Personally, I would have preferred a smaller case with a smaller compartment, but this is what's available these days.

The case is lined with black fake-fur, the closure is by way of two zippers and a Velcro handle clasp.  The case comes with a strap that can be used to carry your cased instrument like a backpack.

The internal dimensions are a little sloppy -- the internal cavity that accepts the chord-bar assembly was a little bit "off" in my case, and I have to wiggle the instrument around a bit before I can close the lid on it.  Since this is an Oscar Schmidt case, and my instrument in an Oscar Schmidt autoharp, the only reason I can image for the slight ill-fit is sloppy manufacturing and quality control.

Still, the harp does fit in the case with a little fussing, and you have to have a case, and the price is reasonable, as these things go.
If they make the fit a little neater, I'd give them another star.
summary: Decent quality, semi-hard gig bag; not too expensive

Clipping onto the rim might take a minute or two, but it is no problem. The adjustable clip mount is convenient. The material is mildly flexible, like a firm rubber, so there is very little risk of breaks if your drummer is wild and hits it (God forbid), but that means it is very wobbly and you will see your mic moving back and forth. HOWEVER, there is no noticeable change in the sound because of this. To my ears, at least, the tones and levels are consistent throughout tracking. I've used an SM57 and Audix i5 with this and both are long and kind of heavy which I'm sure contributes to the wobble.
It does stand several inches above the snare, which I can imagine can get in the way of a drummer moving from snare to hihat or whatever the situation may be if they have a tight kit, where just a level boom stand sneaking in between the drums would actually be better. In my opinion this is worth getting just to have as backup or as an alternative to have a clean kit micing setup and to set aside an extra stand.

UPDATE:
A client I was recording had to remove the clip during the session to adjust his snare and tried to clip it back on himself, resulting in a snap in the curved part at the bottom of the photo. Guess the device is not as flexible as I thought! Not sure how much pressure he put on it but he must have been confused on how to attach to the drum. I decided not to buy a replacement since I have 3 On Stage DM50 clips that are sturdier metal.

Are you tired of playing guitar alone? Me too. None of your friends keep up with their instrument? Mine neither. Nobody wants to jam with you? Not anymore. Who needs friends to jam with when you have this pedal. It LEARNS what you play. It's like Artificial Intelligence playing with you. Just lay down some chords (in the common time, or 3/4) and it will lay down some bass and drums that you can adjust. Then you can twiddle with how the drums and bass sound some more with the knob. The styles all sound very different for each genre.

I had a rather frustrating experience trying to get all my pedals set up and run through this. I found you can't put anything in front of it. And it seems to like having its own power source. It also doesn't seem to like a lot of pedals connected to it. I'm \having the best luck running it to a separate amp using the second output. It sends the bass and drums there. For my guitar, I'm running running a Ditto x2 looper and a crybaby wah and it's incredible how much sound you can make with one person.

If you really want to experiment, get better and just enjoy playing music again because you're sick of playing alone, get this pedal. You will more than likely enjoy it.

I bought this and returned it the next day. I was fortunate enough to purchase a Danelectro Dan-echo for my first ever delay pedal, way back when I started buying guitar pedals a couple decades ago (thank you random music store salesman). I'm still not sure that anything out there emulates the 60s-era tape echo as well as the Dan-echo. It's lush and warm and perfect in every way. So..  I thought about buying one of those again. But, my combined love of all other MXR pedals (they really do things right most of the time) and having seen so many positive reviews on this pedal, I decided to grab this. I also liked the slimmer design and my pedal board space is nearly maxed out.

I plugged it in and as expected, the tone was beautiful and the more I played with it, the more I liked the sounds I was getting, and then..  I kicked in the distortion. What the heck happened? I started checking all my settings, trying to figure out where I went wrong. No matter what I did, it was horrible sounding. I started researching online and finally realized this simply doesn't work for distortion no matter what you try. It's a "clean sound" pedal.

This has me perplexed as to the number of 5-star reviews and I have to wonder if many people just get this as their first delay pedal and think this is the way it is for all delay pedals?  It's not!  The best part of owning a really good delay pedal is turning it on during a solo after kicking in the distortion. It's about getting that big John Petrucci delay sound - putting air around all the notes and getting a sound that makes you want to stay in your room and play for hours. You will never come close with this pedal.

I emailed my Sweetwater rep with my finding and he replied with the same response.. "oh yeah, definitely not you want for soloing". He recommended the Faux Tape Echo v2. I started to decline and go look for the Dan-echo that brought me so much joy years ago but the one thing about the Dan-echo is that plastic pots are used and they break on every one of those pedals ever made. If you play and gig a lot, you can get about a year out of them - 2 if you're lucky. If they would ever replace that with a metal part, they would be gold. The Faux Tape also had one other feature I was really interested in.. tap delay.  Tap your foot to the beat of the song and click it on and you've got a perfectly timed delay every time. I checked out some vids (with distortion) and loved what I heard. I ordered and have never looked back. The Echo is perfect for that sound I was looking for. I'll say it's 95% of the sound the Dan-echo gave me and that's darned good.

So I'm giving the Carbon Copy 3 stars. MXR makes quality stuff and this pedal is no exception. I also realize that many will simply want/need a "clean sound" delay only and for this, I couldn't recommend a pedal anymore. It's beautiful on clean sounds and everything I had hoped.

I hope MXR buys a Dan-echo someday and tries it out for a dirty solo. They'll quickly realize what the Carbon Copy is missing and no doubt, they could create an even better sounding pedal than Danelectro did all those years ago.

SUMMARY: Get the Carbon Copy if you want a great clean sounding delay. If you play a harder style of music and want to add delay to your solos, this is not the delay for you.
summary: Great for Cleans and Terrible for Dirty.

reviewText: Can't be beat for the price. Simple, protects your guitar. Color is more of a black walnut color than whatever is in this particular photo.
Sounds great!

I picked one up on December 5. I liked the fact that this model has no robotics tuning feature, just plain Kluson type tuners with the tulip shaped knobs, stamped "Gibson deluxe"

The heritage cherry finish comes in the so called vintage gloss. This is not the smooth, shiny deluxe Gibson finish, nor is it a 'satin' finish. Somewhere in between, and the surface is grained just enough to show the unpolished slab of mahogany tree it began life as. I have seen a lot of SG's made this way and not just the stripped down Specials. The back of the neck is oddly a lighter shade of red than the back of the body. It shows clearly in the Sweetwater photos. Again, many of them seem to have been painted this way for some reason.

I like the crme colored pickup rings and switch plate. I guess the max grip knobs are OK. I am not a guitar snob, so no need to run out and change the knobs back to the classic style right away. Also, I have great expectations of the new cold treated fret wire for hardness and durability. I would much rather replace worn strings than worn frets.

Right out of the box I did some fingering all up and down the neck, picking and chording, unplugged. THAT's when I knew I was right. A non- chambered solid body will carry sounds better than a weight relieved body. It only makes sense. With the SG plugged straight into a Vox 15 watt tuber, I couldn't believe the amazing sounds. I knew that Pete Townshend, Robby Krieger and Angus and Tommy had to be on to something good. Mine has Gibson 490 T and R pickups. They are perfectly balanced in volume and tone. This guitar plays circles around my Les Paul Studio Pro which cost way more. I repeat, the LP's 'modern weight relief' mutes volume and tone on the high end, which is a common complaint, I am learning (the hard way).

These push pull coil switching volume controls are useless to me, just a gimmick, like self tuning tuners, IMHO.

My new SG Special is becoming my favorite playing guitar. I also have a Gibson Les Paul Junior Special with humbuckers that I play the hell out of, another non chambered slab of mahogany that sings out loud and clear. The 2014 SG special like mine now costs $350.00 more than the SGJ, for which I got a slightly better paint job (same exact neck, by the way). Next year's model will cost even more (by $200.00) for essentially the same thing. Prices have risen so fast in the last 2 years for Gibsons, and all I want to do is play guitar music.
summary: Not so much to look at but, MAN what a sound!

reviewText:
Like the previous user said try other options. I have the Shure SM58 along with this usb adapter. It's not bad for a first usb adapter made by Shure. However, I do not recommend this product except if you extensively work on your laptop. It's heavy and the four controls can be messed up easily. The X2u has a latch that secures the XLR connection pretty well. On the negative side, I would seriously recommend using duck tape for both the four controls and the base of the X2u. If you don't the Mic Gain control (like the other controls) will be either too high for recording or too low since three of the controls are not secured when one holds this heavy adapter. Tape up the controls when you get the standard settings for good wave file recordings without the hiss.
The base of the X2u seems to loose connection too often with the cable, thus ruining recordings.  This adapter sound quality is just not that clear. The Mic Monitor function is excellent feature but if you get this, "use electrical tape or even duck tape" for the background hissing noise and ideal control settings. A XLR cable adapter to a quality external sound device may be your best option for both laptops and desktops.

Shure has been making excellent products for a long time but this product is not what I expected it to be in terms of quality.
summary: Just not that good of product for a Professional XLR Microphones

reviewText:
A year or so ago I bought a Boss Micro-BR for portable and home recording, and after fighting with it for a few months, I sold it. It worked well enough, and had a lot features, like built in effects and drum tracks- but it was way too complicated to use. Every time I took it out it seemed I had to review the manual. Even when when I thought I had the functions all sorted out, it was easy to get confused, with all the menus and sub-menus. I sold it after a few months. Why couldn't they make a cheap multitrack recorder that was as easy to use as the old Tascam cassette-based Portastudios?

Enter the DP-004. While it's not as easy to use as the old cassette units, it's pretty easy- and it does a lot more than any cassette deck ever did. It doesn't have effects or drum tracks (it does have a metronome function) but it does have a lot of knobs and buttons where the Micro BR used menus, and it has two microphones- making it a great portable stereo recorder.

The DP-004 does have menus, but once you've set the parameters for a session (inputs, track assignments) you can pretty much ignore most of them until it's time for mastering, and even then it's not too complex. Most of the time you can just use the default settings. Live stereo recordings using the built-in microphones can be done with the DP-004 right out of the box: Punch record on tracks 1 and 3, adjust the levels, and hit the RECORD and PLAY buttons. That's it.

I find myself using the stereo recording function even more than the multitrack capability. It's great for recording practice sessions (or school concerts, for you parents) and yet costs about the same as a lot of the two channel recorders.

It's not perfect. I'd prefer less menu functions and more buttons and switches, but I suppose that would have raised the price and made it larger. Battery life could be better, too, but an AC adapter works well at home. (Hint: Use the Sony PSP100 power supply, which can be had for a fraction of the price of the Tascam unit.) For the money, it's pretty hard to beat.
summary: The easiest to use of the new multitrack recorders

I have three other acoustic guitars in addition to my new Recording King: a 1970s Guild D35, a 1970s Gibson Gospel, and a Taylor Big Baby. All great guitars, but I wanted something smaller than the Big Baby, for travels, and I was also interested in finding a guitar with less bass, and more of a midrange sound- like the older, small, guitars that this one is trying to copy. I did a lot of on-line research, and a number of people suggested looking for a used Recording King RP-06, a similarly sized guitar but one that has rosewood sides and a slotted headstock, like an old 0-16 or 00-18 Martin. Better sound at not much more money, they said. But I liked the look of the RPH-05, and when I found a used one in "like new" condition at Amazon for $140, I grabbed it.

First impressions: This is a good looking, solidly built guitar. I read about problems in fit in fit and finish in other reviews, but the one I received is almost- but not quite- free of any flaws. The frets are all finished nicely at the ends, there's no finish overspray, and the neck arrived perfectly adjusted. The binding looks better than what I've seen a lot of more expensive guitars. One problem: The Twelfth fret was just a tad high under the low E, which resulted in a string buzz when fretting Db to Eb. I could have returned it- I suspect this was why my sample was a discounted return- but instead I spent a few minutes with a fret file, and it sounds fine now.

The neck has an old-school chunky feel to it- not huge, but significantly thicker than a lot of modern flat tops aimed at crossover electric players.  It really deserves a decent case- although a decent hardshell case will cost you almost as much as the guitar ;-) It is a bit heavy, compared to other guitars this size, probably because of the heavy bracing on the back and top.

Sound-wise, it's just what I was looking for. It doesn't have the boom of a dreadnaught, or even the deep bass of my Big Baby Taylor. It has a very balanced sound, with the basses and the trebles being equally loud. It records well, and sounds great fingerpicked or strummed. Thanks to the solid top you can strum it pretty hard and still get good tone- a friend who has an old Kalamazoo of a similar size and look thought it compared well. I wouldn't necessarily recommend this as a first guitar for a beginner, despite the low price, unless they were specifically looking for the 1920s-30s sound. But if you are looking for that sound, or if you're looking for a travel guitar with a bigger sound than a Martin Backpacker, this is a great choice.
summary: Good sound and a 1920s vibe in a compact package-  at a bargain price

reviewText:
I've never had good experience with VHF wireless micro system in the past.  Maybe it was because I live in the metro New York City area where wireless signals are crowded.  However, I'm quite surprised with this set of microphone in terms of sound quality and connection stability.

It's five star for the sound quality, but I remove one star for the product design and built quality.  First of all I don't like 9v batteries; they are expensive, not as readily available and not interchangeable with most other devices.  In this day and age where wireless systems using AA batteries are available, I would pay more to avoid 9v systems.

Secondly, the power on off switch is inside the battery compartment, just right under the battery cover.  That means you can't turn it off unless you remove the battery cover.

Thirdly, the switch on the outside of the microphone--at the normal position where most microphone switch are located--is just a mute switch.  The problem with that switch is that it is so sunken that you can't easily switch it on and off.  You have to pry it with your nail to move the switch.

Some might deduct several stars for the weaknesses I mentioned above.  However, in most actual usage, the system is managed by a sound professional who will give the microphone to the speaker or vocalist that doesn't need to know how to switch off or mute the microphone.  So in most situations this is not a problem.  In fact some sound managers might prefer that the power switch is hidden, so that it wouldn't be accidentally turned off by the user.

In general, I would recommend this system for the price, for getting four microphones, and for reasonably good sound.
summary: Great Sound with some Minor Weaknesses

reviewText:
OK, the whole band bought these things - one of the guys made a bulk order. The light seems great and looks as though it will solve our problem because snaking extension cords for 16 players is a nightmare. Those 9 LEDs really put out. This happened after one of our poorly lit gigs where my tiny Mighty Bright Duet with its little antennae was the only respite. Afterward I researched better options, then as I said one of the guys took the lead to get them.

The question: An adapter is supplied that apparently serves as both charger and on-the-grid power supply. But the directions say very clearly "Caution: When charging, please make sure the switch is in the OFF position. If you turn on the light when charging, the AC adapter will be easily damaged by strong electricity. Please be careful with this operation."

So those instructions would seem to eliminate AC, plugged-in use, since that's exactly the same configuration as when you're charging... and obviously you would then turn the light on... which is exactly what the Caution says not to do. Duh? Can anyone figure that out? (PS - you have to stop a minute and think it through!)

Another discrepancy is that the box states "Powered by AC adaptor or 3X AA batteries" whereas the slip of paper instructions say "Powered by AC adaptor or Polymer Lithium Ion Battery".

I am hoping this nice bright light will work in spite of these not-good signs but do worry about the manufacturer's obvious lack of attention to important details.

reviewText:
Please note that every violin responds differently to different strings, so my experience may be totally different from yours. However, in this case, I really don't see what justifies the price on these strings. I gave the Kaplan Amo strings a week of hard playing in hopes that they would improve with age, and then I took them off (they didn't improve). They are formulated similarly to Zyex (also from DAddario), but supposedly are fancier and more expensive. They were indeed very similar to Zyex in some respects, including a similar sound, especially on the A string. However, they were significantly worse than Zyex in several ways, on my fiddle. The Amo strings were much less responsive.  This includes being slow to speak under most circumstances, especially on the D and G strings, and not responsive enough to play quietly (well, you can play quietly on them, but they sound terrible under most reasonable attempts to do this). In contrast, Zyex strings on my fiddle have had incredibly fast response, and a decent dynamic range.  Also, even more concerning, the Kaplan Amos that I tried had very weak D and G strings. They totally lacked any kind of power. In contrast, the Zyex strings I've tried in the past have had an awesome boom and growl on the low end when you want it, and smooth velvety power when you want it. In short: If you haven't tried Zyex yet (the *new* formulation of Zyex strings from the past few years), try them before Kaplan Amo - you may save a lot of money in the long run for a better overall experience.

I'd also like to mention the advertising point they make that Kaplan Amos are supposed to be warm, to compliment a bright fiddle. I did not find that to be so. They actually seemed a little on the bright side. I've used Obligatos and Larsen Tzigane strings for powerful warmth on this fiddle, and they worked fabulously. Kaplan Amo did not.  But, of course, your milage may vary.  Who knows; maybe I got a dud set of strings?
summary: In almost every respect, Amo strings were worse than Zyex strings (their sibling composites from DAddario). What's the point?

I wish I had had the courage to lay down the cash for this equipment years ago instead of wasting funds on two other less expensive audio interfaces and three pre-amps. The Apollo's use of its own processor takes the load off of my computer, and comes with a superb, clean mic pre-amp that gives my voice the warmth I have been seeking for the past four years. The pre-amp is so quiet that my noise floor is negligible now. In fact, I no longer have to worry about using Noise Reduction processing during my final mix down. Additionally, the Console software that comes with the hardware makes the entire experience of controlling the process of recording quite easy.

The Apollo Twin Duo and accompanying software are very powerful tools, and they have uncluttered my desk tremendously. There are many additional processing plug-ins available from Universal Audio (albeit kind of pricey), but certainly a whole lot cheaper than attempting to purchase the hardware originals.

I bought one of these to solve a ground loop hum problem. I play electric guitar, and have a pedalboard with stereo output. I run the left channel to one amp, and the right channel to another amp, and play in stereo. The problem I was having was that if I had both amps connected, they both had a buzz. If I disconnected the cable from the amp input of one amp, the buzz would stop from the other amp. This is how I knew it was a ground loop issue.

I did some research, found this Hum X, and decided to try it. Got it, plugged it in, and Presto! my hum problem was fixed. So I can say this definitely worked for me. If you have a dual amp setup, and there is no hum/buzz when one amp is plugged into your pedalboard, but there is hum/buzz once you attach the 2nd amp to the pedalboard, then you probably have the same issue I did, and this filter should fix it.

The thing I really like about this filter is that it removes hum at the amp's power cable. There are other ways to get rid of hum, such as using an isolation transformer (or some kind of direct box) between the pedalboard and the amp, but that can introduce its own noise. The Hum X fixes ground loop hum without inserting anything into the signal path, which is awesome.

The only down side to this is that it is a very simple electronic device with a huge markup. You're paying $$$ for probably $2 worth of parts. Somebody is making a huge profit off this invention. As far as I know, there are no competing devices that do quite the same thing, maybe because it would be patent infringement or something. But hey, expensive or not, it works. So I'm happy with it.
summary: Fixed the hum in my dual amp setup

reviewText: FIVE STARS all the way for these DR Pure Blues .11-.50 strings!  I did some comparisons, and found these to be the best-sounding strings so far on my semi-hollow Hagstrom Viking, far more interesting to listen to with many "voices" than the Thomastik Jazz .11's.  I won't take these off for awhile.  Note, relatively-speaking, these are not "bright" strings, as I noticed someone said, they are mellow and thick-sounding just as described by the manufacturer, without feeling heavy.  The .11 gauge is not "heavy" as it says in the description, they're more like a medium if even that, and very easy to play.  They are round-wound, giving me the "zip" sound and feel that I like when sliding my fingers along them!  Great Strings.  Comparing the Viking with these and the Thomastiks for me is the difference between wanting to pick the guitar up and wanting to put it down.  With the DRs I never want to put my guitar down!  You can hear these strings here:  https://soundcloud.com/littlemisshagstrom.  Have a Great Day!

I'm not sure gluing it again will do much good because the glue it had on it was so thick and viscus, like vaseline. It really looks like I'm going to have to rip it all off to clean off the old glue and do it all over again with a better glue. The pro for this mute, however, is that it's very out of the way.

I'd suggest getting a rubber violin mute. You have to cut a groove into on one edge to make it fit the full length of the bridge, but it works great. It protrudes quite a bit though (an extra ~1/4" from the bridge). I personally like resting my hand on it, but if you don't like that protrusion, it's a problem.

If I had to cite the one thing that truly makes a difference on a drum kit it would be these sleeves. Believe it or not but back in my early days of playing circa 1964 we gave no thought to cymbal sleeves and the result is a slew of otherwise great cymbals today with serious keyholing. I have provided a customer-supplied image at the top of this page to illustrate what I mean.

These sleeves positively prevent keyholes and the twenty-four in this pack will outfit most drum kits plus provide spares for those inevitable times when you lose one during teardown after a long gig.

The tubing is relatively thick-walled and pliable. The length is perfect for folks like myself who do not use top felts. Most importantly, though, is that they fit both 6mm and 8mm screw posts on vintage and modern stands.  Think of this as a very inexpensive way to protect a large investment in cymbals. I guarantee that a cymbal mounted without a sleeve is going to keyhole (or worse) in a relatively short time. I also can say with confidence that these will prevent it.
Works well for great price. Bill

reviewText:
I've only used one of the 5 cables that came in the package, so far. But i've been using that same cable, every day, for 7 or 8 months now. It's no worse than any other cable i've used, including Monster Pro, but all others i've used failed far earlier than this. The Aurum is still working like new, no signs of wear, no crackles, and no more buzz / hum than the others had ( including the Monster Pro ). By the looks of it so far, i won't need to shop for a cable again for at least another couple of years. Heck, i don't even know when i'll have to pull another one out of the package to replace the one i'm still using.
Some people complain about cables having molded plugs on the ends, but the plugs on these are holding up better than the metal plugs supplied on my other cables, which had a tendency to bend at the shaft or have the wires pull out even with strain relief springs / shrink tube on them.

Edit / update 8/11/2016 :  I've now been using the same one of these that i originally pulled out of the package some 18 months ago,
and it's still working as well as it did from the start. I play standing up and walking around, and leave the cable on the floor of my room
when i'm done, so it's now gone through hundreds of hours of being dragged around, coiling and uncoiling, being walked on, pulled
this way and that, and i can find no sign whatsoever of it being "compromised" in any way.
summary: One of the best purchases i've made

But a few days later, I have never heard such a sweet, mellow sound with such clarity on the highs and a deep bass with a right amount of volume.  Either I fingerpick or strum it, my guitar sounded so good I couldn't let go of it.  I finally heard the sound I've been looking for in a guitar.  Furthermore, intonation was perfect, feel is amazing..at long last my search is over!  True it is pricy!  But great tones doesn't come from cheap materials.  Then again, pls don't take my word for it..I suggest you try it!  Maybe it'll work for you..

reviewText:
I had a Vox Valvetronix, that I used as my practice-modeling Amp. The Valve went on the thing. I went to Guitar Center & tried ALL the modeling amps. The Marshall, the Orange, the Fender Mustang, the Blackstar... the ONLY ones that I've ever liked in terms of "modeling", is the Fender Mustang & The Peavey Vypyr. I am a Metal Head & the Peavey just made sense for me. The sounds out of this thing are quite simply amazing!
I am talking Crazy Distortion, but also VERY controlled and compressed....and these are only the presets! I DID get the Sanpera I Pedal & I don't know if I'd use the term "unlock" to describe what the Pedal can do. The Wah, The Pitch-Shifter, Volume and the Modulation can all be manipulated w/ this Pedal. But the kicker on this AMP is that it's as warm as a Tube & HAS No tube! It's just awesome. No breakdown (I know of). I think if you're gonna switch back & forth from clean to dirty & from clean to clean with EFX (delay, flanger, phaser, reverb, Octave) such as with "Floods" from Pantera, this is what you want. I can't express enough how perfect the distortion sounds. I am partial to the XXX, but the other Peavey Models on there are pretty-solid as well. I've never bought Peavey. Ever. Now? I am a believer. I ain't no deceiver.
Would buy again

Works great for a vintage Neumann U87, EV RE20, and other big mics. With what you save compared to the OEM shockmount, you can buy another microphone!

Now, this design is not quite as stable/precise as the "official" shock mounts, in terms of locking a mic into position at a precise angle. So it's a little more finicky to set into position. But it's under $10, compared to $350 for a Neumann. So there's that. And it does seem secure, as in, it's not going to drop the mic.

The suspension is just a little bit sort of "saggier", especially if you position the mic sideways, or at an angle. You can kind of wiggle the angle and position of the mic, within the suspension. Which means that gravity etc might gradually shift the angle or placement of the mic slightly, which could be an issue for certain kinds of precise-placement techniques, e.g., if you are using a mid-side array for drum overheads. Whether that's worth paying 70x the price for, is up to you!
summary: Can't beat it for the price!

I looked at other cases and had several on my shortlist based on price, features and reviews. Right smack dab in the middle of moving I needed to upgrade the case for my Les Paul Standard Plustop PRO from my current gig bag. I knew when I got the gig bag it is what it is - a cheap, kinda-sorta-maybe protected carrying solution. This case is the real deal.

It should not be a surprise that it fits like a glove, which is what I expected from a case made by the guitar manufacturer. This should not be understated- this will fit your Epi Les Paul like it is nobody's business. The lining is fairly lush and well-padded and the hinge top storage section is of ample size and construction.

The clasps function well and open and closes with ease. While in the closed position, your gear is safely stowed and will survive transport without breaking a sweat.

The covering is quite good for a ~$100 guitar case and the handle placement balances well when being carried. (I have heard some mention they are not crazy with the case sporting a huge Epiphone logo, but I personally think that is ridiculous. For me, if you are that brand obsessed, then go fork out the cash for a Gibson, but as for me, I don't mind "representing" Epiphone as I really love this guitar. Get over yourself.)

Great bang for the buck and your Les Paul deserves this case. It would do the same for you.
summary: Perfect for my Epiphone Les Paul

Received these today. Holy cow these things really are cheap toys.

In my opinion - these are not even really good for starter harmonicas for someone who is interested in learning to play. If you or a child think you are interested in harmonica, at the very least go for the Hohner Marine Band (Key of C or G) for a starter, NOT these.

To put these things into perspective:

I tossed one on the kitchen scale to see just how light it was. It comes in at 7/8 of an ounce.

For comparison, an egg from my fridge weighed 2 ounces.
5 red grapes weighed the same as this harmonica.

So if you want to get a feel for how chincy these things are, grab 5 grapes and play them like a harmonica.

FYI - my Hohner Marine Band weighs 2 3/4 ounces, so about 3 times as heavy as one of these.

Sorry, but unless you're buying these as a (very) little kids toy, I'd say stay away.

high quality! looks amazing!

I use this mic mostly for live vocals, although I have recorded with it too. I had a Heil PR20 and really liked it and decided about 2 years after using the PR20 that I wanted to try the PR35 out...the comments were so good I felt that it might be a real upgrade. Indeed it was.

I am a female vocalist that sings from alto to a very "low" soprano. (Can't hit true soprano highest register notes.) My singing voice is not super projection-oriented and I am not classically trained. I sing gospel, country, Americana, and some rock.

I  thought I loved the PR20...it was a real improvement over the SM58 for me and my voice. Handling noise is higher, but the trade off was worth it. Then I met the PR35...wow - just wow.

Every nuance of my voice, even when in my breathy lower register shows up natural, detailed, and clear. It is a delight to sing live with the mic.

That said...it is not SM58 "idiot proof" to use. As some on many forums have mentioned, the sensitivity and accuracy come at a price. You need to really focus on your mic technique. For me, I cannot use it without a foam windscreen...really noticeable issues with plosives. Handling noise is better than the PR20 but it is not absolutely silent.

For me the tradeoff is more than worth it.

As a bonus, the mic works well as a "old time music" play around mike if needed, too.

Note:  the mic has a high gain...it's a very hot mic.

Hope this helps.

BTW:  the pic on the site is for the old PR35...the newer one has a continuous grille below the main grille, not the little slots.
summary: Incredibly natural sound...but not effortless to use.

reviewText: Awesome built case

Sometimes the people next door make too much noise, thus making it hard to hear music through open back phones at a safe volume level.  According to AKG parts lists, the 271 and 240 models use the same superb XXL drivers.  In addition the 271 has an automatic cut out switch that mutes the phones if you take them off.  This feature is vital in studio use but is somewhat annoying for home use.  Like the 240,  two sets of ear cushions and two cords are included.  Cords for the 240 and 271 are interchangeble.

I used no equalizer or tone controls in this listening test.

After a 20 hour break-in, sound is very similar to the 240 studio version, as would be expected.  Balance is very natural, like live music, rather than punchy or  unnaturally bright.  Bass seems more tight and the lowest notes seem more defined than with the  K 240 studio phones. Female vocals sound very natural with both model phones, Male vocals sometimes sound a bit thin, especially operatic basses with the K 271 phones.  The K 240 phones really shine with bass voices and choral music.  Orchestral sound can be thin with the 271, especially when historic instrument recordings are played,  On the otherhand, the K 271 studio is superb at cleaning up bass heavy orchestral sound.  Having both reduces my desire to buy an equalizer, as most recordings sound ideal on one phone or the other.  At this point you may want to read my K240 reviews if you are not familiar with the K 240 phones. UPDATE AUG 2012: I am just starting to test Beyerdynamic  DT 770 PRO phones (80 Ohm) which are more expensive.  The DT 770 Has a cleaner midrange than either AKG 240 or 271, but is not as clean above 13 kHz. The DT 770 came from a person who is younger than I am, who now likes the AKG 240 studio better.  For an older listener, like me, the DT 770 PRO may be a better choice.  As my high frequency hearing declined I became more critical of midrange sound. Older recordings benefit the most from the DT 770 PRO phones, however many audiophile grade recordings sound better too, if I listen very critically.  My father had the same experience of becoming more midrange critical with age. Sound isolation is the same as the AKG 271.

Here is the science behind what I perceive,  the Headroom website allows one to compare headphone test data.  The AKG 240 has a smooth rolloff from 13 kHz to 20 kHz while the the DT 770 PRO dip and then peak, in this frequency range.  Harmonic distortion peaks at minus 50 decibels in the AKG 240 which is sometimes heard.  On the otherhand, the DT 770 PRO harmonic peak is down minus 70 decibels.  This is so low that any harmonic distortion products are masked by the slight background noise that is part of any recording.

Conclusion:  If your hearing above 12 kHz is weak,  the Beyerdynamic DT 770 PRO (80 ohms) is the best choice sonically due to it's super clean midrange and strong but accurate bass. You get the full sound of the AKG 240 with the isolation of the AKG 271.  Unlike AKG however, Beyer offers no diagrams or parts, not good if you do your own repairs.  If you damage the cord you may have to open the ear cup with no knowledge of what is inside. No spare ear cushions or cord is included.
summary: CLOSED VERSION OF AKG K 240  MK II  STUDIO HEADPHONE

reviewText: ok

Clearly this is not a pro level instrument. But it is surprisingly good... perhaps astoundingly good for it's price point.

Pros:
- It's well made for the most part. Well put together.
- Factory setup was pretty good. Better than the factory setup on some Gibsons, though I am not trying to imply that the quality of the instrument is in that ball park. It's not.
- The parts that are important for sound are good... The nut is cut well. The bridge and saddles are substantial.
- Soldering and wiring is well done, albeit with cheap parts.

Cons:
- Tuners are difficult to use... Particularly for new players that this instrument targets. A half turn seems to adjust pitch by about... Whoa... Just measured it. 1/2 turn of the E string tuner dropped it 2 whole steps. Not a subtle change.
- The quality of wood and workmanship on the neck prevents a really great setup. It can be made good, but not fabulous without way more effort than the instrument is worth.
- Lol at the knobs. Actually, I don't think people would notice the cheap knobs if the potentiometers behind them had more friction. The combination of fake-chrome plastic and very low resistance to turning creates a very cheap feel.

In short, this is a great instrument to learn on. Except for a bit of a hurdle with the tuning, learners should not be frustrated by this bass. I would love it if Ibanez would turn out a pro or semi-pro model in this size. But outside of that, it is hard to find something better. In fact, one path to getting a semi-pro bass in this size without the cost of a custom build seems to be examining several of these until you find one of these with a great neck. Then replacing pickups, wiring, tuners, and possibly the nut.

reviewText:
Behringer makes good speakers, these are very linear for the size and well designed for good bass response.  I thought about dinging it one star just because they are a tad underpowered with 10W per speaker (20 total) but they have enough headroom for their size as pc speakers or digital mixer speakers that I did not.  SELDOM do I ever need 20W at my mixing workstation but it's nice to have headroom, which these do have.  It's just that they want so much more money (1.5x) for the 40W total / 20W per channel version of the same speaker.  They should drop the 10Wpch and just make the 20Wpch which would be an excellent product.  Still, getting this ability for less than a benjamin is a great pricepoint.

The advantages are that these work well with all digital systems - I am moving to all digital workflow now and these speakers take optical or coax directly to the speaker, which is a great benefit.  On the coax digital you can use a video distribution amplifier to make multiple coppies of a coax digital signal to feed several devices from one digital source.

I use 24 bit / 96 khz most of the time but the speakers are rated to 24 bit/ 192 khz and autorange the digital input, so things just work no matter what you are sending to the speakers.

If you are not all digital yet, they feature a full compliment of analog inputs so you can buy these today for your analog mixer and when you move to digital your speakers won't need to change.

For flexibility - 5 stars
For value - 5 stars
For audio output only - 4 stars
For ease of connectivity - 5 stars

In summary - its a 5 star product at 99 bucks

In all honesty you don't need more than 10 watts at a mixing board - save the kilowatt amps for the house speaker systems - hopefully someday we will run optical cable to our house amplified speakers and connect them digitally from the mixer.

I would recommend you measure the power in watts you use at your workstation today and decide on the 20W total or 40w total version of this when going all digital.  That way you do not underbuy power.  Keep in mind that both designs have ample headroom on the amplifier.
summary: 2/3 the price anywhere else and digital inputs, optical and coax

For the money this is an excellent lav mic. I have two that I connect to two iOS devices to record two person video interviews (using the built in camera/video app).

My only gripe is the length of the cable (and the reason for the missing star) - really guys, 4'? The available TRRS extension cables are prone to 60 cycle hum (poor shielding), and Rode's SC1 extension cable is not yet available here in the States. If you're using it with a remote iOS device you're screwed. Anything close in (like the iOS device right in front of you, or in your pocket if your just recording audio), it's great.

Like all omnidirectional lavs, placement is key. You want it as close to the speaker's mouth as possible without having plosives (and looking weird on video). Placing it too far down on the chest will result in a buttload of ambient sound (the sound of the room that you're doing the interview in).

reviewText:
I thought I would throw my two-cents in about the new design and effectiveness of this soundhole humidifier.

After making a few homemade case humidifiers out of things like a travel butter container with many holes drilled into it and a sponge, I started thinking about how some of the cases separate the body cavity from the neck & headstock cavity inside the guitar case and not allowing the humidity to flow freely to all areas, especially the body where it is needed the most.

Even though I was getting acceptable humidification in the case I was concerned about the body being dryer in comparison so I went ahead and splurged the 8 bucks on these. (I actually bought three of them.)

I crank the gas heat up in the house in the winter and A/C in the summer, keep my guitars inside their cases and inside a closet. The humidity drops quite low, but the sponges remain moist for several days before I can no longer fight the urge to re-wet them. lol.

Two great tips in one:
Use a regular, more dense sponge, thicker like the ones at the dollar store. Cut them to size and stuff them in!
Throw away the sponge when it starts to get yucky and don't worry about distilled water, unless you want to. I can't argue using very pure water compared to the possibly toxic crap that comes out our faucets, but for one dollar you can get a boat load of them after you cut them to size, and toss them away without any regard when needing replaced.

Don't worry about the "thing" hanging in-between your strings. It will not damage anything unless you get the sponge  too saturated and it leaks. I will either squeeze the excess water out, or shake the container with the sponge inside until I am satisfied that it won't drip.

The humidifier will not cause any stress or damage to your strings by spreading them when you wedge this inside your soundhole.

If you ARE rough, careless, thoughtless, or stupid, you could possibly knock this loose and have it rub or fall out, but I would be more worried about the guitar and what it would take for this to happen. This would be more extreme to the guitar than the humidifier or any harm it could cause.

The top snaps on by squeezing the sides to release little tabs that stick through the top cover. The sponge inside is quite small, and there isn't too much room for a much larger sponge. The device is simple and fairly solid. Treat it gently and it will last forever. You can easily clean the inside or run it through a dishwasher. If you give the inside a quick rinse every few fills, I'm sure it would be a decade before anything "built up" to require extensive cleaning or replacement.

Keep an eye on it for the first few days and then weeks to get a feel for when you should be re-wetting the sponge.
Try to keep the sponge moist when it's dry.

I strongly suggest getting an Oasis case humidifier, (or similar) mini sized about 1" X 4" costing around 17-20 bucks.
This will take any guesswork out of the equation and give you fairly accurate readings inside your guitar or instrument case.

Remember, too much humidity can cause your acoustic guitar to warp. Too dry and it will shrink and crack, split the soundboard (top) also leaving the edges of the frets sticking out like the backbone of a fish and quite abrasive!

If you spent more than one hundred dollars on your guitar and live where it gets cold and/or dry, you would be negligent (if not careless) to spend the pittance to make sure your 'baby ain't thirsty', or worse...dead & broken!

Hope this helps!
summary: Works Fine & Much Better Than Nothing!

reviewText:
I am assuming this is a Chinese import.  The price is a bit outrageous, in that case.  If it is made in the USA, I apologize; in that case, the price seems fair, but it is, unfortunately, not very accurate.

I have used these (this is my second one) for years now, along with Oasis humidifiers (separate topic, but I have switched to the Humitar now when my Oases die).  I have always assumed they were accurate.  They are not.

Are they accurate enough to keep in your guitar case?  Yeah, probably.  Once the humidity gets below 30%, they tend to just read "--%".  This is fine, because if the humidity is below 30%, your guitars should be in their cases with humidifiers (or you should be humidifying the house/room).  However, I tended to assume this meant my house had no humidity in it, and I would panic.  That's not the case.  Additionally, they consistently read the humidity lower than it actually is, at least in the 30s and below (above that, I'm not sure yet--maybe it is accurate higher-up, or maybe it is always inaccurate).  I've attached a photo to demonstrate how it always says the temperature is higher than it is, and how it frequently reads the humidity as lower than it is.

I now have a more accurate hygrometer, an Acurite, which sells on Amazon for a fraction of this (and is also a cheap Chinese import, probably ruining the planet and the lives of the people making them, but at least it is priced to reflect that and is high quality).  This one accurately shows when the house is at, say, 16%, or 22% humidity.  I've found that, even in the dry winter months where my forced-air is blasting the house dry as a bone and I can't introduce humidity into the house for fear of mold, the ambient humidity is still 20-30%.  This is comforting.  Yes, it's too dry for guitars, but it's fine for them to be out for a few hours, fine for my electric to sit out, and it is much easier to maintain in-case humidity of 40-50% when you know outside the case is 20-30%, not 0%!  People have tested the Acurite and verified that it is accurate.

Similarly, a good hygrometer will tell you, during the summer with your windows open (or a/c running--yuck) when your humidity is 15-40%.  The Oasis, on the other hand, will simply stop giving you a reading when it gets much below 40%, or it will just give you a lower reading than reality.  Useless.  When it comes to guitars, there is a big difference between humidity of 29% and 36%, yet it is reading 29% at the moment (quite dry) when in reality it is 36% (too dry but not dangerously so).

So, for $30, you are kind of getting duped.  It is accurate enough (though still a few % off) in the 40% and above, but wouldn't you rather have something more accurate?
summary: Overpriced and not necessarily accurate--sometimes won't show a reading at all.

reviewText:
My experience with the ATW-1102 system is limited so, consider this review a first impression.

Judging from the lack of reviews, there's not many of these out there just yet.  But, this technology seems to be the direction of wireless sound systems.  The only down-side I've seen so far is excessive battery consumption.  Sound reproduction is excellent.  So, four stars for incredible sound reproduction.  Minus one star for battery consumption.  Read on.

I bought two of these from a local source to replace a couple UHF wireless mics which operated in a frequency range that was re-dedicated to public service entities by FCC in about 2010, i.e. 698 to 806 MHz wireless microphones are now illegal to use in US & Canada. (Mexico might also have adopted the same protocol).  The ATW-1102's are UHF mics (300MHz to 3 GHz) and operate at 2.4 GHz.  (That's over-simplifying everything).

Wireless mics require batteries.  And, most wireless mics do not have a battery meter to tell you when your power source is about to die.. So, you'll find yourself replacing good batteries 'just to be safe' and to make sure the thing doesn't die mid-sentence or mid-song.  The 1102's are no different in this regard.  There is no battery meter on these; they have a blinking green light that indicates low battery....and you have to be looking directly at the microphone to see the green light flashing on and off.  There's no indicator on the receiver.

I've found that mics which require 9v batteries operate longer and are more reliable.  (arguable).  Those which require AA's and AAA's usually require more frequent battery replacement.  The ATW-1102 owners manual suggests that two AA batteries should be good for 7 hours "depending on usage pattern".  My experience is that you 'might' get 3 hours with the 1102 mic continuously on and actually used for 45 minutes of that time speaking normally into the mic at 50-62 db.

They're simple to set up, easy to adjust and are engineered in such a way as to virtually eliminate feedback by manipulating on board gain adjustment.  I could stand maybe four feet in front of a speaker with a hot mic and not be afraid of feedback.

Were it not for the battery consumption issue, which I don't think is all THAT inconsistent with other wireless mics which require AA or AAA batteries, these things would be perfect.  Battery consumption is what it is:  there's better and much worse out there.  But, for the current price of these units, battery consumption might be a deal breaker.  Had I known beforehand that they'd suck this much juice, I might've considered other manufacturers.  But AudioTechnica quality is hard to beat.  The reason I bought these is because I also had some ATW-700's.  Excellent quality stuff!

At this writing there is a rebate of $25 if you buy two of the System 10 ATW-1102's.  It seems also that they can be purchased cheaper locally than on Amazon.  That certainly will change as the price will certainly have to come down.

And, that's my first impression.  Hope it's helpful.

I like Schubbs capos the best for banjo and guitar because of their adjust-ability and thin profile, but as a gigging musician, I need the convenience of being able to clamp the capo on the headstock for easy access when not in use.  I've had great luck with Kyser capos, but the lever sticks up, which can sometimes interfere slightly with your left hand.  This design is slightly better in that regard, but the angle of the part that clamps to the back of the neck causes it to pull the strings out of tune.  Even if I'm very careful, the strings are pulled slightly out - if I'm not careful it will actually pull the strings right over the edge of the neck.  Perhaps you can find an instrument with a neck the perfect size for this capo where this won't happen, but for me this is completely unusable - even for practice.
