The ec-50 is absolutely beautiful in the silver sunburst finish.  The frets are jumbo and make playing real easy.  I must say that I am a beginner-intermediate.  I read tons and tons of reviews on this guitar before purchasing (reviews from other sources, not amazon reviews b/c there are virtually none.) The guitar is marketed for more metal styles but, to my surprise, I found that it has a really decent clean sound as well (to my ears anyway).  I don't know much about pups but I know when I hit the overdrive button this sucker screams and has a really nice heavy sound. It has a three way switch and there is NO splitting of the humbuckers (just so you know). The tuners feel solid but I can understand someone more experienced than I wanting to change them.  The body fits really good against the abdomen and just feels good.  The whole guitar just feels "right" when I hold it.
I wanted a guitar that could do alot of different styles of music.  It didn't have to be the best at anything just passably decent.  I looked at the ec-50 b/c I live in a rural area and this was all my local music shop had to offer IN MY PRICE RANGE (stressed b/c if you got the cash then obviously get something better).  I plugged this into a marshall 15w basic amp and it sounded awesome, even on clean.  I recommend this to anyone who is a beginner-intermediate, especially because of how fast you can finger the fretboard.

Note: It doesn't matter really what reviewers say about guitars (especially electric).  At the end of the day, it is really the type of AMP you get that matters and what YOU like hearing.  That said, PLUG the guitar into some amps before deciding to buy. Any guitar.

I used this as an upgrade to the astonishingly cheap and poorly made plastic nut on a Squier Affinity telecaster. The spacing is a bit wide for the Affinity because it uses a 40.8mm width, and this is spaced at the Fender import width of 42mm. Consequently there was .6 mm hanging off of each side. Additionally the Squier nut breadth is 3.25mm and import standard is 3.5mm. It needed to be thinned, which took about 20 minutes of careful sanding on 320 grit sandpaper. Shaping the shoulders took a bit more time, but was doable with a thin file. The result though was more than satisfactory. Fender takes regular neck blanks for Squier and Fender and simply carves a little deeper between the first fret and the nut for these Squier guitars so as to make retrofitting Fender parts more difficult, and thus make counterfeiting more difficult/impossible. But relevant in this case just resulted in the strings being a little closer to the edges of the neck than is conventional due to the string spacing on this nut. It also made it a little more comfortable to play on the neck because the strings weren't as cramped at the 1st-3rd frets.

Anyway, as to the material of the nut, it sanded like bone. Plastic leaves behind a differently textured grit than bone, and if this wasn't bone it was an amazing counterfeit. Corian perhaps? It looks like bone and plays like bone and works like bone, and has a similar weight and density to bone, and was good enough for what I got it for. If you want to be fussier than that you may want to consider paying more than six dollars for the privilege.

So yes in conclusion measure your existing nut to see if it's American 43 mm width or import 42 mm width. Verify whether your nut slot is flat or radiused. Then consider dropping the serious bank on this $6 piece of hardware.
summary: Suitable for the purpose I purchased it for

Not only is this instrument beautiful, the fit and finish rivals any I've seen.  A couple of months ago I bought that yellow flame maple Slash-AFD Les Paul from Amazon just to see if I like it.  I did, so much so that I sold it to the guy across the street after 3 months for what I paid for it and added $200 to it and got this translucent blue beauty.
The cream binding at top and fretboard add a touch of smooth class.  Those fake mother of pearl inlays shine and glisten like they're lit from within.
It weighs a ton and I'm still taking it to my guy for a trigger job but I could probably live with it as is.
I just know that for about $30, he can have those strings laying on top of the frets so it plays itself.
An earlier review mentioned how much better it looks in person and that is true to the nth degree.  And it would look good with the pick guard off.
Two little chrome screws secure it and can be replaced in their holes and I bet nobody'd ever notice.

I bet you can't get one for under $600 new anywhere now, so I feel like I made an investment at the same time.
It doesn't come with a strap or a rinky-dink gig bag or anything, so don't ask.
DO however, call that Amazon Harmony number on any guitar you buy and they'll give you a 10% discount right then.
They are called Concierge Techs and those guys are great.  Kudos to Amazon for that.
It ships in its original box inside an Amazon outer box that's pretty well protected.  No complaints here.
Good luck finding one Boys, I don't hold out much hope for you.

I mainly use this and the Vater Vintage Bomber Beater as my preferred beaters (I also use more modern style ones occasionally.) The reason I like this particular design is it allows you to feather the bass drum or lay into it depending on what the music requires. I can achieve a wide dynamic range with it. Note: I play heel down and do not use any bass drum muffling beyond a felt strip behind my bass drum heads. I mention those facts because if your playing technique or set-up may lead to a different opinion of this beater. As I mentioned, I do use other beaters sometimes, so have some basis of comparison for the feel of different beaters on the same pedal. The heavy top of this beater gives a certain momentum when you are playing fast. I am sure it has to do with the center of gravity and weight, but am only guessing. The beater itself is densely packed, so you can get near the same effect as you can from a wooden beater head. But because it is felt, you can get softer notes if you feather it. With a non- or minimally-muffled bass drum you can easily coax old school sounds with this beater - something you will be hard pressed to do with some of the modern beaters with light heads and multiple faces. Of course, you will still need the technique to do so, but this beater allows it more than most other ones on the market.

reviewText: Can't beat this for price and effect.

I bought this Violin/Fiddle ( I will be calling it a fiddle for the purpose of this review) to help my 7 year old son practice his fiddle lessons. I wasn't planning on taking up the fiddle at the time I purchased this, so I just needed something inexpensive to demonstrate what he should be doing, or sound like. I had played violin, and cello as a child, and I also play guitar, and a little piano, so I am a bit of a help to him getting through his fiddle homework from his teacher.
I really wasn't expecting too much from this fiddle, and that is partly why I gave it three stars instead of two. I had researched many instruments under $200.00 and decided on this one, because it had real ebony fingerboard, and pegs, not painted black wood. Also I liked the fact that it had inlaid purling. The extra items that came along with the instrument other than the case, were of no real importance to me because I knew I would need to upgrade the bow, and strings. And good rosin is pretty cheap ( around $10.00).

The good: The fiddle came set up with strings and bridge. If you are a new player, it is intimidating to to string and set up the bridge on your instrument.
The fiddle did in infact have ebony fingerboard and fittings. Right out of the box, It was playable, but the sound wasn't very good.  I could have left it as is, for a teaching aid I suppose, but I wanted to get the best possible sound out of it.

The bad: The fiddle had a terrible smell out of the box, I suspect it was the varnish that was used. I could live with it, but someone sensitive to smells might have a hard time. The strings that come on the fiddle, and the extra set are really terrible. Tinny, and buzzy. I had already planned on upgrading the strings. I actually purchased a set of D'Addario Helicores at the same time I purchased the fiddle. Replacing the strings is a must if you want to be able to play without being frustrated by the scratchy sound these produce. The fine tuners were impossible. They simply weren't big enough to get the ball end of the strings through. They didn't look like the fine tuners I had been used to, so I took them to our fiddle teacher, and asked her to help me. She couldn't get them to work either. She said I would need to put a new tailpiece on.
I took it to a local luthier, and had them replace the tail piece that came with it, with a whitney style tail piece with fine tuners. The luthier advised me not to spend anymore money on this fiddle, as it was just not worth it.  I wasn't planning on it anyway, and I knew it was a really cheap poorly made instrument, so his response didn't shock me. The bows that came with the fiddle starting falling apart right away. The hair was constantly snagging on things, and getting ripped out. I decided to upgrade the bow to a carbon fiber bow, and was much happier with the results from that bow. The varnish on the back of the fiddle, comes to a really abrupt stop on the neck. The neck should NOT be varnished.( I saw some reviewers complaining that the neck had no varnish. This is how it should be. The varnish will mix with the oil from your hands, and become sticky, making sliding up the the neck really hard) This fiddle has a clear line of demarkation where the varnish stops. I noticed on my son's much more expensive fiddle, it is a really gradual fade that is hardly noticeable. Also, the neck on my son's fiddle, although varnish free, has been sanded to a really smooth glossy feel. This fiddle feels like it was given a preliminary sand with a rough grit, and then never finished. The action is very high ( the distance from the string to the fingerboard, higher action means you have to press harder to get a good clear tone from the string) this could be fixed by having it re-set up by a luthier, but I really wouldn't waste the money on this instrument. The case is really cheap as I expected, the inside pieces started coming unglued within a few months. Although I didn't buy it for the extra items included, the shoulder rest is also very cheap, it falls off a lot, and I replaced that as well. The rosin is ok. It works. I didn't receive the tuner with my purchase.

The verdict: This is an extremely entry level instrument. For the price, you can upgrade the bow, the strings, and tail piece, and end up with a violin that will last through your first year or two of lessons and is still pretty inexpensive. It is in no way professional level, as stated in the description. It was playable though. I bought a cello online many years ago, and what I received was a cello shaped object. Completely unplayable in every way. This fiddle served its purpose as a teaching aid for me. And I have decided to start lessons myself. I just upgraded to a french trade violin from circa 1890-1913 the difference is remarkable in tone, action, and response. In general if you are looking to get this for yourself or your child who wants to take lessons, I would say you are better off renting from a quality violin store. The ones in my area rent good quality violins for under $30.00 a month. Rent until you are sure this is something you want to do (i'd say at least a year) then shop around locally for an instrument you can try out. Or  use an online violin store that offers in home trials. If you are looking for a throw away instrument like I was this will get the job done for you.

I rarely disparage a product, but in this case I'm extremely let down. I was looking for a replacement for my trusty and faithful Tascam DR-1, and this expensive critter is not it. I play in a band and we routinely record our shows, so I set-and-forget my digital audio recorder for four hours at a time.

In all of my uses thus far, I have yet to achieve a satisfactory recording. The DR-70D just doesn't produce a clear and precise digital recording worthy of mixing down and sharing. Lately, I have used both my DR1 and DR-70D to be certain I get at least one good recording, and I toss the latter's huge digital file away. The DR-1 still does the trick--and with its built-in mics, no less.

I don't understand the reason for the underlying shortcomings in the DR-70D. I've used both the built in mics and a top-line outboard Rode NH4 stereo condenser with no discernible difference in sound--which is best described as "middy," ie, with little bottom and high end frequencies. I would expect a digital recorder to offer a pure, unadulterated sound.

Also, I was distressed to learn that all of my pre-sets would be lost when I change the batteries in the unit unless I plug it in to my computer while swapping. So I have to jigger the whole contraption around as I switch batteries. On the contrary, the DR-1 has a rechargeable Li-Ion battery that has held up for 7 or 8 years. Also the DR-1 is smaller and lighter, and has more adjustable settings for sound files. In fact, I have the DR-1 set to produce a simple MP3 output. Four hours of recording is about 360 MB. The DR1 is limited in its output choices, and the WAV file it produces is two or three gigabytes.

Sorry, but I'm 100% displeased with this product and likely won't be using it in the future.
summary: This Is Not The Digital Recorder You've Been Hoping For

reviewText: Really pleased. I like the fabric wrapped cables and these are really high quality at the price I have paid for cheap plastic cables in the past. Ordered more after first set showed up because they are a great value.

Bought a Takamine 40 years ago. It was an exceptional guitar for which I paid $125. Adjusted for inflation, that would be $800 when I bought this Jasmine.

I got a superb machine for the money. Simply superb.  It's not my old Takamine, but the negative differences are slight, and there are only two of them three days into my acquaintance with this guitar.

The first is that the finish is not as good. The sanding between coats was skimped, which means that the finish on the front has some texture; the sides of the guitar are also a bit rough.

The second probably flows from the first.  The tone is a touch wooden; it doesn't sing as the old Taka did.

Positives: the intonation is true at the twelfth fret, and it is playable (and enjoyable to play) with a slide. After the first tune-up of the strings, it stayed in tune. For its price, this guitar is a superb introduction to playing.

A very young child, or a small woman, will find this guitar a bit large and deep for true playing comfort. For everyone else, it should fit pretty comfortably.

The intonation is true at the twelfth fret, and it is playable (and enjoyable to play) with a slide. After the first tune-up of the strings, it stayed in tune.

Any beginner, and more than a few cost-sensitive intermediate players, will be pleased with this guitar.
summary: Almost as good as it was 40 years ago

reviewText: Nice picks with a wide assortment.

Alrighty, let me begin this by saying that as a musician who's been playing both live and in the studio for over 30 years now and as something of a multi-instrumentalist (I play guitar, bass, drums, a bit of fiddle, some keys and pretty much anything else I can get my hands on)...let's just say I've seen A LOT of tuners in my day.  From Radio Shark and Banana's to tuning forks to high end Sabine rack tuners and Peterson Strobe's...yea, I suspect I've pretty much seen/used them all.  With that in mind, if I could have only -1- tuner in my gig bag, REGARDLESS of price, it would be a Snark!

These little buggers are really amazing to say the least....very easy to use and dead nuts accurate...and they're reasonably affordable to boot!  While I mainly use the Snark for guitar and bass, I have gone so far as to use my SN2 to tune my Autoharp as well...did an outstanding job to say the least.  Because of the amazing accuracy, I've also switched to the Snark for doing guitar setups...as a person who currently owns around 30 guitars, I do A LOT of string changes and setups and these little Snarks are fantastic for setting intonation and such.  For those unfamiliar with this item, it's a "clip on" instrument tuner (I can't remember which Snark is which at the moment but be aware that some models are chromatic, some are not).  In the case of a guitar for example, you clip this tuner to the instrument somewhere (typically the head stock) and it picks up the instrument's vibrations.  The color LED dial is very easy to read (except perhaps in really bright sunlight) and the head even swivels so you can keep an eye on your tuning as you're playing.

Since I've seen a negative comment about this, I feel I should say a word or two about "quality".  First and foremost, this unit is rather small and it's made of plastic...ok?  It's designed to be exceptionally light weight and easy to use.  It's NOT a stomp box and you're likely to break it if you abuse it in any way.  In my own personal (albeit experienced) opinion, this is NOT a design flaw.  It never ceases to amaze me how many people will be abusive with their toys, then not understand why the toy breaks.  These units should be thought of as precision tuners and for what they are and what they do, the quality is excellent. The head is flexible enough that you should be able to move it to where you need it, the clip holds the tuner to the instrument securely and the soft padding on the clip prevents damage to the instrument.  With that in mind however, obviously the Snark isn't for everyone.  If you truly need something more "rugged" for things like stage antics or perhaps for younger students or you're the kind of person who haphazardly shoves everything into one bag after a gig, etc., a pedal like the Boss TU-3 may be more to your liking.  Again, the Snark is small and it's made of plastic - some degree of common sense is advised.

Now that said, I've been using my Snarks for nearly 2 years now...I thought the first one was incredible and as it quickly became an essential piece of gear, I immediately bought a second (I typically have at least two guitars on stage for an average gig so having a second Snark made sense).  In fact my bass player was so amazed with my Snark that after having just received a Korg tuner for his birthday, he went out and bought a Snark the same week!  Except for having to change the battery occasionally (a fairly common CR 2032), I have had no problem at all with these tuners.  My SN2 stays on my favorite Strat about 99% of the time...I use 2 rectangular hardshell cases to transport my axes to and from gigs and they both have plenty of space to leave the Snark attached to the headstock without damage to tuner or guitar.. if you're trying to slide a gig bag over the instrument or you have a tightly molded case however, you'll want to remove the Snark first as you'll likely break it.

While I use my Snark(s) for everything from setups to practice, I think where these tuners really shine is at gigs.  Unlike a pedal tuner, which adds just one more thing to the signal chain and another chunk of metal to the already weighty gig bag, by clipping this small, light weight tuner to the instrument itself, I find the Snark to be wonderfully practical.  Unlike other clip on tuners, the Snark is VERY easy to read...the dial reminds me of a high end, digital tachometer on a car and it makes those quick tuning checks between songs much easier and a lot faster (particularly after a song which may include some heavy trem use on the Strats)!  I just roll the volume on the guitar back and with the Snark, I can give things a quick once over.  For that matter, I have to say that because it's right there on the headstock of the instrument, I find this tuner much easier to read than most pedals I've used as well....it's easier to see and I don't have to be standing right over the pedal to see it.  With the extended number of segments on the scale, (compared with only 8 or 10 on many clip and pedal tuners), again i find the Snark to be incredibly accurate.  With both myself and the bass player using Snarks and our front man using the tuner on his Helicon, the band actually stays in tune thru each and every set!  As they say, Tun-ing is NOT just a city in China :-)

One last thing I would like to add here is regarding the different models of Snark.  If you need a chromatic tuner, then the SN2 here is difficult to beat...it is however, also a bit more expensive.  In various brick and mortar stores (ala Guitar Center and Sam Ash, etc), I've seen the SN2 going for over $30.  Still a bargain compared with other tuners, HOWEVER...if you're just a guitar player and don't really use alternate tunings and such at all and/or you don't have a specific need for a chromatic tuner, a Snark SN5 can save you a couple of bucks.  Works just as well as other models when there isn't a need for chromatic tuning..  Having a tuner with this ability is nice, but if you don't really need it...why pay extra for it?  My first Snark was the SN2 listed here...the second was the SN5 and on both my electrics and acoustics, as well as on my basses, both are equally effective.

The final word - along with a guitar, amp and a decent cable or two, the Snark has become one of my most vital pieces of equipment.  I can live without a distortion pedal or a delay pedal if I have to, but my Snark goes where my guitar goes! 'Nough said :-)
summary: The Snark - Best thing to happen since the invention of guitar strings!

I've tried a number of small battery powered amps, to include the Danelectro Sweet Honey, Fender Mini Twin, Orange Micro crush, Roland Micro Cube, among a couple others I can't recall.

The Danelectro and Fender amps just sound horrible if you turn them up past whisper volume.  I found the Micro Crush and Micro Cube to be way too loud given their intended use.  I wanted a amp I could play quietly, not at whisper volumes, but quiet enough so as not to disturb other house occupants.

Blackstar nailed it here!  For being a little plastic battery powered amp, this little guy can produce awesome tone, clean or overdriven, at my target volumes!  Truthfully, I think this amp is an excellent investment to literally guitarists at all skill levels.  Experienced players would at the very least find this amp's tones satisfying, and it's extremely portable.  Beginners would be able to start with an amp that can be played at reasonable volumes, isn't too simple or too complex to experiment with dialing in tones, and sorry if I sound arrogant, but I think this amp sounds leagues better than any of the amps you see packaged in electric guitar starter sets.

This amp sounds so good, a fellow guitarist actually mistook this amp's tones for my Blackstar HT5-R's tones once!  I'm sure he went and bought one too!
summary: Best small battery amp in my opinion

The primary knocks on the LPJ seem to be issues concerning aesthetics  and or durability. I think mine is beautiful! The maple veneer is well matched and evenly grained. The mahogany is furniture quality. The naked maple neck is unblemished and SMOooooth. The neck/body joint is nice and tight. The "satin" finish is evenly applied and, along with the "zebras", looks awesome.
  As far as durability goes I've got a 10 year old SG special in "faded brown" (comparable to the LPG's "satin") and it looks less used than my 7 year old SG ebony standard even though I use the special a whole lot more. My theory is that lightly finished wood can "rebound" from light knocks and bumps while enameled/nitroed/painted wood surfaces will dent or scratch.
  My LPJ plays and sounds great (most of the reviews agree on this point) and while it may not be as pretty as some guitars it's more beautiful than most of them!

Review of product:  compact, stable, inexpensive, absolutely perfect in every way.

Reason for writing review:  This little stand has changed my life, for the better.  My guitar has always lived in its case, in the corner of the living room.  I would play it a couple times a week, at most -- when I thought about it.  Now, though, the guitar is always out, always in sight, and I pick it up three or four or six times a day.  I'm playing hours more every week, my playing is improving, and I'm loving every minute of it.  When friends come over, THEY pick up the guitar and play it.  Why didn't I get one of these 20 years ago?

Absolutely the best $11 I've ever spent.  If you own a guitar, get one, and park your instrument in it.
summary: Thank you, Fender, for making my life better!
